column3: A Ghaziabad police constable allegedly fired two shots in the air at a dhaba on Friday night, following an altercation after the eatery's owner told him that food was over for the day. The police have registered an FIR against the constable, who's on the run. An officer said he has also been suspended by the Senior Superintendent of Police.

column2: PM's meeting with CEOs from energy sector in US fruitful: MEA
column3: Prime Minister Narendra Modi had a "fruitful" meeting with top energy sector CEOs at a roundtable meeting in Houston, the Ministry of External Affairs' spokesperson tweeted on Sunday. They discussed working together for energy security and expanding mutual investment opportunities between India and the US. An MoU between Tellurian and Petronet LNG was also signed.

column2: Pakistan PM Imran Khan flies to US in Saudi Crown Prince's plane
column3: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan travelled to the US to attend the 74th session of the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) onboard Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman's aircraft. The Pakistan PM was accompanied by Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi. Notably, Khan drove around the Saudi Crown Prince during his visit to Pakistan earlier this year.

column2: I'm overwhelmed: Zoya on selection of 'Gully Boy' for Oscars 2020
column3: After 'Gully Boy' was declared as India's official entry in the Best International Feature Film category at Oscars 2020, director of the film Zoya Akhtar said, "It has been a great year & I'm overwhelmed with the response our work is getting." "It's crazy to receive such news days after Lust Stories received the nomination for the Emmys," she added.

column2: Apna time aayega: Ranveer on selection of Gully Boy for Oscars 2020
column3: After 'Gully Boy' was declared as India's official entry in the Best International Feature Film category at Oscars 2020, Ranveer Singh on Twitter congratulated the film's cast and crew, and wrote, "Apna Time Aayega". He further thanked the Film Federation of India and members of the jury. "Well done...get the gold statue home," Karan Johar tweeted while congratulating the team.

column2: Indian multimedia producer hired by New York's Irene Mamiye Studios
column3: Indian multimedia producer Aseem Suri has been hired by New York's Irene Mamiye Studios as the leading multimedia producer. "I'm working on some very interesting pieces at Irene's studio," he said. Aseem, who is from New Delhi, is a graduate from IIT and Berklee College of Music and has worked with various renowned international artists, musicians and producers.

column2: Prince Harry, Meghan Markle donate $5,000 for pool in Mozambique
column3: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex, Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, have donated $5,000 in the name of their son, Archie Harrison Mountbatten-Windsor, to build a swimming pool in Guinjata Bay, Mozambique. Adam Knight had been running a JustGiving.com fundraiser and noticed a donor named, Archie HMW. "We'll... be thinking of Archie when we open the pool," he said.

column2: Police constable arrested for allegedly raping minor in Assam
column3: Assam Police has arrested two men for allegedly raping their 17-year-old niece over the years. One of accused is the husband of her father's elder sister and the other is her father's younger brother, who is also an Assam Police constable. Reportedly, she told her school teachers recently that she's been sexually assaulted over the years by her uncles.

column2: Pak 'least qualified' to criticise India on Kashmir: Tharoor
column3: Congress leader Shashi Tharoor on Saturday said that Pakistan is the 'least qualified' country to criticise India on the Kashmir issue. "Look at what they have done to PoK (Pakistan-occupied Kashmir)," he added. Tharoor further said that when it comes to national interest, it is not BJP's or Congress' foreign policy but it's the Indian foreign policy.

column2: Do BJP leaders have guts to sit on hunger strike in Delhi: MP CM
column3: Madhya Pradesh CM Kamal Nath accused BJP leaders of "playing politics just to be in spotlight" and asked, "Have they got guts to demonstrate and resort to hunger strike against their own central government in Delhi?" "If BJP leaders, including Shivraj Singh Chouhan are so concerned about...people hit badly by rains and floods, why're they protesting in MP?" he added.

column2: Special court directs Kalyan Singh to appear on Sept 27 in Babri case
column3: A special CBI court has issued summons to the former Uttar Pradesh CM Kalyan Singh to appear before it on September 27 in connection with the Babri Masjid demolition case. This comes after Singh's term as Rajasthan Governor ended on September 3 and he rejoined the BJP. Singh's post of Governor provided him constitutional immunity under Article 361.

column2: Stop slaughterhouse construction near temple: Digvijaya to son
column3: Congress leader Digvijaya Singh wrote to Madhya Pradesh Minister of Urban Development and Housing Jaivardhan Singh, who is also his son, to not implement former BJP government's decision to build a slaughterhouse near a temple in Bhopal. He wrote that feelings of lakhs of devotees were hurt. Singh has asked his minister son to shift the slaughterhouse to another location.

column2: I'm not running after Maha Deputy CM post: Aaditya Thackeray
column3: Speaking at a conclave, Shiv Sena leader Aaditya Thackeray said that he is not running after the Maharashtra Deputy CM post. He added that the decision on same will be taken by his father and Shiv Sena chief Uddhav Thackeray. This comes after Maharashtra CM Devendra Fadnavis said that BJP and Shiv Sena will contest October state Assembly elections together.

column2: Panghal 1st Indian male boxer to win silver at World Championships
column3: Amit Panghal has become the first Indian male boxer to win silver medal at the World Championships after suffering a defeat in the final. Panghal lost with a scoreline of 0-5 to Olympic champion Shakhobidin Zoirov of Uzbekistan in the 52-kg category final. The 23-year-old boxer defeated Kazakhstan's Saken Bibossinov 3-2 in the semi-final.

column2: Saw a hot chick, lost concentration: Kyrgios during match with Federer
column3: During the second set of his Laver Cup singles' match against Team Europe's Roger Federer, Team World's Nick Kyrgios said that he lost his concentration after seeing a "really hot chick in the crowd". "Like, I’m being genuinely honest. I'd marry her right now, right now," he was heard telling his teammates during a changeover.

column2: I have no complaints: Kuldeep on omission from India's T20I squads
column3: Spinner Kuldeep Yadav, who was omitted from India's squads for the last two T20I series, has said he respects the selectors' decision and has no complaints. "Maybe the selectors felt I needed a break...I see this as an opportunity to do well in Tests," he added. Kuldeep has played six Tests so far, taking 24 wickets.

column2: Delhi-Vijayawada Air India flight suffers damage due to thunderstorm
column3: Air India's AI-467 flight from Delhi to Vijayawada suffered damages and its crew members suffered injuries after the aircraft weathered a severe thunderstorm. No passengers were reported injured, news agency ANI reported. The airline has ordered an investigation into the incident. The flight had taken off from Delhi at 7:28 PM.

column2: 2 killed, 8 injured in shooting at a bar in US
column3: At least two people were killed and eight others were injured on Saturday in a shooting at a bar in South Carolina, US. Authorities said they were not sure whether there was more than one shooter. Four victims were airlifted to medical centres for treatment, while the other four were treated for non-critical injuries, the Lancaster County Sherriff's Office said.

column2: Hundreds protest against Egypt Prez after actor calls for demonstration
column3: Hundreds protested in Egypt's capital Cairo and several other cities on Friday against President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi, responding to an online call for a demonstration against government corruption. Mohamed Ali, an Egyptian businessman and actor who lives in self-imposed exile in Spain, posted a series of videos online calling for the protest. Sisi dismissed the allegations as "lies and slander".

column2: Winds force IndiGo to keep 20% seats empty on Delhi-Istanbul flights
column3: Aviation regulator DGCA has asked India's biggest airline IndiGo to keep about 15-20% of the seats empty on its Delhi-Istanbul flights during days of strong Westerlies. Aircraft consume more fuel when they fly into headwinds. IndiGo has been asked to limit passenger capacity to 157 people on the 186-seater A320neo planes and to 173 people on the 222-seater A321neo aircraft.

column2: PM's desire of hugging Kashmiris hollow: National Conference
column3: The National Conference on Saturday said PM Narendra Modi's statements on "hugging Kashmiris" and "turning Kashmir into a paradise" sound hollow and belie actions taken by his government. "Now we see PM parroting new catch-words. These catch-words...will eventually vanish into oblivion," NC added. The party further said that PM's dream of 'Naya Kashmir' is to disempower people of the state.

column2: Masakadza breaks T20I record in his final international game
column3: Zimbabwe captain Hamilton Masakadza broke a T20I record by registering the highest individual score by a cricketer playing his career's final T20I game. The 36-year-old scored a 42-ball 71 against Afghanistan in the ongoing tri-series also involving Bangladesh. Zimbabwe's win was also their first against an Asian side in T20Is, ending Afghanistan's 12-match winning streak in T20Is.

column2: Fitbit considering whether it should explore a sale: Reports
column3: Wearable device maker Fitbit is in talks with investment bank Qatalyst Partners on whether it should explore the possibility of a sale and engage with potential acquirers, Reuters reported. Qatalyst reportedly believes Fitbit could garner acquisition interest from Google owner Alphabet and private equity firms. Following the report, shares of the wearables company closed 11.7% higher on Friday.

column2: Twitter removes state-backed accounts for misinformation
column3: As part of its efforts to remove state-backed accounts spreading misinformation and political spam, Twitter said it has removed thousands of accounts for violations. It banned 4,301 state-backed accounts in China trying to "sow discord" about the protests in Hong Kong. Twitter also removed the account of Saud al-Qahtani, a former adviser to Saudi Arabia's royal court, over platform manipulation.

column2: Facebook building AI system to help users pick what to wear
column3: Facebook has announced it is building an artificial intelligence (AI) system that helps people with choosing what to wear by recommending changes to their outfit "to make it more fashionable". The system recognises garments and offers suggestions on what item to remove, add or swap. It is trained on thousands of public-domain outfit images deemed to be "stylish", Facebook said.

column2: Shah urges people to re-elect BJP to power in Maharashtra, Haryana
column3: Home Minister Amit Shah on Saturday urged the people in Maharashtra and Haryana to vote in huge numbers and re-elect BJP. "In the last five years, BJP governments in Maharashtra and Haryana have taken their states to new heights of development and good governance," he claimed. This comes after the EC earlier today announced elections dates for both the states.

column2: Sharad Pawar’s era of make-and-break politics over: Fadnavis
column3: Maharashtra CM Devendra Fadnavis on Saturday said the "breaking and making parties" kind of politics practised by the NCP chief Sharad Pawar is now over. "Opposition leaders are switching to the BJP because they have realised that the country's future is bright under the leadership of PM Narendra Modi," he added. Elections in Maharashtra will take place on October 21.

column2: Govt-backed incubators now eligible for CSR funds, says FM
column3: Government-sponsored incubators are now eligible for donations under the corporates' Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) spendings, Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman has announced. Research funding in science, technology, engineering and medicine will be counted as part of the mandatory CSR expenditure, she added. The research funding can now go towards publicly funded universities and IITs.

column2: Three ex-Fukushima executives cleared of negligence
column3: A Japanese court has cleared three former executives of the firm operating the Fukushima nuclear plant of professional negligence resulting in death and injury. The executives, who were facing five years in prison if convicted, were indicted for failing to put into place tsunami countermeasures leading to the deaths of 44 people.

column2: Last reactor at worst US nuclear accident site finally closed
column3: American energy company Exelon Corp shut the last reactor at Pennsylvania's Three Mile Island power plant, site of the worst nuclear accident in American history on Friday. On March 28, 1979, the plant's second reactor experienced a cooling problem that resulted in the partial melting of the reactor and the evacuation of 14,000 people.

column2: Prasad inaugurates Bihar's first all-women employee post office
column3: Union Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad on Saturday inaugurated Bihar's first all-women employee post office on the campus of Bihar Public Service Commission (BPSC). "This...post office will deal with all correspondent materials of BPSC competitive examinations and help aspirants in providing required postal services," he said. It's a symbolic move to encourage the empowerment of women, Prasad added.

column2: 6 dead, several injured in firecracker factory blast in UP
column3: At least six people were killed and several others were injured following a blast in a firecracker factory in Uttar Pradesh's Etah on Saturday. The police said that they are trying to find out the reason behind the blast. As per a report, as many as 15-20 workers were present inside the unit at the time of the blast.

column2: Won't harm your son: Supriyo to mother of student who attacked him
column3: Union Minister Babul Supriyo on Friday said that he will not file an FIR against the student who allegedly heckled him at Jadavpur University. His announcement comes after the student's mother appealed to the minister to not take any action against her son that may ruin his career. "I want him to learn a lesson from his mistake," Supriyo tweeted.

column2: Don't know periodic table also, make memes on this too: Sonakshi
column3: After being trolled for failing to answer a question related to Ramayana on KBC, Sonakshi Sinha tweeted, "Dear jaage hue trolls. I don't even remember the Pythagoras theorem...Periodic Table". Adding that 'she doesn't even remember what she doesn't remember', she told trolls, "If you don't have any other work, please make memes on all this as well. I love memes."

column2: American man drowns while proposing to girlfriend underwater on holiday
column3: Steven Weber, an American man drowned while proposing to his girlfriend Kenesha Antoine underwater during their holiday in Tanzania. They were staying in a wooden cabin that had a partially submerged structure. Kenesha shared a video of the marriage proposal on Facebook writing, "You never emerged from those depths, so you never got to hear my answer, "Yes! Yes!"

column2: Disappointed is an understatement: Plunkett on England contract snub
column3: After being overlooked in England's list of centrally contracted white-ball players for 2019-20, pacer Liam Plunkett tweeted, "Disappointed is an understatement." "I'm really happy for all the boys who got contracted. I'm not having a pop at anyone just disappointed I didn't get one," he added. The 34-year-old picked up 11 wickets in seven 2019 World Cup matches.

column2: Showing middle finger to women same as outraging her modesty: Delhi court
column3: A court in Delhi has convicted a man for outraging the modesty of a woman after she accused him of showing her the middle finger and making obscene facial remarks. The court ruled flashing middle finger to a woman also amounts to outraging her modesty. The ruling was made in a case of an assault that took place in 2014.

column2: Chinmayanand and law student exchanged 200 calls since January 1: SIT
column3: The Special Investigation Team (SIT) has said BJP leader Chinmayanand and the law student who accused him of rape exchanged 200 calls since January 1. The SIT added the law student and her friend Sanjay, who was arrested for extortion, exchanged 4,200 calls. The SIT has sent Chinmayanand's mobile phone to Forensic Science Laboratory (FSL) to recover data.

column2: Chinese journalists to give exam on President Xi Jinping
column3: Journalists working in the Chinese state media will have to take an exam that will grade their understanding of the 'Xi Jinping Thought', the socialist teachings put forward by the Chinese President. Journalists will have to take the exam to have their press credentials renewed. Those who fail will have only one more chance to take the test again.

column2: Pakistani MPs critical of Army released after 4 months of detention
column3: Pakistani lawmakers Ali Wazir and Mohsin Dawar, who are critical of the country's Army, were released on bail after four months in detention, their lawyer said on Saturday. The two lawmakers, part of the Pashtun Tahaffuz Movement (PTM), were arrested after a clash with Pakistani troops. PTM alleges extrajudicial killings and enforced disappearances of Pashtuns and other ethnic minorities.

column2: We'll stop attacking Saudi if it stops attacking us: Houthi rebels
column3: Yemen's Houthi rebels have proposed that they will stop aiming missile and drone attacks at Saudi Arabia if the Saudi-led coalition targeting them in Yemen does the same. "I call on all parties from different sides of the (Yemen civil) war to engage seriously in genuine negotiations that can lead to a comprehensive national reconciliation", a Houthi official said.

column2: Any nation that attacks us will become the 'main battlefield': Iran
column3: Any country that attacks Iran will become the "main battlefield", Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) warned on Saturday. "We've stood tall for the past 40 years and if the enemy makes a mistake, it will certainly receive a crushing response," IRGC said. This comes after the US sent troops to Saudi Arabia following attacks on oil facilities.

column2: User asks why FM didn't cut corporate tax in Budget, Mahindra replies
column3: Mahindra Group Chairman Anand Mahindra replied to a user who asked him why Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman did not have the "wisdom" to cut corporate tax rate when she presented the Union Budget. "Do you always get things right the first time? Do you not value & desire the humility in leaders to listen & recalculate their route?" Mahindra said.

column2: UK plans its biggest peacetime repatriation if Thomas Cook collapses
column3: The UK government and Civil Aviation Authority have drawn up plans for the biggest ever UK peacetime repatriation potentially costing £600 million if Thomas Cook collapses. About 150,000 British customers are currently on holidays overseas with Thomas Cook. The 178-year-old package-holiday company could fall into administration this weekend unless it secures £200 million in extra funding.

column2: China says Maldives is not 'mired in a Chinese debt trap'
column3: Chinese foreign minister Wang Yi told the visiting Maldivian foreign minister Abdulla Shahid that the Maldives is "not mired in a Chinese debt trap". The ruling Maldivian Democratic Party fears the debts to China could run as high as $3 billion. China provides what help it can to the Maldives with no political pre-conditions, Wang added.

column2: I wasn't expecting this: Radhika on Int'l Emmy nomination
column3: After Radhika Apte got nominated in the 'Best Performance by an Actress' category for her role in 'Lust Stories' for the International Emmy Awards, she said that she wasn't expecting this. "I found out yesterday when Anurag [Kashyap] told me...had to ask him five times like is this the Emmys?" she added.

column2: Call of Duty: Mobile set for global launch on October 1
column3: Call of Duty: Mobile, the mobile edition in the popular first-person shooter video game franchise Call of Duty, will roll out for Android and iOS platforms on October 1. The game will feature several gameplay modes such as 'Team Deathmatch', 'Free-for-All', and 'Search and Destroy'. The game's battle royale mode will support up to 100 players in an open map.

column2: Batman PC games on offer for free on Batman's 80th anniversary
column3: To celebrate DC Comics character Batman's 80th anniversary, gaming company Epic Games is offering six Batman PC games for free on the Epic Games Store. The offered bundle, which has a retail value of $120, features Rocksteady's three Batman Arkham games, as well as three Lego Batman games from Traveller's Tales. The offer is set to run till September 26.

column2: Spurs' Kane scores after falling to the ground vs Leicester
column3: England captain Harry Kane scored while lying down after falling down in Spurs' fixture against Leicester City. Kane got the ball in the penalty area after a pass from Heung-min Son but was fouled after which he lost his footing and fell inside the penalty area with the ball still at his feet. This was Kane's 14th goal against Leicester.

column2: Doubtful about our future: India's physically disabled team opener
column3: India's physically disabled cricket team opener Wasim Khan, who was felicitated with the team after winning T20 Physical Disability World Cricket Series, has said he is doubtful about their future. "But...acknowledgement by BCCI and government...is a step in...right direction," the Kashmir-based cricketer stated. Khan added that no matches are taking place in Kashmir after Article 370 revocation.

column2: Leicester take second place after beating Tottenham 2-1
column3: Former Premier League winners Leicester City took the second place in the points table after beating last season's Champions League finalists Tottenham on Saturday. Tottenham had taken the lead with a goal from Harry Kane, which was cancelled by Ricardo in the 69th minute. The final goal was a long-range goal from around 25 yards out by James Maddison.

column2: YouTube apologises after verification changes, rescinds them
column3: A day after YouTube changed its channel verification criteria, it has rescinded the changes and apologised for "causing frustration". It had said it would verify accounts based on authenticity and prominence, rather than for having over 1 lakh subscribers. After many creators criticised YouTube over losing their verification badge, YouTube said already verified channels will now remain verified.

column2: Gujarat govt website leaks Aadhaar data of citizens: Report
column3: The website of Gujarat's Real Estate Regulatory Authority exposed sensitive citizen data including Aadhaar cards, PAN cards and income tax details, among other documents, a French cybersecurity researcher alleged. Several users confirmed they could access the data via the unprotected download URL that the researcher posted on Twitter. The webpage has since been pulled down by the authority.

column2: EC fixed elections dates as per its convenience: Kharge
column3: Congress' Mallikarjun Kharge on Saturday criticised the Election Commission (EC) and said that it fixed the dates for the Assembly Elections in Maharashtra and Haryana as per its own "convenience". "They should have given sufficient time," he added. The EC announced that Maharashtra and Haryana will have single-phase elections on October 21 and counting will take place on October 24.

column2: BJP will win in both Maharashtra and Haryana: Vijay Goel
column3: BJP's Vijay Goel on Saturday said that in both Haryana and Maharashtra, his party will form the government and "people know it well". Elections in both the states will take place on October 21. Goel, who was protesting in Delhi against CM Arvind Kejriwal over the money being spent on advertisements, added that AAP will also not return to power.

column2: Government proposes social security benefits for gig workers
column3: The government in its draft social security code has proposed providing life and disability cover, health and maternity benefits, and old age protection to gig workers, estimated to be millions in number across India. Gig workers are people who earn from temporary or freelance arrangements outside of the traditional employer-employee relationship, working for the likes of Swiggy, Zomato and Ola.

column2: Tesla board must face trial over Musk's high pay package: Judge
column3: The board of electric vehicle maker Tesla must defend CEO Elon Musk's multibillion-dollar pay package at a trial, a US judge has ruled. A shareholder lawsuit had alleged the package unjustly enriched Musk. The pay deal includes no salary or cash bonuses for Musk, rather setting compensation based on Tesla's market value growing to $650 billion over the next decade.

column2: Government agrees to UP farmers' 5 demands out of 15
column3: Bharatiya Kisan Sangathan President Puran Singh on Saturday said the government has agreed to five of their demands out of 15. "The agitation hasn't been called off, it's just a temporary arrangement. We'll meet PM Narendra Modi after 10 days for the remaining demands," he added. An 11-member farmer delegation met the Agriculture Ministry officials earlier today with their demands.

column2: 12 killed after bomb explodes on minibus in Iraq
column3: A bomb exploded on a minibus near the city of Karbala in Iraq on Friday, killing 12 people and injuring five others, officials said. Before the explosion, a passenger exited the minibus but left a bag containing explosives under one of the seats, officials added. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack.

column2: Gut bacteria reason behind man getting 'drunk' by sugary meals
column3: Researchers have found that some strains of bacteria in the human gut are responsible for a man in China getting blackout drunk after eating high-carbohydrate or sugary meals. The case came to the attention of researchers after a 27-year-old man sought care in Beijing for bouts of unexplained intoxication that dated back 10 years and were getting worse.

column2: When I do patriotic films, I become a biopic meme: Akshay Kumar
column3: Actor Akshay Kumar said that whatever he does, someone always has something to say, stating, "When I do comedy, I'm called mindless; when I do action, I'm called repetitive; when I do patriotic films, I become a biopic meme." "No matter what I do, whatever I do next my last efforts are forgotten," he added.

column2: Deepak Punia 4th Indian wrestler to qualify for 2020 Olympics
column3: Deepak Punia has become the fourth Indian wrestler to qualify for 2020 Olympics after reaching the semi-finals of World Wrestling Championships in men's freestyle 86-kg category. Vinesh Phogat had become the first Indian to qualify for the Games and was followed by Bajrang Punia and Ravi Dahiya. In August, Deepak had become India's first junior world champion in 18 years.

column2: Protein behind slow bone fracture-healing found: Study
column3: Duke University researchers have found protein ApoE (Apolipoprotein E) slows down bone fracture-healing through experiments on mice. "When we decreased the protein level, ageing was reversed," a researcher said, adding, "Not only was there more bone and healing happened faster, but it was also structurally more sound." The mice were injected with a virus to block ApoE.

column2: Cap that gently shocks the scalp could reverse baldness: Study
column3: A University of Wisconsin-Madison research has found that a cap-like device that would send shocks to the scalp could help reverse baldness. This new hair-growth technology aims to stimulate skin with gentle, low-frequency electric pulses, which would coax dormant hair follicles to reactivate hair production. This could be used as an intervention for people in early stages of pattern baldness.

column2: Delhi Police arrest man with 500 bullets, arrange them as 'SPL CELL'
column3: Delhi Police Special Cell has arrested a man and seized five illegal fire arms and 500 cartridges that were in his possession. The seized cache was arranged on a table and spelled 'SPL CELL' with three guns lined above and two below. The cartridges were also arranged to form letter 'N' and 'R' on two corners.

column2: UP teacher on dharna booked for hanging underwear outside govt office
column3: A teacher who has been on a sit-in protest for more than 23 years over alleged land grabbing by a former legislator, has been booked for hanging his underwear outside the Collectorate office in Muzaffarnagar. A case under Section 509 (word, gesture or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman) of IPC was registered against the teacher.

column2: Delhi cab drivers start keeping condoms to avoid challans amid rumours
column3: Many cab drivers in Delhi have started carrying condoms in the first-aid kit of their cabs after rumours that not having them would invite a fine under Delhi Motor Vehicles Rules. Meanwhile, Sarvodaya Driver Association of Delhi President said carrying condoms was compulsory, adding that it can be used for medical purposes like to stop someone's bleeding.

column2: Pak thought our leadership won't permit Balakot-like strike: IAF
column3: Giving examples of the 1965 Indo-Pak war and 1999 Kargil conflict, IAF Chief BS Dhanoa on Friday said, "Pakistan has always underestimated our national leadership. Always. They have always miscalculated." He added, "After Pulwama happened, I think they had miscalculated, thinking that our political leadership will not permit such a (Balakot-like) strike."

column2: US signs deal to send asylum seekers to El Salvador
column3: The US signed a deal with El Salvador on Friday to help the Central American nation give refuge to more asylum seekers. Individuals arriving at the US-Mexico border through El Salvador should be able to seek protection there even if they intend to apply for asylum in the US, US' Acting Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kevin McAleenan said.

column2: China a threat to the world, building military rapidly: Trump
column3: Expressing concern over China's growing military might, US President Donald Trump has said the country is a threat to the world. Blaming his predecessors for not stopping China from stealing US' intellectual property to strengthen its defence capabilities, Trump further said the two countries were very close to having a trade deal.

column2: 3,000 out of 20 lakh FB volunteers reach Area 51 to 'see aliens'
column3: Out of the over 20 lakh people who signed up for a Facebook event to "storm" Area 51 in US' Nevada to "see aliens", only 3,000 turned up at the US military base. There have been several conspiracy theories related to Area 51, most importantly those pertaining to the US government's cover-up of secrets related to UFOs and aliens.

column2: Saudi Aramco has emerged from attacks 'stronger than ever': CEO
column3: Saudi Aramco has emerged from attacks on its oil facilities "stronger than ever", CEO Amin Nasser said. "Had we not acted quickly to contain the fires and undertake restoration efforts, the impact on the oil market and global economy would've been far more devastating," he added. Aramco is shipping equipment from the US and Europe to rebuild the damaged facilities.

column2: Firms will have freedom to cut prices: Maruti Chairman on tax relief
column3: Maruti Suzuki Chairman RC Bhargava said that companies will now have the leeway to cut prices after government reduced corporate tax rates. "They can (if they want to) reduce prices or use any other measure to the extent of anticipated profits to make a comeback in the market," he said. The effective corporate tax rate has been reduced to 25.17%.

column2: Actor Mohanlal chargesheeted for ivory possession after 7 yrs
column3: Kerala Forest Department on Friday filed a chargesheet against Malayalam actor Mohanlal for alleged illegal possession of ivory. During an income tax inspection in 2012, four elephant tusks were reportedly seized from his residence. Reportedly, the state government had allowed him to keep the ivory after modifying the law. Later, an activist challenged the order in the Kerala High Court.

column2: BJP, Sena to fight Maha polls together, will return as CM: Fadnavis
column3: Maharashtra CM Devendra Fadnavis said that BJP and Shiv Sena will contest state Assembly polls together next month and expressed confidence that he'll return as the CM. "The seat-sharing talks are still on, don't trust the reports," Fadnavis added. This comes after reports claimed that BJP will contest 162 and Shiv Sena 126 seats, out of the total 288 seats.

column2: Priyanka criticises BJP after farmers stopped from entering Delhi
column3: Congress' Priyanka Gandhi Vadra on Saturday criticised BJP after Uttar Pradesh farmers marching into Delhi demanding loan waiver, among other things, were stopped from entering. "BJP government talks about farmer welfare...but when the farmers...say they want sugarcane arrears, loan waiver...why are they not allowed to speak," she tweeted. The farmers were stopped at Delhi-UP border near Ghazipur.

column2: PM should have verified my comment on Pakistan: Pawar
column3: After PM Narendra Modi said that NCP President Sharad Pawar has love for Pakistan, the latter said, "PM should have verified my statement before criticising me." "He said I've love for our neighbouring country. I have been Defence Minister of this country," he added. "I will not criticise Modi...don't want to hurt the dignity of PM's office," Pawar further said.

column2: 11-member farmers delegation to meet Agri Ministry officials
column3: An 11-member delegation of farmers will be meeting the Agriculture Ministry officials after police stopped protesting farmers from marching towards Kisan Ghat in Delhi on Saturday. If our demands are not accepted we'll march to Delhi, said Bharatiya Kisan Sangathan President Puran Singh. Farmers from across the Western UP are holding march asking for full loan waiver, among other demands.

column2: After Taj Mahal, Agra's Red Fort gets baby feeding room
column3: After opening a baby feeding room in Taj Mahal, the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) has now opened another baby feeding room at the Red Fort in Agra. Agra MP SP Singh Baghel stated, "Supreme Court had prohibited any new construction in these historical monuments, so these rooms have been made in the existing spaces. The room is fully air-conditioned."

column2: 23 Taliban militants killed in air strikes by Afghan forces
column3: As many as 23 Taliban militants were killed in air strikes carried out by Afghan security forces in the provinces of Kandahar, Ghazni, and Badghis, the Afghan state media said. This follows several attacks carried out by the Taliban in Afghanistan. The Taliban's attacks come after peace talks between the militant group and the US collapsed.

column2: Amitabh trolls Sonakshi for failing to answer question on Ramayan on KBC
column3: Sonakshi Sinha appeared on KBC 11 to help a contestant and was unable to answer whom did Hanuman fetch the 'Sanjivani' herb for in the 'Ramayan'. Amitabh Bachchan trolled Sonakshi saying her father's name is Shatrughan and names of all his brothers are also inspired from 'Ramayan'. She herself said that her residence's name is 'Ramayan'.

column2: Haryana and Maharashtra Assembly Elections to be held on Oct 21
column3: The Election Commission of India on Saturday announced that elections for Maharashtra and Haryana Assemblies will be held on October 21. The elections will be held in a single phase for 288 seats in Maharashtra and 90 seats in Haryana. The counting of votes for both the states will take place on October 24.

column2: By-elections to be held for 64 seats across India on October 21
column3: The Election Commission has announced that by-elections will be held for 64 Assembly constituencies across 18 states on October 21. While polls will be held for 15 seats in Karnataka, there'll be elections for 11 seats in Uttar Pradesh, five in Kerala and four seats each in Gujarat and Assam, among others. The votes will be counted on October 24.

column2: Chandigarh biker finds 189 challans pending against him: Report
column3: A 21-year-old Chandigarh youth named Sanjiv has 189 challans pending against his motorbike for various offences between 2017 and 2019, as per a report. Sanjiv has claimed that he purchased the second-hand bike 1.5 years ago, and was only aware of one challan issued in July 2019. He asked, "Why did no one ever inform me about these pending challans?"

column2: Ex-Tinder CEO bribed witnesses in $2-billion lawsuit: Owners
column3: Ousted Tinder Co-founder and former CEO Sean Rad was accused by the platform's owners Match Group and IAC of bribing former employees to back his allegations in a $2-billion lawsuit. Rad claimed that he was shortchanged because IAC unfairly valued Tinder intentionally in 2017. The owners had sued Rad in January for $250 million over allegedly violating his employment contract.

column2: Facebook employee dies after alleged suicide by jumping off HQ
column3: A 38-year-old Facebook employee died after allegedly jumping off the social media giant's Menlo Park, California headquarter's fourth floor on Thursday. Menlo Park Police said preliminary investigation indicated that no foul play was involved in this "apparent" suicide, adding that the employee was pronounced dead at the scene. "We're cooperating with police in their investigation," Facebook said.

column2: Only Pulwama-like attack can change people's mind in Maha: Pawar
column3: NCP chief Sharad Pawar on Friday said people in Maharashtra are angry with the BJP-led government and "only another Pulwama attack-like situation can change people's mind." He added, "There was anger against the Narendra Modi government before 2019 LS polls. But Pulwama attack changed the entire situation." Earlier, he'd accused Centre of spreading propaganda against Pakistan for political gains.

column2: PolicyBazaar raises up to $150 million from Tencent: Report
column3: Chinese gaming giant Tencent has invested up to $150 million in Gurugram-based insurance aggregator PolicyBazaar at a $1.5-billion valuation, Entrackr reported citing sources. "Post investment, [Tencent] will acquire anywhere between 7-10% equity in [PolicyBazaar]," sources told Entrackr. A past report had claimed that Tiger Global is looking to sell its 21% PolicyBazaar stake for $300 million.

column2: Club Factory being probed over customs fraud attempt: TechCircle
column3: Chinese e-commerce platform Club Factory is being probed by the Delhi Commissioner of Customs over non-compliance with Customs Act 1962, TechCircle reported citing official documents. Club Factory's imported goods were mislabeled as business-to-business (B2B) shipment which were found to be a business-to-consumer (B2C) shipment. A few Club Factory parcels were reportedly seized in Mumbai in June.

column2: Zomato extends Gold service to delivery amid protests from eateries
column3: Zomato has extended Gold subscription service to food delivery alongside restaurant visits and has partnered over 13,000 restaurants for the same. This comes amid several restaurants' #Logout campaign over deep discounting by food delivery and table booking platforms. Restaurants' body NRAI's President Anurag Katriar responded saying that Zomato Gold in current form is an unacceptable proposition.

column2: Mission Gaganyaan next priority, no link with lander: ISRO Chief
column3: Mission Gaganyaan is our next priority, Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) Chief K Sivan said on Saturday, adding, "For this, we are working on different options." Stating that Chandrayaan-2 has achieved 98% of its objectives, Sivan further said, "We have not been able to establish communication with Vikram lander yet."

column2: 'Making fantastic efforts,' UN chief praises India for climate action
column3: UN chief Antonio Guterres has said India is an important actor and "fundamental partner" in international efforts on climate action and is making a "fantastic effort" in relation to renewable energy. He added that India's gift of solar panels to UN is "very useful". Guterres said this ahead of Climate Action Summit, which will be attended by PM Narendra Modi.

column2: Pakistan violates ceasefire along LoC in J&K, Army retaliates
column3: Pakistani troops violated ceasefire by targeting forward posts and villages along the Line of Control in the Poonch and Rajouri districts of Jammu and Kashmir, an Indian Army spokesperson said on Saturday. The Indian Army retaliated befittingly to the ceasefire violation, and there was no report of any casualty on the Indian side.

column2: Bus carrying Chinese tourists crashes in US; 4 killed
column3: Four people were killed and 26 others were injured after a bus carrying Chinese tourists crashed near Bryce Canyon National Park in US' Utah on Friday. The cause of the crash is under investigation, police officials said. The Chinese Embassy in Washington said on Twitter that it was sending diplomatic personnel to the area to further assist the victims.

column2: Iran says new US sanctions target Iranians' access to food, medicine
column3: Iran's Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif on Saturday denounced renewed US sanctions against its central bank as an attempt to deny ordinary Iranians access to food and medicine. "When they repeatedly sanction the same institution, this means their attempt at bringing the Iranian nation to its knees under maximum pressure has failed," he said.

column2: Taiwanese companies considering India as alternative to China
column3: Taiwanese firms are looking to invest in India's tech, renewable energy, auto and farm sectors, Taiwan External Trade Development Council's Vice Chairman Shih-Chung Liu said. Trade war encouraged Taiwanese firms with operations in China to look for newer markets, he added. About 120 Taiwanese information and communications technology firms are setting up operations in Bengaluru, an official said.

column2: I don't think super perfect characters exist: Sonam Kapoor
column3: Actress Sonam Kapoor said in an interview that she has never played a 'super perfect' character and added, "I don't relate to them. I don't think they exist." "I enjoy playing little imperfect human beings because humans aren't perfect," she further said. Sonam added that she watches her films again and never thinks that she did a good enough job.

column2: Rich will benefit, poor left to fend for themselves: Sibal
column3: After Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced lowering of corporate tax rate to 22% for firms that do not avail any exemptions, Congress leader Kapil Sibal tweeted, "The rich will benefit...poor left to fend for themselves." "Howdy Modi. Corporate Diwali...[E]xtra money in corporate hands will not boost demand. Need extra money in hands of rural India to spur consumption," Sibal added.

column2: Lopez wears 2000 Grammy inspired Versace dress at Milan Fashion Week
column3: At Versace's jungle-themed Spring-Summer 2020 show during Milan Fashion Week, actress-model Jennifer Lopez reprised her green jungle-inspired Versace dress that she wore at the 2000 Grammy Awards. The iconic dress is often regarded as the reason Google Image Search exists. "The world had the same reaction: jaw dropping," said designer Donatella Versace, who herself was present at the show.

column2: Karan's mom sprinkled Gangajal before party video: Vicky on drug use claim
column3: Speaking at India Today Conclave 2019 about Karan Johar's house party video, following which actors were accused of taking drugs, Vicky Kaushal said, "Five minutes before the video was made, Karan's mother was there to put Gangajal on us". Karan had shared the video of the party, which was attended by Deepika Padukone, Shahid Kapoor and Ranbir Kapoor, among others.

column2: 3 political leaders released from detention in Jammu and Kashmir
column3: Three J&K political leaders, including PDP leader Khursheed Alam and NC leader Syed Akhoon, were released on Friday, officials stated. They had been detained following the abrogation of Article 370 on August 5. Akhoon was released on medical grounds while Alam was temporarily released following the recent death of his brother, the officials added.

column2: Virat Kohli shares pictures showing his transformation
column3: India captain Virat Kohli took to social media to share two pictures of himself showing his transformation. One of the pictures show how Kohli looked as a 16-year-old, while in the other picture Kohli poses as if he is trying to avoid looking at how he looked when he was 16. "There is hope for everyone," a user commented.

column2: Amazon vows to be carbon neutral by 2040; to buy 1 lakh EVs
column3: Amazon Founder and CEO Jeff Bezos has announced "The Climate Pledge", a commitment to meet Paris Agreement's goal 10 years early by achieving net-zero carbon across businesses by 2040. Amazon has ordered 1 lakh electric vans for deliveries starting 2021 from EV startup Rivian. "We know we can do it and we know we have to do it," Bezos said.

column2: Facebook says it banned 'thousands' of apps that likely stole info
column3: Multiple privacy scandals-hit Facebook has revealed that it has suspended "tens of thousands" of apps on suspicions of collecting large amounts of user profile data. The suspended apps are associated with about 400 developers, it revealed. This comes weeks after Facebook was fined $5 billion by US FTC and a separate $100 million by US SEC over its privacy scandals.

column2: Sex abuse case against former Sequoia Capital Partner dismissed
column3: A 2016 sexual abuse case against venture capitalist Michael Goguen, which led to his exit as a Partner from Sequoia Capital after nearly 20 years, has been dismissed. The plaintiff, Amber Baptiste, sought $40 million as compensation for the alleged abuse and sexual infection contracted from Goguen. Baptiste failed to undergo medical examinations and produce necessary documents.

column2: Would rather be unicorn in revenue than m-cap: Infosys Co-founder
column3: Infosys Co-founder Nandan Nilekani, when asked about his views on the right way of building startup businesses, said that he is still a little "old fashioned". "I would rather be a unicorn in revenue, than a unicorn in market cap, and I'd rather generate cash, than burn cash," he added. Nilekani has invested in over a dozen startups since 2014.

column2: World's 1st vagina museum to open after crowdfunding raises $62,000
column3: The world's first museum dedicated solely to vaginas will open in London in November after a crowdfunding campaign raised almost $62,000 for the same. The museum aims to educate visitors about vulvas and vaginas while 'challenging the prevailing stigma surrounding them.' Founder Florence Schechter got the museum's idea after discovering a museum dedicated to penises in Iceland.

column2: Roof turned into showers: Kanimozhi on Chennai airport's leaky roof
column3: DMK MP Kanimozhi has posted a picture of blue plastic baggage trays laid out on the floor to collect the dripping rainwater at Chennai airport. "First it was the ceiling falling. Now the roof has turned into showers," she tweeted, criticising the airport authority. Heavy rainfall was reported in Chennai on the intervening night of Wednesday and Thursday.

column2: My US visit will present India as a global leader: PM Modi
column3: Before departing for a week-long visit to the United States on Friday, Prime Minister Narendra Modi stated, "I am confident that my visit would present India as... a reliable partner and a global leader". He added that his visit will "present India as a vibrant land of opportunities... and help impart new energy to our relations with the US."

column2: Prez accepts Madras HC Chief Justice Tahilramani's resignation
column3: Days after the Chief Justice of Madras High Court VK Tahilramani submitted her resignation after her transfer to the Meghalaya High Court, President Ram Nath Kovind accepted her resignation on Friday. Moreover, Justice Vineet Kothari, the senior-most judge of the Madras High Court, has been appointed as the acting Chief Justice of the court till further orders.

column2: I've seen many theatrics at UNGA: Indian envoy on Pak PM's speech
column3: After Pakistan said that PM Imran Khan will raise the issue of Kashmir in his UN General Assembly address, Indian envoy to the UN Syed Akbaruddin said, "I have seen many theatrics in the General Assembly." "Many people use their 30 minutes of global attention in the ways they want [but] people remember them for what they are," he added.

column2: Epicentre of terrorism is right in our neighbourhood: Jaishankar
column3: In an apparent reference to Pakistan, External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar on Friday said, "The epicentre of global terrorism is there right in our neighbourhood." Stating that cross-border terrorism has claimed over 40,000 lives in the past three decades, he added, "When subjected to terrorist attacks, any polity that's sincerely committed to the welfare of its people will surely respond."

column2: US to deploy troops to Saudi after drone attacks on oil sites
column3: The US has announced plans to send forces to Saudi Arabia in the wake of attacks against the country's oil infrastructure. Defence Secretary Mark Esper said the deployment would be "defensive in nature". Total troop numbers have not yet been decided. Yemen's Iran-backed Houthi rebels have claimed responsibility for the attacks, however, both the US and Saudi have blamed Iran.

column2: Fake pic accusing climate protesters of leaving rubbish behind goes viral
column3: A fake photo that claims to show rubbish left behind by Australian climate strike protesters has gone viral on social media. On Friday, an estimated three lakh Australians, and millions of people around the world took part in protests against inaction on the climate emergency. Hours later, an Australian pro-coal page posted the picture, which had surfaced in April.

column2: IndiGo appoints advocate Pallavi Shardul Shroff as director
column3: India's largest airline IndiGo's board has approved the appointment of advocate Pallavi Shardul Shroff as an independent woman director. Shroff is a managing partner at law firm Shardul Amarchand Mangaldas & Co with over 37 years of experience. She is currently on the boards of many companies including Apollo Tyres, Asian Paints and Paytm.

column2: Saudi reveals damage caused by drone attacks on oil facilities
column3: Saudi Arabia on Friday took media on a tour of the oil facilities damaged by the recent drone attacks and showed melted pipes and burnt equipment. At Abqaiq, the world's largest oil processing plant, reporters saw a punctured and blackened stabilizer tower. "We are working 24/7...This is a beehive," an official of state oil giant Aramco said.

column2: We stayed at post office during Gangs of Wasseypur shoot: Richa
column3: Speaking at a conclave, actress Richa Chadha said that during the shoot of 'Gangs of Wasseypur', they stayed in government guest houses, collector's office and a post office. "My first memory...is getting up in the morning to switch on the geyser as I was told it takes 2-3 hours for the water to warm up," she added.

column2: Dravid spends time with Team India, seen giving tips to players
column3: Former captain Rahul Dravid was seen interacting with Team India players and giving tips to them during their practice session in Bengaluru ahead of the third T20I against South Africa. Dravid also met India head coach Ravi Shastri. BCCI shared a picture of Shastri and Dravid on Twitter with the caption, "When two greats of Indian cricket meet."

column2: Kindness foremost trait desired by students in partners: Study
column3: A study conducted on 2,700 college students from five countries has revealed that the most important trait desired in a partner is kindness. The attributes considered were physical attractiveness, financial prospects, kindness, humour, chastity, religiosity, desire for children, and creativity. After kindness, men heavily favoured physical attractiveness while women chose good financial prospects.

column2: Mother sells house to buy daughter's medical cannabis
column3: Elaine Levy, the mother of a severely epileptic 25-year-old woman, has put her house up for sale after spending her family's savings on private prescriptions for medical cannabis. Levy said that her daughter no longer needed a wheelchair after using full extract cannabis oil. "Her IQ has gone up... It's not a cure but the result is phenomenal," Levy added.

column2: Man brings down 2 pillars at Hampi while taking selfie, arrested
column3: A 45-year-old man has been arrested after he accidentally brought down two pillars while taking a selfie at Hampi, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Nagaraj, a resident of Bengaluru, has been charged under the sections of the Ancient Monuments and Archaeological Sites and Remains Act 1958, and has been remanded to judicial custody for 15 days.

column2: Gang in Argentina smuggles cocaine in plastic penises, arrested
column3: Police in Argentina have arrested members of a gang of drug dealers who were accused of smuggling cocaine hidden inside plastic penises. A video showing 10 phallic containers was released by police following a bust on home of a Peruvian couple who allegedly led the gang. The gang used code words like 'grandmother' and 'baby' to describe amount of drugs.

column2: Umbrella jammed in door locks workers out of US office for 2 days
column3: Employees at a company based in US' Washington DC were locked out of their office for two days after an umbrella fell and jammed the door. Neeraj Agrawal, a spokesman for cryptocurrency non-profit Coin Center, tweeted photo evidence of the incident, which quickly went viral. "This is a 40 second problem tops," a user tweeted reacting to the viral post.

column2: Rohit shares video of Dhawan talking to himself; Dhawan trolls himself
column3: India opener Rohit Sharma took to Instagram to share a video of Shikhar Dhawan talking to himself on a flight. "No, no, he isn't talking to me! And he's too old to have an imaginary friend. Why so loco jattji," he wrote. Responding to it, Dhawan said he was learning shayari, adding, "Kaash itne dil se padhaayi bhi kari hoti."

column2: ICC describes Dravid as left-handed batsman in Hall of Fame, criticised
column3: The ICC mistakenly listed former India captain Rahul Dravid as a left-handed batsman in the 'Hall of Fame' section on their official website. "Incorrect batting style is mentioned in the Hall of Fame list. This is a big mistake," a cricket fan tweeted. "A world governing body can't get facts right of a legend," wrote another.

column2: Time has come for MS Dhoni to quit international cricket: Sunil Gavaskar
column3: Ex-India captain Sunil Gavaskar has said the time has come for MS Dhoni to quit international cricket. "Everybody has a shelf life. He should be going without being pushed out. He should be going on his own terms," Gavaskar added. "He's 38 and will be 39-plus during next T20 World Cup. I think India should be looking ahead," he said.

column2: I had given up on cricket after 2007 World Cup snub: Gautam Gambhir
column3: Ex-India opener Gautam Gambhir has said he had given up on cricket after he wasn't selected in India squad for 2007 World Cup. "Before that, I had missed both U-14 and U-19 World Cups. In 2007 I thought I was the closest to play the World Cup," he added. He further called it the "lowest moment" in his cricketing career.

column2: Millions protest across the world demanding action on climate change
column3: Millions of people joined protests across the world on Friday to demand global leaders to act against climate change. The global climate strike is being led by the 16-year-old Swedish activist Greta Thunberg. Students from several schools joined protests throughout the day in Mumbai, with thousands of events having been planned in more than 130 countries.

column2: US sanctions Iran's central bank in highest ever sanctions on a nation
column3: US President Donald Trump on Friday announced a new round of sanctions against Iran's central bank, calling the new penalties the "highest sanctions ever imposed on a country". His remarks came days after he ordered to "substantially" increase sanctions on Iran. The sanctions come after the US blamed Iran for the drone attacks on two Saudi oil facilities last week.

column2: Dhawan calls Rohit, Jadeja caring dads; shares team's flight video
column3: India opener Shikhar Dhawan took to Instagram to post an in-flight video of the team travelling to Bengaluru. In the video Dhawan can be seen asking Rohit Sharma, who was arranging toys, what he has bought for his daughter and later asking Ravindra Jadeja the same. "Meet the loving and caring fathers from our team," Dhawan captioned the video.

column2: WannaCry ransomware still active worldwide: Report
column3: Two years after the initial WannaCry ransomware attack, it still remains active with 12,000 variants in circulation, Sophos researchers revealed. Sophos claimed in August alone it detected over 4.3 million attempts by infected computers to spread the variants, with 8.8% located in India. It added the WannaCry variants were able to bypass the 'kill switch' that stopped the 2017 spread.

column2: US Senator asks Facebook CEO to sell WhatsApp, Instagram; he refuses
column3: US Senator Josh Hawley on Thursday asked Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg to sell WhatsApp and Instagram to prove that Facebook "is serious about bias, privacy and competition", to which Zuckerberg said "no". Hawley claimed Zuckerberg also refused submitting to an independent, third-party audit on censorship. Facebook Co-founder Chris Hughes had in May called for breaking up the social media giant.

column2: Uber opposes govt's move to likely cap surge prices: Reports
column3: Ride-hailing giant Uber has reportedly contested that restricting cab fares would result in lower earnings for the drivers. This follows reports claiming that the government will likely cap surge prices charged by cab aggregators at thrice the base price during peak hours. Uber reportedly said drivers in Bengaluru, where fares are regulated, on average earned 8-15% less than in Hyderabad.

column2: Indonesian airline Lion Air probes passenger data breach
column3: Indonesia's biggest private carrier, Lion Air, has said it is investigating a data breach that compromised customer data from its units Malaysia-based Malindo Air and Thai Lion Air. Reportedly, data of about 35 million passengers like phone numbers and passport details, was stolen and circulated. Malindo Air said its passenger data was hosted on cloud-based services including Amazon Web Services.

column2: YouTube updates criteria for channel verification
column3: YouTube has announced changes to its eligibility criteria for channel verification starting late October. Unlike the present criteria of channels with over 1,00,000 subscribers receiving verification, YouTube will verify them based on their "authenticity" and "prominence". It also announced a "new look" for the verified symbol, swapping the checkmark with a grey-coloured swipe across channel name.

column2: Ajoy Kumar appointed as AAP's national spokesperson
column3: Ajoy Kumar, who joined the Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) on Thursday after quitting from the post of Jharkhand Congress chief, was appointed as the party's national spokesperson. The announcement was made by AAP MLA Saurabh Bharadwaj on Friday. Upon joining, Kumar had said that AAP is the only party which gives the common man a chance to serve through politics.

column2: BJP's countdown in Uttar Pradesh has begun: Akhilesh Yadav
column3: Samajwadi Party chief Akhilesh Yadav on Friday said that the countdown for the BJP government in Uttar Pradesh has begun. "Poor people are being humiliated in the state. The direction in which the UP government is headed is not right," he added. Yadav asserted that his party will form the government in the 2022 Assembly elections.

column2: BJP protests in Kolkata against Jadavpur University incident
column3: A day after Union Minister Babul Supriyo was allegedly heckled in West Bengal's Jadavpur University, BJP on Friday took out a protest rally in Kolkata against the incident. "BJP leader was heckled and beaten by Naxals and students of Students' Federation of India," BJP state vice-president Jay Prakash Majumdar said. "What happened...was a heinous incident," Majumdar also said.

column2: E-pharmacy startup Digi-Prex raises $5.5 mn in seed funding
column3: Online subscription pharmacy startup Digi-Prex has raised $5.5 million in seed funding from Khosla Ventures, Vedanta Capital, Y Combinator, Quiet Capital and SV Angel. Justin Mateen, the Co-founder of dating app Tinder, also participated in the round. Founded in 2019 by Samarth Sindhi, the Hyderabad-based startup offers doorstep delivery of prescribed medicines to patients with chronic diseases.

column2: Monitoring listings to enforce e-cigarette ban: E-comm firms
column3: E-commerce giants Amazon and Flipkart on Thursday said they are monitoring the listings on their platforms to ensure that sellers do not offer e-cigarettes. This comes after the government banned the sales, production and advertisement of e-cigarettes, with up to three-year jail-time for offenders. Amazon said it would delist any such products in case they are evasively listed by sellers.

column2: Drug to treat enlarged prostate may slow Parkinson's disease
column3: An international team of scientists claimed that a drug used to treat enlarged prostates may be a powerful medicine against Parkinson's disease. Terazosin, a drug that relaxes the muscles of the bladder and prostate, may help by activating an enzyme called PGK1 which can prevent the brain cell death associated with Parkinson's disease.

column2: 6 dead after allegedly consuming illicit liquor in Uttarakhand
column3: Six people died and three were hospitalised on Friday after allegedly consuming illicit alcohol in Uttarakhand's Dehradun. "We are trying to find out the exact cause of death. As per the initial information we have received, illicit alcohol could be the reason behind deaths," police said. BJP MLA Ganesh Joshi expressed disappointment over the incident and called for an investigation.

column2: How does India's corporate tax rate compare with other Asian economies?
column3: India's reduced base corporate tax rate of 22% is in line with the rest of Asia. The effective rate, after including surcharge and cess, will be 25.2% and applicable to companies that aren't availing any incentives or exemptions. New manufacturing companies formed from October 1 will attract an effective rate of 17.01%, the same level as in Singapore.

column2: Man sees everything in miniature after stroke damages brain
column3: A sexagenarian man from the Netherlands whose brain was damaged by a stroke now sees all objects approximately a third smaller than their actual size. A CT scan of his brain revealed he had experienced a stroke in the part of brain responsible for visual processing. The man told doctors that he thought his clothes appeared to be too small.

column2: Pandya reveals he used to travel in trucks to play, shares throwback pic
column3: India all-rounder Hardik Pandya took to Instagram to reveal he used to travel in trucks to play local matches. The 25-year-old shared a throwback picture of himself standing on a truck. "#majorthrowback to those days when I'd travel in a truck to play local matches which has taught me so much. It's been an amazing journey so far," he wrote.

column2: China lured it with planes: Taiwan as Kiribati switches ties to China
column3: Taiwan has said that China offered airplanes and ferries to lure the Pacific island nation of Kiribati after it severed diplomatic ties with Taiwan in order to establish relations with China. Kiribati's decision came only four days after the Solomon Islands cut ties with Taiwan in favour of China. Only 15 countries now have diplomatic relations with Taiwan.

column2: Shaman detained while walking across Russia to exorcise Putin
column3: A self-styled "warrior-shaman" was detained while walking across the country to Moscow to "drive the evil spirit of (Russian President Vladimir) Putin from the Kremlin". Alexander Gabyshev had begun his trek in March and had walked nearly 3,000 kilometres into his journey. Police said Gabyshev was detained in Siberia as he was wanted for committing offences on Yakutia territory.

column2: Whistleblower complaint about Trump involves Ukraine: Reports
column3: A whistleblower's complaint about US President Donald Trump's phone call with a world leader involves Ukraine, as per reports. The whistleblower filed the report after learning of a "promise" Trump had made to the leader over the phone call, reports added. The Trump administration has withheld the details of the report from Congress.

column2: Philippines reports first case of polio in 19 years
column3: The Philippines will vaccinate millions of children against polio as it reported two cases this week, 19 years after it was declared free of the disease. The Philippines blamed poor immunisation coverage, a lack of sanitation and proper hygiene as among the reasons for polio's return. Afghanistan, Nigeria and Pakistan are the last three countries where polio is still present.

column2: People want to see batsmen in T20s, bowlers spoil party: Shamsi
column3: South African spinner Tabraiz Shamsi has said that he feels T20 is a batsman's game and bowlers are just there to "spoil the party". "People obviously are coming there to see batsmen hit fours and sixes. They're not there to see you bowl a maiden over," he added. He further said people's expectations from batsmen put more pressure on them.

column2: Manish beats top seed to win Men's World Boxing C'ships bronze
column3: India's Manish Kaushik secured a bronze in the 63 kg category after his display against top seed Andy Cruz Gómez at the Men's World Boxing Championships. Kaushik had earlier beaten fourth-seeded Baatarsukhin Chinzorig and becomes the fifth Indian to win a medal at the World Championships. Meanwhile, Amit Panghal became the first Indian to enter a World Boxing Championships final.

column2: Twitter tests 'Hide Replies' feature in US and Japan
column3: Twitter has announced it is testing the 'Hide Replies' feature in the US and Japan, after initially testing the same in Canada. The feature lets a Twitter user hide any reply to their tweet, which they deem irrelevant, abusive or offensive. Hidden replies can be seen by the users who choose to click on a dedicated icon to view them.

column2: Those who assaulted me will be mentally rehabilitated: Supriyo
column3: Union Minister Babul Supriyo on Friday said that the students who assaulted him will be mentally rehabilitated so that they "behave as students". "You shall be found out by us soon but don't worry, you shall not be treated in the manner you treated me," he tweeted. Supriyo on Thursday was allegedly heckled by some students at Jadavpur University.

column2: Pharmacy startup Generico raises $14 million led by Lightbox
column3: Mumbai-based pharmacy retail startup Generico has raised $14 million in a Series A funding round led by venture capital firm Lightbox Ventures. The startup's existing investors Tomorrow Capital and Whiteboard Capital also participated in the round. Founded in 2017 by IIT alumni Siddharth Gadia and Girish Agarwal, Generico runs an offline pharmacy retail chain focussed on generic medicines.

column2: 3 billion North America birds have died due to human activities
column3: A new study has found that around three billion birds have died due to human activities in the past 50 years. "[F]or the first time, results [also] showed pervasive losses among common birds across all habitats, including backyard birds," a researcher said. The most severe impact was observed in grassland birds with over 720 million of them dead since 1970.

column2: Canberra 1st non-European city to shift to 100% renewable energy
column3: The Australian capital city of Canberra will become the first city outside Europe to shift from fossil fuel to 100% renewable energy. From January 1, 2020, Canberra will join seven other districts around the world that produce or purchase the equivalent of their total electricity consumption from renewable sources. Notably, Canberra has a population over 400,000.

column2: One of solar system's most powerful volcanoes to erupt on Io
column3: Loki Patera, a volcano on Jupiter's moon Io, considered to be one of the most powerful volcanoes in the solar system is on the brink of eruption. Loki is around 203 kilometres wide and has a lava lake at its centre. The researchers had correctly predicted the volcano's last eruption, which took place in May 2018.

column2: Uttar Pradesh CM visits flood-affected areas in Varanasi
column3: Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath on Friday visited the flood-affected areas in Varanasi with a team of National Disaster Response Force (NDRF). As per reports, the Ganga river has breached the danger mark in Varanasi following heavy rains. At least 15 NDRF boats and other private ferries have been deployed to rescue stranded people.

column2: Accused in mob violence won't get govt jobs: Bihar govt
column3: The Bihar government has decided that the accused in a mob violence case will automatically get disqualified for any job in the government. It was further stated that if a government employee is accused in such a case, they might lose their job. As per reports, 39 mob violence cases have been reported across Bihar in the last two-and-a-half months.

column2: SC notice to Centre on Rohith Vemula, Payal Tadvi's mothers' plea
column3: The Supreme Court on Friday issued a notice to the Centre on a petition filed by mothers of Rohith Vemula and Payal Tadvi for taking steps to end caste-based discrimination in educational institutions. Reportedly, the notice was also sent to the UGC. Vemula and Tadvi committed suicide allegedly after facing caste-based discrimination in January 2016 and May 2019, respectively.

column2: OnePlus 7T to charge 23% faster with Warp Charge 30T: CEO Pete Lau
column3: Ahead of its official unveiling, the OnePlus 7T has been confirmed to get the Warp Charge 30T technology, which claims 23% faster charging speeds even while the device is in use. CEO Pete Lau also confirmed that the latest Warp Charge delivers 6A amperage at 5V voltage to attain 30W. OnePlus 7T will be launched in India on September 26.

column2: OnePlus 7T launch event tickets sold out under '7T' seconds
column3: Tickets for OnePlus 7T launch event that went on sale today have been sold out on the very first day. 'Gone under 7T seconds' tweeted OnePlus India. The launch event that will take place on September 26 seeks to share the products while witnessing the audiences' experiences firsthand. OnePlus has also announced a special surprise for the launch event.

column2: I'll pledge every square inch of my body: Rahul Bose on organ donation
column3: Actor Rahul Bose has said he'll soon be signing up for deceased organ donation and would be pledging "every square inch" of his body for donation after death. "If you're going to die, (and post that) if your body can be used to benefit 8-9 other human beings in terms of organs, what would be greater good karma," he added.

column2: My late sister raped me when I was 10: US singer Aaron Carter
column3: US singer Aaron Carter on Thursday tweeted that his late sister Leslie, who suffered from bipolar disorder, raped him from the age of 10 to 13 years old. Aaron also alleged that he was sexually abused by two back-up dancers when he was eight years old. The 31-year-old also accused his brother and Backstreet Boys member Nick Carter of abuse.

column2: Amit Panghal first Indian male boxer to reach World Championships final
column3: Asian Games 2018 gold medallist boxer Amit Panghal has become the first Indian male boxer to reach the final at the World Boxing Championships. The 23-year-old boxer defeated Kazakhstan's Saken Bibossinov 3-2 in the semi-final bout of the 52-kg category. Panghal will face Uzbekistan's Shakhobidin Zoirov in the final on Saturday.

column2: US sanctions-hit Huawei launches phone without Google apps
column3: Chinese smartphone maker Huawei has launched its latest high-end smartphone without American technology giant Google's apps pre-installed on it. This comes over the US' move to put Huawei under its 'Entity List', restricting it from carrying out any business with US firms. "Today because of the US ban we can't pre-install Google's applications," Huawei's consumer business group head said.

column2: When PM goes abroad, I want him to be treated with respect: Tharoor
column3: Congress leader Shashi Tharoor has said that when PM Narendra Modi goes abroad, he wants the PM to be received and treated with respect. "As an Opposition MP I have the right to criticise [PM Modi's] policies, statements...But when he goes abroad, he's [the Prime Minister of India] & he carries my flag," he tweeted.

column2: Congress appoints 5 election incharges for Maharashtra polls
column3: Congress appointed five election incharges on Thursday ahead of the upcoming Maharashtra Assembly polls, senior party leader KC Venugopal stated. Mukul Wasnik was named the election incharge for Vidarbha, Rajni Patil for western and Konkan regions, Rajeev Satav for Marathwada region, RC Khuntia for northern Maharashtra and Avinash Pandey for Mumbai region and Election Control Room.

column2: E-comm startup Meesho sues GlowRoad, ex-employees for data theft
column3: Bengaluru-based e-commerce startup Meesho sued rival GlowRoad and nine ex-employees alleging that the employees stole confidential data and GlowRoad actively poached them. Meesho claimed to have proof of data theft and GlowRoad forcing people to steal data and solicit employees. GlowRoad Co-founder Shekhar Sahu responded saying that they will "strongly reply" to the legal notices sent by Meesho.

column2: Elon Musk-backed startup Stripe to get $250 mn at $35 bn valuation
column3: US digital payments startup Stripe is raising $250 million in funding at a pre-money valuation of $35 billion, a 56% surge from its previous valuation. The round saw participation from investors including Sequoia Capital, Andreessen Horowitz and General Catalyst. Founded in 2010, Stripe is backed by investors including Elon Musk, Peter Thiel and Google's venture arm CapitalG, among others.

column2: UN urged by own staff to look at its carbon footprint
column3: More than 1,000 United Nations employees have called on the global body to reduce its carbon footprint. "Let us look at our own impact and take bold steps to address the climate emergency," the letter by the employees said. The UN emitted 1.86 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent in 2017, according to its own data.

column2: Heavy rains in Houston ahead of 'Howdy, Modi' event
column3: Ahead of the 'Howdy, Modi' event on September 22, torrential rains triggered by a tropical storm have brought Houston in US' Texas to a halt. The heavy rains have prompted the Governor of Texas Greg Abbott to declare an emergency in several parts of the state. However, volunteers of the event said, "We are going to have a fantastic programme."

column2: UN chief could discuss Kashmir issue during UNGA: Spokesperson
column3: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres' spokesperson Stephane Dujarric has said, "I think he will also use the opportunity of discussions during the General Assembly to raise the Kashmir issue." Earlier this week, Guterres said that dialogue between India and Pakistan is an "absolute essential element" for reaching a solution on the Kashmir issue.

column2: Can't recall how many times I wore blackface makeup: Canada PM
column3: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has said that he cannot recall how many times he had worn blackface makeup. This comes after a video of a third instance of Trudeau wearing the blackface makeup emerged. Trudeau on Thursday apologised for wearing the blackface makeup, saying "it was a racist thing to do".

column2: US says it is building a coalition after attacks on Saudi oil facilities
column3: After accusing Iran of drone attacks on two Saudi oil facilities, US State Secretary Mike Pompeo has said the country was building a coalition "aimed at achieving peace and a peaceful resolution". Iran has warned US President Donald Trump against being dragged into a war in Middle East and said it would meet any offensive action with a crushing response.

column2: Condom sales in Argentina fall amid recession, falling currency
column3: Condom sales in recession-hit Argentina have fallen by 25% over recent months amid rising inflation and currency devaluation. Because of a weaker currency, condom prices have risen 36% since the start of the year as raw materials are imported, a manufacturer said. The peso currency has lost over 65% of its value against the dollar since the start of 2018.

column2: Brad confronted Weinstein after latter allegedly assaulted Paltrow
column3: Brad Pitt has revealed in an interview that he once confronted producer Harvey Weinstein when his ex-girlfriend Gwyneth Paltrow alleged that the latter assaulted her. "I just wanted to make sure nothing was going to happen...she was going to do two films (with Weinstein)," Brad said. "At that moment, I was just a boy...that's how we confronted things," he added.

column2: Chinmayanand held after victim threatened self-immolation: Priyanka
column3: Congress leader Priyanka Gandhi Vadra on Friday said the BJP government is "so thick-skinned" that it took action against BJP leader Swami Chinmayanand only after the victim threatened self-immolation. "It was the strength of the public and journalism that SIT had to arrest Chinmayanand," she tweeted. Priyanka added that public has ensured that 'Beti Bachao' doesn't remain in mere slogans.

column2: Trump signs executive order to help develop universal vaccine
column3: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order on September 19 that will help the US Department of Health and Human Services support research to develop a universal flu vaccine. Trump has directed the department to come up with a plan and budget for the effort within 120 days. The program will also help modernise the development of flu vaccines.

column2: Part of 4-storey Mumbai building collapses, no injuries reported
column3: A portion of a four-storied building at Lokmanya Tilak Road in Mumbai collapsed amid heavy rainfall on Friday. Several fire tenders and ambulances were rushed to the spot but no casualties were reported. Meanwhile, authorities have launched an investigation into the building collapse.

column2: No stressed MSME to be declared as NPA till March 2020: FM
column3: Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman has told state-run banks to not classify any stressed loan accounts of micro, small and medium enterprises (MSME) as non-performing assets (NPA) till March 31, 2020.
