column3: US President Donald Trump has ordered the Treasury Secretary to "substantially" increase the sanctions on Iran following the drone attacks on two Saudi oil facilities last week. The US and Saudi Arabia have blamed Iran for carrying out the attacks, which caused the biggest ever sudden disruption to oil production. Iran has, however, denied involvement in the attacks.

column2: Ballot paper is history now: EC on Maharashtra Assembly elections
column3: Addressing a press conference on Maharashtra Assembly elections on Wednesday, Chief Election Commissioner Sunil Arora said, "Few political parties have asked about voting through ballot paper." "We have told them it is not possible, it's history now," he added. He further said, "Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs) cannot be tampered. EVMs can malfunction but cannot be tampered."

column2: Howdy economy doin', Mr Modi: Rahul tweets ahead of PM's US event
column3: Ahead of PM Narendra Modi's event 'Howdy, Modi!' in Texas, US on Sunday, Congress leader Rahul Gandhi tweeted, "'Howdy' economy doin', Mr Modi? Ain't too good it seems." Rahul Gandhi also shared a news report that said foreign investors sold $4.5 billion of Indian shares since June after investing $45 billion in Indian stock market over the past six years.

column2: Amazon's new Hyderabad office has 12 theme-based floors, cricket area
column3: Amazon's world's largest campus opened in Hyderabad last month has 12 floors, each with a separate theme, with one of the floors having 'Bollywood' theme. The building has numerous 'work points' where employees can sit, in a group or solo, and work with their laptops. There are billiard tables, yoga rooms, and areas dedicated to cricket and wall climbing.

column2: Sexual harassment case against angel investor Mahesh Murthy quashed
column3: Bombay High Court quashed a sexual harassment case against angel investor Mahesh Murthy and said that the delay in filing the case 14 years later is not "properly explained". The Bandra Police had registered the case against Murthy in March 2018 on a woman's complaint. She alleged that in 2004, Murthy touched her inappropriately and kissed her against her will.

column2: Army conducts warfare exercise in east Ladakh after China face-off
column3: Days after a face-off between Indian and Chinese forces in Ladakh sector, Lieutenant General Ranbir Singh on Tuesday presided over a high-altitude warfare military exercise in Eastern Ladakh. Lieutenant General Singh oversaw the integrated exercise of all arms in super high altitude area and complimented all ranks for an outstanding display of warfighting capability under challenging conditions.

column2: UP school principal, teacher booked for gangrape of 16-yr-old teacher
column3: The principal and a senior teacher of a school in Shikohabad town of Uttar Pradesh's Firozabad district have been booked for the gangrape of a minor kindergarten teacher in May earlier this year. The matter came to light when the 16-year-old victim became pregnant, following which her mother contacted the police. The victim is 21 weeks pregnant now.

column2: Will govt believe Chinmayanand raped me if I end my life: Student
column3: The 23-year-old law student, who accused BJP leader Swami Chinmayanand of rape and blackmail, has raised doubts over the approach of Special Investigation Team (SIT) in her case. "Will the authorities believe me when I attempt suicide?" she said. She added, "It has been over 15 days since I recorded my statement and gave the SIT necessary evidence."

column2: Employees forget to lock bank in UP, passerby informs police
column3: Employees of the state-run United Bank of India forgot to lock the bank after the day's work on Tuesday evening in Uttar Pradesh's Muzaffarnagar. The matter came to light after a passerby spotted the opened gates of the bank and informed the police. The bank was locked after police asked the manager and other staff to reach the bank.

column2: Regret Pak's decision: MEA as Pak denies airspace for PM's plane
column3: Ministry of External Affairs Spokesperson Raveesh Kumar has said India regrets Pakistan's decision to not allow PM Narendra Modi's plane to fly through its airspace for his upcoming US visit. Kumar added, "Pakistan should reflect upon its decision to deviate from well established international practice, as well as reconsider its old habit of misrepresenting reasons for taking unilateral action."

column2: Trump names Robert C O'Brien as new US NSA
column3: US President Donald Trump announced on Wednesday that he has named Robert C O'Brien as the US' new National Security Adviser (NSA). O'Brien has been serving as the Special Presidential Envoy for Hostage Affairs at the US' State Department. He will replace John Bolton, who was fired by Trump earlier this month.

column2: 18-yr-old US woman threatens to 'shoot 400 people for fun', arrested
column3: An 18-year-old American woman has been arrested after she allegedly threatened to "shoot 400 people for fun". Authorities got an anonymous tip that the accused, Alexis Wilson, told her friends and co-workers that she was going to carry out the shooting at her former high school. Authorities seized an AK-47 and a shotgun from Wilson's house.

column2: India scraps 5% import tax on open cell panels, TV makers to benefit
column3: India has scrapped a 5% import tax on open cell TV panels, used to make television displays. Samsung Electronics shut its TV production unit in India last year and moved production to Vietnam because of the tax. The decision will provide relief to TV manufacturers, which have been hit by cheap imports from Vietnam, Panasonic India CEO Manish Sharma said.

column2: Will never accept imposition of Hindi in TN: Karti Chidambaram
column3: Congress MP Karti Chidambaram on Wednesday said that imposition of Hindi in Tamil Nadu will never be accepted. "Hindi is not the unifying force of this country. We will oppose the imposition of Hindi vociferously," he added. Karti had stated his participation in DMK's now-postponed September 20 protest against Home Minister Amit Shah's remarks about Hindi being a "unifying" language.

column2: Transport strike in Delhi-NCR over new fines on September 19
column3: The United Front of Transport Associations (UFTA) has confirmed that transport union will hold a strike on September 19 in Delhi-NCR to protest against the fines being levied under the newly-amended Motor Vehicles Act, 2019. The strike will include all commercial vehicles. As per a report, the Noida Transport United Front will also participate in the strike.

column2: Savarkar must be awarded the Bharat Ratna: Uddhav Thackeray
column3: Shiv Sena chief Uddhav Thackeray on Tuesday said Vinayak Damodar Savarkar, popularly known as Veer Savarkar, must be awarded the Bharat Ratna, country's highest civilian award. Other people also contributed to freedom struggle other than the Nehru-Gandhi family, he added. He also said Pakistan would not have been created if Savarkar had been India's Prime Minister during partition.

column2: Monsoon rains above-average for third straight week: IMD
column3: Monsoon rains in India in the week through to Wednesday were above average for a third straight week, the India Meteorological Department (IMD) said. Floods reportedly hit many districts in the central parts of the country and damaged crops such as soybean and pulses. India has reportedly received 5% more rain than average since the start of the monsoon season.

column2: GST tax rate cuts for auto sector unlikely: Government
column3: The GST panel is unlikely to lower tax rates for the auto sector due to large revenue losses, government officials said. A government study said that the total annual revenue loss could be as much as $6.95 billion if the panel decided to decrease tax rates. The auto sector, however, has pushed to lower tax rates to 18% from 28%.

column2: SEBI bars Gautam Thapar from securities market for CG Power fraud
column3: Markets regulator SEBI barred ousted CG Power and Industrial Solutions Chairman Gautam Thapar and three ex-officials from securities market. Thapar, ex-CFO VR Venkatesh, ex-Director of finance Madhav Acharya and ex-Director B Hariharan were found guilty of misusing company's assets for illegal transactions. SEBI directed BSE to appoint a sole auditor to audit CG Power's books from FY16 to date.

column2: US Navy confirms leaked UFO videos are real
column3: The US Navy has acknowledged that three leaked UFO videos are real, calling the objects in these videos "Unidentified Aerial Phenomena" (UAP). The first video of the unidentified object was taken in 2004, while the second and third videos were taken in 2015. The US Navy refused to give details about the locations the videos were shot in.

column2: Udit, Alka, Sanu get notice for accepting Pak national's invite to US
column3: The Federation of Western India Cine Employees has issued notices to singers Alka Yagnik, Kumar Sanu and Udit Narayan to cancel an event promoted by a Pakistani national. The three of them were scheduled to perform in the USA at an event organised by Moazzma Hunain on November 17. The film body earlier issued a similar notice to Diljit Dosanjh.

column2: Defamation suit against Digvijaya Singh for comments against BJP
column3: A criminal defamation suit was filed against Congress leader Digvijaya Singh for his alleged statement "BJP and Bajrang Dal are taking money from Pakistan's ISI". The court will look into the petition on October 9. Earlier, Uttar Pradesh BJP leader Satish Arora had filed a criminal case against Digvijaya Singh for his statement. Bajrang Dal had also condemned Singh's statement.

column2: NRC will be implemented across the country, reiterates Amit Shah
column3: Home Minister Amit Shah has reiterated that the National Register of Citizens (NRC) will be implemented across the country. "Can an Indian go and live illegally in the US, UK, Russia? No, then how can other nationals reside in India without legal documentation?" he questioned. This comes days after the final list of NRC for Assam was released.

column2: I never asked for imposing Hindi over other regional languages: Amit Shah
column3: Home Minister Amit Shah has said he never asked for imposing Hindi over other regional languages and had only requested for learning Hindi as second language after one's mother tongue. "I myself come from a non-Hindi state...If some people want to do politics, it's their choice," he added. Shah had pitched for Hindi as a "common language" for the country.

column2: No chance of talks with India on Kashmir until curfew lifted: Pak PM
column3: Pakistan's Prime Minister Imran Khan has said that there is no chance of holding bilateral talks with India on Kashmir until the Indian government lifts the "curfew" for people there. "No one has fought for the case of Kashmir like I will," Khan added. The Pakistani Prime Minister's remarks came during the opening of the Torkham border crossing with Afghanistan.

column2: US man jailed for 16 months for vandalising Gurdwara
column3: A 29-year-old American named Artyom Manukyan has been jailed for 16 months for vandalising a Gurdwara in California in 2017. The sentence is concurrent with a penalty Manukyan faces under a previous arson case, the US media reported. Manukyan was previously arrested on suspicion of burglary, grand theft auto and making criminal threats.

column2: Bermuda judge says mention of sex in murder trial made him 'horny'
column3: A now-retired judge in Bermuda was criticised by the British Court of Appeal for saying during a murder trial he was getting "horny" because of the amount of sex mentioned in the case. The lawyer of the defendant who was found guilty of murder, had filed an appeal with the higher court, claiming the judge acted inappropriately during the trial.

column2: Leader of Pak PM's party shares stage with US-designated terrorist
column3: Firdous Ashiq Awan, a leader of Pakistan PM Imran Khan's Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) party, was seen sharing the stage with US-designated global terrorist Maulana Fazlur Rehman Khalil. She attended the event called the All Parties Kashmir Solidarity Conference with Khalil in Islamabad earlier this week. Awan also serves as the Prime Minister's Special Assistant on Information and Broadcasting.

column2: Iran denies role in attacks on Saudi oil plants in note to US
column3: Iran sent a diplomatic note to the US denying any role in the attacks on Saudi oil plants. "If any actions are taken against Iran, that action will face an immediate response...and its scope (won't) be limited to just a threat," the Iranian state media said. The note was sent through the Swiss embassy which represents US interests in Iran.

column2: Shares of cigarette companies rally after govt bans e-cigarettes
column3: Shares of cigarette makers surged on Wednesday after the Union Cabinet passed an ordinance banning the production, import and sale of e-cigarettes. Shares of ITC, Godfrey Phillips India, VST Industries and Golden Tobacco climbed 2.2%-9%. The Association of Vapers India said the ban would deprive millions of smokers of a safer solution to cut back on smoking.

column2: I need to get back to that look: Madhavan on his 2-yr-old picture
column3: Actor R Madhavan on Wednesday replied to one of his fans on social media who shared the actor's old picture and said, "He's so hot, I wanna cry. Why you be so hot @ActorMadhavan." "2 year old pic my lady.. I wanna cry too. Damn I need to get back to that look," Madhavan said in reply to the post.

column2: Zayn Malik's sister gets married days after turning 17
column3: Singer Zayn Malik's youngest sister Safaa Malik, who turned 17 last Friday, got married to boyfriend Martin Tiser in a traditional Nikkah ceremony in their hometown Bradford, England on Monday. Safaa wore a red wedding lehenga with gold jewellery, whereas Martin wore a white sherwani. The wedding was attended by Zayn's mother, father and sisters Doniya and Waliyha Malik.

column2: FB partners with US, UK to develop technology to track live attacks
column3: Facebook announced on Tuesday that it will use footage from police body cameras in the US and UK to develop technology to better detect videos of live shootings and immediately take them down. It will obtain footage from their firearms training programs. This comes after the Christchurch shooting in New Zealand, which killed 51 people, was broadcasted live on Facebook.

column2: Discussed changing West Bengal's name to 'Bangla' with PM: Mamata
column3: West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee met Prime Minister Narendra Modi in Delhi on Wednesday. After meeting the PM, Banerjee said that the meeting was "good" and that she discussed the demand for changing West Bengal's name to 'Bangla'. "The PM has promised to do something about the matter," she added.

column2: Don't criticise work done in national interest: BJP to Priyanka
column3: BJP leader Baijayant Jay Panda on Wednesday criticised Congress' Priyanka Gandhi Vadra for her tweet in which she wrote that investments don't come from international events. He claimed that in the first quarter this year, FDI increased by 28% due to international events. "She shouldn't criticise the work done in the national interest for the sake of politics," Panda said.

column2: DMK workers blacken Hindi text at TN station, detained
column3: Several youths, allegedly from the Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (DMK), defaced the name of Tamil Nadu's Gudiyattam railway station that was written in Hindi on Wednesday. As per a report, the youths were later detained. The incident comes amid DMK's announcement of a state-wide protest against Home Minister Amit Shah's remarks about Hindi being a "unifying" language.

column2: Several B'luru Zomato delivery execs suspended after protest on pay
column3: Several Zomato delivery partners in Bengaluru protesting over the new payment structure were suspended from the platform. They allege that a few of those whom the company has identified as organisers of the protest are being targeted. "Certain delivery partners (0.1% of Bengaluru fleet) found instigating and hindering services for other partners have been temporarily suspended," Zomato said.

column2: Rajnath Singh gives nod to writing India's border history
column3: Union Defence Minister Rajnath Singh approved initiating the work of writing the history of the country's borders, Defence Ministry said on Wednesday. The work will cover various aspects of borders including tracing its making and unmaking, shifting of borders, role of security forces and borderland people, it said. The project is expected to be completed within two years, it added.

column2: Tripura man lynched by mob for allegedly stealing mobile phone
column3: A man, identified as Kishan Debnath, was lynched by a mob in Tripura for allegedly stealing a mobile phone, a pair of headphones and one bicycle on Tuesday. The incident took place after the allegedly stolen items were found with Debnath by the villagers. "On getting information, we rescued Debnath and admitted him to a...hospital, where he died," police said.

column2: Activist group stages funeral at finale of London Fashion Week
column3: Climate change activist group Extinction Rebellion on Tuesday staged a funeral march on the last day of the London Fashion Week (LFW). A group of around 200 people demanded the end of the fashion week this year. Earlier, the group accused LFW of encouraging the demand for fashion, resulting in increased pollution and exploitation of workers by the industry.

column2: Terrorists didn't land in J&K from Moon, we must support India: Polish MEP
column3: Polish politician and Member of the European Parliament (MEP) Ryszard Czarnecki, during the plenary session, said the parliament needs to look at the terrorist acts that took place in Jammu and Kashmir. "India is the greatest democracy of the world. Terrorists didn't land in J&K from Moon. They were coming from neighbouring country. We should support India," he further said.

column2: All 25 members of a family in MP have more than 10 fingers and toes
column3: A 25-member family in Madhya Pradesh's Betul suffers from polydactyly, a congenital condition of supernumerary fingers. All the members have more than 10 fingers and toes. "I've...12 fingers in hand and 14 [toes] on my feet. I didn't get a job because of this. I'm not getting any help from the village panchayat," said a member of the family.

column2: Big B criticised by MNS leader for tweet supporting Mumbai Metro
column3: Actor Amitabh Bachchan has been criticised by MNS leader Akhil Chitre after he praised Mumbai Metro in a tweet. "In 2010, Bachchan [opposed] the metro...But, after the change of the government, his views changed," said Chitre. "When people across Mumbai are protesting against the cutting of trees in Aarey forest, he is tweeting in favour of metro construction," Chitre added.

column2: With J&K move, PM showed strength sought by Sardar Patel: RS Prasad
column3: Union Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad today said it took 70 years for the Indian government to show its strength and nullify Article 370. Reading out a quote from Patel's biography, Prasad stated, "Sardar Patel said, 'the future will depend upon the strength and guts of Indian government'...(Prime Minister) Narendra Modi had to demonstrate that strength after 70 years."

column2: Legalise betting to curb corruption in cricket: BCCI's ACU chief
column3: BCCI's Anti-Corruption Unit chief Ajit Singh Shekhawat has said that betting should be legalised to curb corruption in cricket. "Legal betting will be done under some parameters and it can be controlled. It will also bring a huge amount of revenue for the government, close to what the excise department generates," he added.

column2: Vinesh Phogat becomes first Indian wrestler to qualify for Tokyo Olympics
column3: Vinesh Phogat has become the first Indian wrestler to qualify for the 2020 Tokyo Olympics after defeating American wrestler Sarah Hildebrandt in the World Championships. Vinesh will wrestle in the bronze-medal bout against Maria Prevolaraki of Greece later on Wednesday. The 25-year-old has qualified for the Olympics in the 53-kg category.

column2: Apple is coming to India in a big way: Ravi Shankar Prasad
column3: Union IT Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad has said all electronics companies are bullish on the Indian market, adding that Apple is going to come to India in "a big way". The government on Monday urged Apple to expand its manufacturing base and use India as an export hub. Apple is reportedly investing $1 billion to expand iPhones' manufacturing in India.

column2: Mamata meeting PM Modi to save Rajeev Kumar: Vijayvargiya
column3: BJP General Secretary Kailash Vijayvargiya said that West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee is meeting Prime Minister Narendra Modi in a "last-ditch effort" to save former Kolkata Police Commissioner Rajeev Kumar. The CBI is looking for Rajeev Kumar in the Saradha chit fund case. On Tuesday, a district and sessions court had rejected Kumar's pre-arrest bail plea.

column2: China halts sale of JUUL products a week after launch: Bloomberg
column3: China has abruptly halted both offline and online sale of e-cigarette startup JUUL's products a week after its launch, Bloomberg reported. JUUL was reportedly not told why its e-cigarettes and nicotine pods were removed from the stores. JUUL responded by saying that it remains steadfast in its commitment to provide China with a viable alternative to combustible cigarettes.

column2: BMW should buy Jaguar Land Rover from Tata Motors: Bernstein
column3: Sanford C. Bernstein analysts have said BMW should buy Jaguar Land Rover from Tata Motors as the German carmaker is "awash with cash". Buying JLR for $11.2 billion could add 20% to BMW's earnings but "Tata would need to swallow its pride to sell," they added. Tata Motors bought Jaguar and Land Rover from Ford in 2008 for $2.3 billion.

column2: Hard disk, other devices stolen from under-construction INS Vikrant
column3: A probe has been launched after a hard disk and electronic devices like a multi function control processor were stolen from the country's first indigenous aircraft carrier INS Vikrant. The police said the incident occurred at the Cochin Shipyard's high-security zone, where the vessel is under construction. Meanwhile, the Home Ministry said the theft was "a possible insider job".

column2: Fire breaks out at UCO Bank building in B'luru, many feared trapped
column3: A massive fire broke out at a UCO Bank building at MG Road in Bengaluru on Wednesday, in which several people are feared trapped. Several students were present in the multi-storey building, which also houses coaching centres, at the time of the blaze. People were seen rushing out of the building in panic. The rescue operation is underway.

column2: India asks Pak to allow use of its airspace for PM's flight: Pak media
column3: India has formally requested Pakistan to allow the use of its airspace for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's flight to the US later this week, ANI reported on Wednesday quoting Pakistani media. It added that Pakistan will hold consultations before announcing its decision. PM Modi is set to attend the annual session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York.

column2: Indian troops fire grenades to foil Pak infiltration: Reports
column3: A video has surfaced online, reportedly showing Pakistan's Border Action Team (BAT) trying to infiltrate into Indian territory last week in Hajipir Sector of Pakistan-occupied Kashmir. Pakistan's infiltration was foiled by the Indian troops by launching grenades at them, according to reports. In August, Indian Army foiled over 15 infiltration attempts by Pakistan on LoC.

column2: 11 lakh railway employees to get 78 days' wages as productivity bonus
column3: The Union Cabinet on Wednesday approved a payment of productivity linked bonus equivalent to 78 days' wages to over 11 lakh eligible non-gazetted railway employees. The government had given the same amount in bonus last year. "For 11 lakh Railways' employees, this government has consistently for the last six years, been giving record bonus," Union Minister Prakash Javadekar said.

column2: Britney's father not to face charges over alleged abuse of her son
column3: Singer Britney Spears' father Jamie Spears has been cleared of criminal charges after he was accused of physically abusing the singer's 13-year-old son. The Ventura County District Attorney's Office on Tuesday said that there was "insufficient proof that a criminal offense was committed". Britney's ex-husband Kevin Federline filed a complaint against Jamie a couple of weeks ago.

column2: Google Assistant gets voice option in 9 more languages
column3: Google is launching nine new voices for Google Assistant built by a machine learning system called WaveNet by using Alphabet's DeepMind. The voices will come in languages like French, German, Dutch, Japanese, Norwegian, Korean, Italian and English for India and the UK. Users will be able to select a new voice by choosing colours, which will be in random order.

column2: Digvijaya trying to foment phobia against 1 community: Baijayant
column3: BJP National Vice President Baijayant Panda has criticised Congress' Digvijaya Singh for saying that "people are wearing saffron clothes and raping." Panda said, "Singh is known for making very controversial statements and almost all of his statements go in a particular direction, which tries to foment phobia against one community." Panda accused Digvijaya of addressing terrorists with respect.

column2: Instagram influencer Dan Bilzerian invests in LivePools
column3: Online fantasy gaming startup LivePools has raised an undisclosed amount of funding from Instagram influencer Dan Bilzerian, marking his financial entry in India. Bilzerian, who came to India last week, said he had been monitoring the market for a while. Founded in 2017, LivePools is backed by Bollywood actor Dino Morea and claims to have over one million registered users.

column2: Newly-found giant salamander species is world's largest amphibian
column3: Scientists have discovered a new species of giant salamander, believed to be the world's largest amphibian. Chinese giant salamanders were previously thought to be a single species until three genetic lineages were found. The newly-found species, Andrias sligoi, is thought to be the largest of all three after analysis of a 74-year-old specimen that once lived at the London Zoo.

column2: Southern states won't accept imposition of Hindi: Rajinikanth
column3: Actor-politician Rajinikanth on Wednesday said that none of the southern states will accept the imposition of Hindi on them. However, he advocated the idea of having a common language across the country and said that it would be good for its unity. Union Home Minister Amit Shah on the occasion of 'Hindi Diwas' said that Hindi can unite the country.

column2: Hearings in Ayodhya case likely to be completed by October 18: SC
column3: Speaking about the Ayodhya land dispute case, CJI Ranjan Gogoi said, "As per the estimate of tentative dates to finish the hearing in the case, we can say that the submissions have to be likely completed by October 18." The Supreme Court also said that if the parties want, mediation process can simultaneously take place with the daily hearings.

column2: OnePlus reveals first-look of OnePlus 7T with triple camera design
column3: Ahead of the launch, OnePlus released the first official images of its OnePlus 7T. The smartphone features a rear camera setup encased in a circular module, placed side-by-side horizontally on the 4th generation matte-frosted glass. On the official forum, OnePlus CEO Pete Lau wrote, "With perfect symmetry from any orientation, a circular design became the natural choice."

column2: Mouni Roy's car hit by rock falling from 11th floor at Mumbai Metro site
column3: Actress Mouni Roy has shared a video showing her car's sunroof being damaged after a rock fell on it at Mumbai Metro construction site. "Was on my way to work at Juhu signal a huge rock falls on the car 11 floors up...What if anybody was crossing the road[?]," she wrote. Mouni also called out the "irresponsibility" of Mumbai Metro.

column2: Aus hiker crawls for 2 days with broken leg after falling 20ft; rescued
column3: Australian hiker Neil Parker has revealed that he crawled for two days after falling 20 feet down a waterfall, following which his foot "clean snapped in half" and he also fractured his wrist. Adding that he used his hiking stick to splint his leg, the 54-year-old said he covered 3 km distance by crawling. He was rescued by a helicopter.

column2: OYO raising $200 million to buy luxury hotels in US: Report
column3: OYO is reportedly in talks with several financial institutions to raise $200 million to buy premium and luxury hotels in America. "OYO is going to create a separate entity in the US to help it acquire and run four and five-star hotel assets," Livemint quoted its sources. OYO recently acquired Las Vegas' Hooters Casino Hotel for a reported $135 million.

column2: Ola, Lenskart, others seek relaxed IPO listing norms: Report
column3: Several prominent startups including Ola, Lenskart and PolicyBazaar are reportedly in the process of submitting a petition to the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) over the regulations for listing publicly. The startups reportedly want the rule for minimum promoter holding requirement of 20% to be either be removed or be considered on a case-to-case basis.

column2: DRDO to help ISRO with tech for India's 1st manned space mission
column3: The Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO) on Tuesday signed MoUs with ISRO to develop human-centric systems for India's first manned space mission Gaganyaan. DRDO will provide critical technologies including space food, survival kits for the crew, radiation protection equipment, among others. ISRO plans to launch the mission before the 75th anniversary of India's independence.

column2: Air pollutants inhaled by mother found on unborn babies' placentas
column3: Belgium's Hasselt University researchers have found air pollution particles on the foetal side of the placenta, confirming that black carbon inhaled by mothers can cross into unborn children. The study comprised 28 placentas from non-smoking women in the town of Hasselt. The particle pollution levels were below the EU limit but above the WHO limit.

column2: Man tries to kidnap sleeping 4-yr-old girl in Punjab, video surfaces
column3: A video of a man attempting to kidnap a 4-year-old girl sleeping outside her house with her family members in Punjab's Ludhiana on Tuesday has surfaced. In the video, the man can be seen lifting the girl sleeping on a cot and placing her in a cart. The attempt was foiled as family members woke up and rescued the child.

column2: Tulsi Gabbard denies refusing invitation to attend 'Howdy Modi' event
column3: US lawmaker Tulsi Gabbard has denied a report that she refused an invitation to attend Prime Minister Narendra Modi's 'Howdy Modi' event in Houston, US. "I'm not attending the Houston event due to previously scheduled presidential campaign events. However I'm hoping to meet PM Modi on his visit," she said while issuing a clarification on Twitter.

column2: Babul Supriyo takes auto ride to airport after car gets stuck in traffic
column3: Union Minister Babul Supriyo on Tuesday shared a video of himself in an autorickshaw and revealed that he decided to take an autorickshaw ride to Mumbai airport after his car got stuck in a traffic jam. "I'm...reminiscing the past, the city where I struggled several times in an auto," he said. "It's really making me feel very good," Supriyo added.

column2: Thousands drowning, but dam filled for 1 person: Patkar's dig at PM
column3: Social activist Medha Patkar has claimed that Gujarat government filled Sardar Sarovar Dam before PM Narendra Modi's birthday on September 17, a month ahead of schedule. Adding that 192 villages in three districts of Madhya Pradesh were affected after increase in the water level, Patkar said, "Thousands of people are getting drowned but for one person the dam was filled."

column2: US govt sues Edward Snowden over new book, seeks all its earnings
column3: The US government has filed a lawsuit against whistleblower Edward Snowden over the publication of his book 'Permanent Record' and sought all proceeds earned from it. The government alleged Snowden published the book in violation of non-disclosure agreements he signed with the CIA and NSA. The lawsuit further alleged Snowden didn't submit the book to the agencies for pre-publication review.

column2: Aramco emerged 'like a phoenix from the ashes' after attacks: Saudi
column3: Saudi Arabian Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman has said the kingdom will restore the oil production lost due to drone attacks by the end of September. He added that state oil giant Aramco had emerged "like a phoenix from the ashes". Aramco shut down 5.7 million barrels per day of oil output, which is over half of Saudi's production.

column2: Audience gives the result: Shraddha on negative reviews for ‘Saaho’
column3: Talking about the negative reviews of her film 'Saaho', actress Shraddha Kapoor said that the audience is the boss and ultimately they are the people who give the result. "At the end of the day, they are the ones who... go watch your film," she added. "So if they love the film then who can question anything," she further said.

column2: Guru Randhawa to make his debut at Milan Fashion Week
column3: Singer Guru Randhawa will make his debut at the Milan Fashion Week, where he'll be attending FILA's Spring/Summer 2020 fashion show on September 22. Talking about the event, Randhawa said, "I think it's a big opportunity for me." "I'm sure we are going to have a blast there, see new fashion trends... photoshoots, and some good food," he added.

column2: BSP to contest all 90 seats alone in Haryana polls: Satish Misra
column3: Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP) has decided to contest Haryana Vidhan Sabha elections alone on all 90 seats, party General Secretary Satish Misra said on Tuesday. Misra stated, "We decided to end the alliance with INLD following their family dispute." He said the BSP has got into election mode in Haryana, adding, "The results will be in favour of BSP."

column2: Springboard mentors train learners to transition to data science
column3: Industry experts in data science from companies like Paytm, Myntra, Uber, Swiggy, Hike, Careem, Redhat, PhonePe, Inmobi, Gramener, Airtel, Brillio have joined hands with Springboard to provide 1:1 mentorship to Indian learners to help them transition to a data science career. Springboard, a US-based online learning platform, is on a mission to help learners transition through its unique approach.

column2: Mongia announces retirement 12 years after playing his last int'l match
column3: All-rounder Dinesh Mongia has announced retirement from all forms of cricket, 12 years after playing his last international match. The 42-year-old represented India in 57 ODIs from 2001 to 2007 and was also part of India's first-ever T20I. Mongia last represented his domestic side Punjab in 2007 before joining the now-defunct Indian Cricket League.

column2: Restore preferential trade status for India: 44 US lawmakers urge Trump
column3: As many as 44 US lawmakers have urged President Donald Trump-led administration to reinstate India's designation as a beneficiary developing nation under the Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) trade programme. In a letter signed by 26 Democrats and 18 Republicans, they suggested an "early harvest" approach "to help American jobs that depend on two-way trade between the US and India".

column2: US man who has beaten cancer twice wins $4.6 mn state lottery
column3: Stu MacDonald, a man from US' Oregon who has beaten cancer twice, has won $4.6 million in the state lottery. MacDonald, who opted for a $2.3 million lump sum payment and pocketed $1.56 million after taxes, said, "[A]m a very lucky guy." MacDonald bought the ticket from a cafe, who will be given $46,000 as one per cent seller's bonus.

column2: It's really irritating: Sunil Grover on rumours of joining Kapil's show
column3: Comedian Sunil Grover, while commenting on rumours of him joining Kapil Sharma's show, said, "It is all baseless and I don't want to comment on it." "It's really irritating that these speculations arise out of nowhere. So when there's something, I myself will reveal," he added. Sunil had quit the show in 2017 after a fight with Kapil.

column2: Facebook to form content Oversight Board that can overrule CEO Mark
column3: Facebook has unveiled its plans to form an independent content Oversight Board comprising 40 people globally. The new rules will let users appeal content decisions directly to the board instead of through Facebook's usual channels. "The board's decision will be binding, even if I or anyone at Facebook disagrees with it," Facebook Co-founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg said.

column2: Apple to invest $250 million in iPhone glass supplier Corning
column3: Apple has announced that it is investing $250 million into display glass supplier Corning from its $5-billion Advanced Manufacturing Fund. The iPhone maker had also invested $200 million into Corning in 2017. Apple said that it has spent nearly $3 billion with Corning on the glass used in iPhone, Apple Watch and iPad since iPhone's launch in 2007.

column2: 3 sisters allege torture in Assam police post, 1 claims she had miscarriage
column3: A case has been filed against an Assam police officer and female constable for allegedly torturing a pregnant woman and her two sisters inside a police station. They accused the officials of "custodial torture, including being stripped naked and beaten", after they were picked up over a case registered against their brother. The pregnant woman claimed she suffered a miscarriage.

column2: Chandrababu blames YSRCP for ex-Andhra Speaker's death
column3: Former Andhra Pradesh Chief Minister and President of Telugu Desam Party, N Chandrababu Naidu, has blamed YSRCP for the death of former Speaker Kodela Siva Prasada Rao. Chandrababu Naidu also demanded a CBI inquiry into the circumstances that led to Kodela's death. Naidu said, "Kodela Siva Prasada Rao was mentally tortured, financially troubled, harassed and humiliated badly by YSRCP."

column2: Chinmayanand making excuse like kid, his arrest imminent: Law student
column3: After BJP leader Swami Chinmayanand was treated by doctors for uneasiness, the law student in Uttar Pradesh's Shahjahanpur who has accused him of rape and blackmail said, "He's making an excuse like a kid when his arrest is imminent." She also questioned why SIT has not registered an FIR against Chinmayanand despite her detailed statement in the case.

column2: Mamata meets PM Modi's wife before boarding flight to meet him
column3: West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee on Tuesday met PM Narendra Modi's wife Jashodaben at the Kolkata airport before boarding her flight to Delhi. Reportedly, it was an accidental meeting as Jashodaben was leaving the city after a two-day visit to Dhanbad. Meanwhile, Banerjee is scheduled to meet PM Modi in Delhi on Wednesday.

column2: Indonesia raises legal marriage age for women from 16 to 19
column3: The Indonesian Parliament has raised the minimum age at which women can marry from 16 to 19 in a bid to curb child marriages. Previously parents could ask religious courts or officials to authorise the marriages of girls aged below 16. One in four girls in Indonesia is married before they turn 18, according to Indonesia's Statistics Agency and UNICEF.

column2: Govt to shut down STC, PEC and MMTC one by one: Piyush Goyal
column3: Commerce and Industry Minister Piyush Goyal has said the government will shut down state-owned trading companies such as State Trading Corporation (STC), Project and Equipment Corporation (PEC) and MMTC one by one. "It's not the business of the government to remain in such businesses. The government should not run companies only for gold imports," Goyal added.

column2: Global daily forex trading surges to $6.6 trillion, London biggest hub
column3: Global daily currency turnover jumped to $6.6 trillion in April 2019, up 29% from $5.1 trillion in 2016, the Bank for International Settlements said. London's share of daily volumes rose to 43% from 37%, while the US' share shrank to 17% from 20%. The dollar remained the most dominant currency and was on one side of 88% of all trades.

column2: India looks to raise oil imports from Russia after Saudi attacks
column3: Oil Minister Dharmendra Pradhan has said India is looking at raising oil imports from Russia after an attack on Saudi facilities halved the kingdom's production. "Today I met excellency Igor Sechin, CEO of Rosneft. We elaborately discussed the possibility of oil imports," Pradhan said. Notably, Rosneft holds a 49.13% stake in Nayara Energy, which owns India's second-largest refinery in Vadinar.

column2: Big B praises Mumbai Metro, calls it 'Solution for Pollution'
column3: Amitabh Bachchan on Monday praised the Mumbai Metro and tweeted, "Friend of mine had a medical emergency, decided to take METRO instead of his car.. came back very impressed.. said was faster, convenient and most efficient." "Solution for Pollution. Grow more trees, I did in my garden. Have you," he added. Mumbai Metro thanked Bachchan for sharing the experience.

column2: I'm petrified of the responsibility of a kid: Mallika Sherawat
column3: Actress Mallika Sherawat has said that she's not ready for parenthood as she thinks "it's too much of a responsibility" for her. "I'm petrified of the responsibility of a kid," she added. "If I have a child, I'd have to think of the child all the time. I'll go crazy... about which school and all of that," she further said.

column2: Stop creating space for terrorists in J&K: Rahul to Govt
column3: Congress' Rahul Gandhi on Tuesday said the government should release the detained J&K leaders and stop creating space for terrorists. He accused the government of removing nationalist leaders like Farooq Abdullah for creating a political vacuum that "will be filled by terrorists". "Kashmir can then permanently be used as a political instrument to polarise the rest of India," added Gandhi.

column2: Era of corrupt over, good governance has begun: Naqvi
column3: Union Minister Mukhtar Abbas Naqvi on Tuesday said the "era of the corrupt" has come to an end and the phase of good governance, inclusive growth and service to the poor has begun. He claimed that this phase is being recognised worldwide as "Modi Revolution". The corrupts are either in jail or are waiting for their turn, Naqvi added.

column2: Hunger significantly alters decision-making process: Study
column3: A new study claims hunger significantly alters people's decision-making, making them impatient and more likely to settle for a small reward that arrives sooner than a larger one promised at a later date. As a part of the study, participants were asked questions relating to food, money and other rewards when satiated and again when they had skipped a meal.

column2: Screen time found to have no negative mental health effect on kids
column3: A new study has stated that there is no connection between the amount of time kids spend online using digital technologies and mental health symptoms like depression and anxiety. The study additionally found that kids who sent more text messages actually reported better mental health. "The hope is that more parents will hear this message and relax," a researcher stated.

column2: Andre Russell, wife announce pregnancy; reveal gender by hitting ball
column3: West Indies all-rounder Andre Russell and his wife Jassym Lora announced they are expecting their first child. Russell shared a video on social media wherein the couple revealed the gender of the baby by hitting a ball. Jassym threw the ball towards Russell, who smashed it with bat and it burst into pink smoke, revealing that it is a girl.

column2: Virat Kohli and selectors should decide on Dhoni’s future: Sourav Ganguly
column3: On being asked about former India captain MS Dhoni's future, ex-India captain Sourav Ganguly said that selectors and captain Virat Kohli are "important persons" and they should make the decision. Further, on being asked if he would like to become Team India head coach, Ganguly said, "Let one coach finish, then we will think about the other coach."

column2: Jamaican college footballers struck by lightning during match
column3: A video has surfaced online showing Jamaican college footballers being struck by lightning during match. As soon as the lightning struck, two players fell onto their knees and clutched their heads. The referee later called off the match as five players in total were affected, according to local reports. One of the players complained of chest pain.

column2: Amazon changed product search to favour more profitable products: WSJ
column3: Amazon tweaked its product-search algorithm to favour more profitable products, The Wall Street Journal reported on Monday quoting Amazon employees. It said the move may have favoured Amazon's own brands to appear in the product search, adding that the algorithm was modified late last year. However, Amazon denied any such change to the algorithm to favour profitability or own products.

column2: 12-year-old boy stabs his tuition teacher to death in Mumbai
column3: A 12-year-old boy stabbed his tuition teacher to death at her home in Shivajinagar in Mumbai, police said on Tuesday. The incident happened on Monday night when the victim was giving home tuition to the 12-year-old boy. As per reports, the boy's mother had sought money from the tuition teacher but she refused, which resulted in an argument.

column2: Chidambaram condemns Farooq Abdullah's detention under PSA
column3: Congress leader P Chidambaram, who is lodged in Delhi's Tihar Jail in INX Media case, on Tuesday condemned the detention of former Jammu and Kashmir Chief Minister Farooq Abdullah under the Public Safety Act (PSA). Chidambaram said that no one in Kashmir was more devoted to the idea of a united India than Farooq Abdullah.

column2: Maharashtra CM's wife calls PM Modi 'father of our country' in b'day wish
column3: Maharashtra Chief Minister Devendra Fadnavis's wife Amruta Fadnavis called Prime Minister Narendra Modi 'father of our country' in her tweet wishing the PM on his birthday. Reacting to her tweet, a user wrote, "When did PM Modi become the father of the country and how?" "Father of our nation is only Mahatma Gandhi," wrote another.

column2: Cong leader DK Shivakumar sent to judicial custody till October 1
column3: Karnataka Congress leader DK Shivakumar, who was arrested by the Enforcement Directorate in a money laundering case earlier this month, was sent to judicial custody till October 1 by a court in Delhi on Tuesday. Special judge Ajay Kumar Kuhar directed the ED to take Shivakumar to a hospital first and to see whether doctors suggest admitting him there.

column2: Tripura college student held for defaming CM Deb on social media
column3: A 20-year-old college student in Tripura was arrested for allegedly defaming Chief Minister Biplab Kumar Deb and for attempting to hatch a conspiracy against him on social media, police said on Tuesday. According to Deputy Inspector General (DIG) Arindam Nath, the student wrote "abusive words" on WhatsApp against Biplab Deb and attempted to hatch a conspiracy against him.

column2: PM Modi shares his old photos sent by people on his 69th birthday
column3: Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who turned 69 on Tuesday, took to social media to share some of his old pictures sent to him by people. "Reliving precious moments and special memories. I have been receiving many old photos from various friends," he tweeted. "If you have such memories, kindly share them with me," the PM added.

column2: Taliban holds discussions with Iran after talks with US collapse
column3: A delegation from Afghanistan's Taliban held discussions with Iran, a week after talks between the militant group and the US collapsed, Iran's Foreign Ministry said on Tuesday. The talks were held in the framework of "comprehensive consultations with all parties in Afghanistan", Iran said. The US had earlier accused Iran of providing military training, money and weapons to the Taliban.

column2: Archer special, he's going to make things happen: Joe Root
column3: Speaking about 24-year-old pacer Jofra Archer, England's Test captain Joe Root said that he is "something special". Adding the team should be careful not to expect too much of him, Root said, "One thing we can expect is he's going to entertain and he's going to make things happen." Archer picked up 22 wickets in the recently-concluded Ashes 2019.

column2: Zidane likes my brother, everyone knows it: Pogba's brother
column3: Speaking about his brother Paul Pogba's transfer speculation linked with Real Madrid, Mathias Pogba said, "I like (Real Madrid coach) [Zinedine] Zidane and he likes my brother, everyone knows it." Juventus and Real Madrid were linked with a move for Pogba in the summer but United were reportedly asking for a price around £150 million.

column2: Google announces Oct 15 event, expected to unveil Pixel 4
column3: Google has announced that it will be hosting a 'Made by Google' event on October 15 where it is expected to launch the next generation Pixel 4 and Pixel 4 XL smartphones. The event will take place in New York where Google is also expected to launch Pixelbook 2, new Google Home speakers and other devices.

column2: Maharashtra govt ties-up with Zipline to deliver medicines via drones
column3: The Maharashtra government announced on Monday that it will tie-up with US firm Zipline to use autonomous delivery drones to deliver emergency medicines and critical care across the state. The initiative will be supported through a grant from Serum Institute of India (SII). Zipline will establish about 10 distribution centres across Maharashtra in phases over the next several years.

column2: Breaking up big tech companies a bad idea, says Bill Gates
column3: Ex-Microsoft CEO Bill Gates said that breaking-up the biggest US tech companies will be a bad idea, as suggested by politicians. "Splitting the company in two, and having two people doing the bad thing--that doesn't seem like a solution," Gates told Bloomberg. His comments come after US government officials are scrutinising tech companies for becoming too big and powerful.

column2: Ziro music festival to be held in Arunachal Pradesh from Sept 26-29
column3: The Ziro Festival of Music held annually in Arunachal Pradesh's Ziro valley is being held from September 26-29 later this month. The outdoor music festival, hosted by the Apatani tribe which is known for its hospitality, also offers attendees to experience the local food and wine. People can also camp nearby and enjoy the jamming sessions.

column2: Her reaction is natural: Gehlot on Mayawati's remarks
column3: After BSP supremo Mayawati called Rajasthan Congress "untrustworthy" and "deceitful" as six BSP MLAs joined Congress on Monday, Rajasthan CM Ashok Gehlot said her reaction was "natural". "MLAs considered the situation in the state and feelings of the people, that's why they joined, we didn't pressurise them," he added. Our state has never indulged in horse-trading, the CM added.

column2: Cred raises $9.5 mn in Series B funding from General Catalyst
column3: Credit card bill payment app Cred has raised about $9.5 million in Series B funding round from US-based venture capital fund General Catalyst. In July, Cred had raised $120 million in the same round led by fintech fund Tiger Global, Ribbit Capital, Gemini Investments, existing investor Sequoia Capital, etc. Following that round, its valuation rose to $450 million.

column2: Meddo raises $3 mn in pre-Series A funding led by SRI Capital
column3: Healthcare startup Meddo Health, started by former Foodpanda CEO Saurabh Kochhar, has raised $3 million in a pre-Series A funding round led by SRI Capital. The round also saw participation from growX Ventures, LetsVenture, Venture Gurukool and Citrus Payment Founder Jitendra Gupta, among others. Founded in 2018, Meddo claims to have tie-ups with more than 400 doctors and 200 clinics.

column2: ISRO thanks supporters after Chandrayaan-2 mission
column3: Days after the Indian Space Research Organisation's (ISRO) Vikram lander lost communication while attempting to land on the Moon, the space agency posted a tweet, thanking supporters from around the world. The tweet read, "Thank you for standing by us. We will continue to keep going forward — propelled by the hopes and dreams of Indians across the world!"

column2: Bottle of lethal pesticide found in rice sack in Kerala school
column3: A bottle of aluminium phosphide, used for killing rats and in other pest control methods, was recovered from a rice sack in a school in Kerala. The pesticide bottle was found when staff opened the rice sack to prepare a meal. The Food Corporation of India and Supplyco officials later arrived at the school and inspected the remaining stock.

column2: Thai PM defends police monitoring of Muslim university students
column3: Thailand's PM Prayut Chan-o-cha on Tuesday said the police requesting information about Muslim students from universities was needed to build a national security database. "No rights have been breached. We cannot manage anything if we don't have data," he added. "This is interference to personal rights and discrimination based on religion," former rights commissioner Angkhana Neelapaijit said.

column2: 65,000 displaced in Myanmar's Rakhine & Chin this year: UN
column3: Up to 65,000 people have been displaced by conflict across northern Rakhine and southern Chin States since January, UN Special Rapporteur on the rights situation in Myanmar Yanghee Lee said. Myanmar's army has reportedly deployed thousands of soldiers there to fight rebels from Arakan Army. Government has restricted humanitarian access in conflict areas affecting 1,00,000 people, Lee added.

column2: Cancer survivor Sarah 1st person to swim Channel four times non-stop
column3: Breast cancer survivor Sarah Thomas has become the first person to swim English Channel four times non-stop. The 37-year-old American swam 215 km in 54 hours. As many as four swimmers previously crossed the Channel three times without stopping. She was diagnosed with an aggressive form of breast cancer in November 2017 after which she underwent chemotherapy, surgery and radiation.

column2: I will do everything I can to bounce back: Warner in message to fans
column3: Australia opener David Warner took to Instagram to share a message with his fans following 2019 Ashes. "For me personally it was a tough series but my challenge now is to bounce back. I’ll be doing everything I can to do just that," he wrote. "The fact we retained the urn makes all our hard work worthwhile," he added.

column2: Musk hired detective to probe man who sued over 'pedo guy' tweet
column3: Tesla CEO Elon Musk has revealed that he hired a private investigator for $50,000 to support his claim that British caver Vernon Unsworth was a "pedo guy". "The investigator learned that Mr Unsworth frequented Pattaya Beach [in Thailand] which is well known for prostitution and sex tourism," Musk said in a court filing. Unsworth has sued Musk for defamation.

column2: Fisherman catches 'dinosaur-like' fish off Norway coast, pic goes viral
column3: A picture of a fish with huge eyes caught off the coast of Norway by Oscar Lundahl, a 19-year-old guide for a fishing company, has gone viral. He described the fish as "a bit dinosaur-like", adding that he has never seen anything like it before. The fish is a ratfish, a relative of shark that dates back 300 million years.

column2: Supreme Court to be blamed for economic slowdown: Harish Salve
column3: Supreme Court lawyer Harish Salve has blamed the apex court for the economic slowdown. Salve said that the economic decline began with the SC judgment in the 2012 2G spectrum case, wherein 122 spectrum licences were cancelled. "Foreigners invested billions of dollars, and with one stroke of the pen, the Supreme Court knocked all of them out," added Salve.

column2: Kerala man caught between wheel & body of bus survives, video surfaces
column3: A Kerala man escaped with knee injuries after being caught between the wheel and body of a bus, a video of which has surfaced. He was standing near his two-wheeler when a bus hit a few two-wheelers parked near him and knocked him and his vehicle down. The bus continued to move for a short distance, dragging him with it.

column2: PoK part of India, expect to have physical jurisdiction over it: EAM
column3: External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar on Tuesday said, "PoK (Pakistan Occupied Kashmir) is part of India and we expect one day that we'll have physical jurisdiction over it." He added, "Our position on PoK has always been very clear." Earlier, Defence Minister Rajnath Singh said that if talks take place between India and Pakistan, then it will be on PoK.

column2: 3 Russian border guards injured in attack by N Korean poachers
column3: Three Russian border guards aboard a border patrol ship were injured in an attack by North Korean poachers in the Sea of Japan on Tuesday. The Russian Coast Guard seized two North Korean vessels and its crew for allegedly poaching fish in Russia's exclusive economic zone. More than 65 crew members are on board the two North Korean vessels.

column2: Indonesia arrests 185 people suspected of starting forest fires
column3: Indonesia arrested around 185 people suspected of starting forest fires which have destroyed over 3.28 lakh hectares of land nationwide from January to August 2019. Forests in Indonesia are illegally set on fire to clear land for the lucrative palm oil and pulpwood industries. Meanwhile, nearly 1.5 lakh people have been treated for acute respiratory infections related to the haze.

column2: 200 people booked over anti-Hindu riots in Pakistan's Sindh
column3: More than 200 people have been booked in connection with the anti-Hindu riots in Pakistan's Sindh province on Sunday. The riots began after the Hindu owner of a school was accused by a student of passing blasphemous remarks. The mob vandalised the school and at least five shops owned by Hindus and also desecrated a temple.

column2: What are some of the biggest oil supply disruptions in history?
column3: The drone attacks on Saudi crude processing facilities cut production by 5.7 million barrels/day, the single biggest sudden disruption on record. It surpasses the loss of Kuwaiti and Iraqi supply in August 1990, when Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait. It also exceeds the loss of Iranian oil output during the Islamic Revolution in 1978-79, according to the International Energy Agency.

column2: Capable of responding to attacks: Saudi after attacks on oil plants
column3: Saudi Arabia's King Salman Bin Abdulaziz Al Saud has said that the kingdom is capable of defending itself against "cowardly" attacks. His statement came following the drone attacks on two Saudi Aramco oil facilities last week. Yemen's Iran-backed Houthi rebels claimed responsibility for the attacks, but the US blamed Iran for it.

column2: Suriya, Kamal urge fans not to use film banners after girl's death
column3: Following the death of 23-year-old girl Subhasri Ravi in Chennai, actors Kamal Haasan and Suriya have urged their fans to not put up banners during the release of their films. Suriya asked his fans to express their admiration through blood donation camps instead of erecting cut-outs. Subhasri died after a hoarding fell on her when she was on her two-wheeler.

column2: Don’t see many who bowl at 150 kmph: Klusener praises Saini
column3: Former South African all-rounder Lance Klusener praised Indian youngster Navdeep Saini, saying, "I am so glad to see Navdeep Saini being recognised. You don't see many in Indian cricket who can bowl at 150 kmph." Klusener said that he talked to Saini and realised that the pacer is 'hungry' to bowl at speeds above 150 kmph.

column2: US college apologises for dismissing black athletes 50 yrs ago
column3: The University of Wyoming has issued an apology to 14 black athletes who were suspended by the university in 1969 for wanting to protest a policy prohibiting black people from becoming priests. The university held a commemorative week in honour of the 14 players, called the "Black 14". The week was attended by eight of the 11 living players.

column2: Don't think it's right to play Anderson and Broad together: Vaughan
column3: Former captain Michael Vaughan has said that he does not think it is right to play pacers James Anderson and Stuart Broad together for England in the future. "They're not going to like it, but they're at that stage of their careers where England...have to manage the combination very smartly," he added. Anderson and Broad are England's leading Test wicket-takers.

column2: Tinder to launch own TV series, wraps filming: Reports
column3: Dating app Tinder is set to launch its own TV show and has wrapped-up the filming of the series as its parent company Match Group looks to get into original content creation, reports said. The series has an 'apocalyptic' storyline with a 'relationship subplot'. It was filmed in Mexico City in late August and the post-production is reportedly underway.

column2: Will talk on issues related to WB: Mamata on meeting with PM
column3: West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee on Tuesday said that in her meeting with PM Narendra Modi, she would highlight issues like funds that are due to the state, among others. She will be meeting PM Modi on Wednesday. "I'll also highlight issues like change of West Bengal's name...merger of public sector banks, issues with Air India, BSNL, Railways," Mamata added.

column2: 6 BSP MLAs joined Cong without any conditions: Sachin Pilot
column3: Rajasthan Deputy CM Sachin Pilot on Tuesday said six BSP MLAs have joined Congress without any conditions or demand for benefit. "If by seeing our work, any MLA wants to join the Congress for the sake of faster progress of his constituency, then no one should object to it," he added. Congress now has 106 seats in the 200-seat Assembly.

column2: Russian volcano causing purple sunrises, sunsets: Research
column3: A remote Russian volcano Raikoke's eruption in June is being called the reason behind the recent sunrises and sunsets with a purple hue in the Northern Hemisphere. According to researchers, the volcano released sulfur dioxide into the atmosphere, which led to the creation of tiny particles called aerosols. The aerosols scatter sunlight which results in the purple-hued skies.

column2: Govt mulling security fencing on Indo-Nepal border: BJP MP
column3: BJP MP Akshaibar Lal on Monday said that the Centre is mulling the possibility of fencing the Indo-Nepal border to curb human trafficking. "Human trafficking is the most inhuman crime and should be checked effectively," the Bahraich MP added. Lal also said that besides the government, social groups and defence forces will have to work together on the issue.

column2: Iran rules out talks with US as Trump links it to Saudi attack
column3: Iran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei on Tuesday ruled out talks with the US after President Donald Trump blamed Tehran for an attack on Saudi oil facilities. "Iranian officials... will never talk to American officials," he said. Talks could only take place if the US returned to nuclear accord with Iran that it abandoned last year, Khamenei added.

column2: Truck plunges down ravine in Philippines, 20 dead
column3: A truck accident in the Philippines claimed the lives of 20 people and left 14 injured after the vehicle plunged into a ravine on Tuesday. The truck was reportedly bringing a group of people home from a trip to the beach. "Based on eyewitness accounts, the truck lost its brakes. We will conduct further investigations," an official said.

column2: Surat baker plans to make 700-foot-long cake on PM Modi's birthday
column3: As part of celebrations on PM Narendra Modi's birthday on September 17, the owner of a Surat-based bakery has planned to produce a 700-foot-long cake. Weighing 7,000 kg, the cake will be cut by 700 'honest people' at Sarsana convention centre. "It will be a world record for biggest cake," the owner of the bakery said.

column2: Man fails to find helmet that fits on his head; police lets him go
column3: A Gujarat man escaped being fined for riding a two-wheeler without a helmet after he told police that he couldn't find a helmet that can fit on his head. "I respect the law...As far as helmet is concerned, I'm helpless," he said. The police didn't penalise him, saying, "He is a law-abiding person and keeps all relevant documents while driving."

column2: Not joining any other party: Urmila Matondkar after leaving Congress
column3: Actress-politician Urmila Matondkar, who resigned from Congress party earlier this month, said on Tuesday that she is not joining any other party. Her clarification came amid rumours about her joining Shiv Sena following her meeting with the personal assistant of party chief Uddhav Thackeray. She added that her talk with Milind Narvekar was just a "courtesy meeting".

column2: Was in anda cell for a month: Sooraj on his arrest after Jiah's suicide
column3: Actor Sooraj Pancholi, while speaking about being arrested after his ex-girlfriend Jiah Khan committed suicide, said, "For about a month, I was put in the anda cell at...Arthur Road jail which is the most secluded cell." "You've no contact with anyone...I was completely numb," he added. The case has been running in court with the matter being sub judice.

column2: Ben Stokes criticises newspaper over article on murders in his family
column3: England all-rounder Ben Stokes has described a front page story by 'The Sun' newspaper about a family tragedy 31 years ago as "disgusting" and "immoral". 'The Sun' published the story about murders of his half-brother and half-sister, titled 'Hero Ben's brother and sister were shot dead'. "The decision to publish these details has...lifelong consequences for my mum," Stokes wrote.

column2: Computer scientist who defended sex offender Epstein quits MIT
column3: Computer scientist and open software advocate Richard Stallman, who defended late convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, has resigned as a visiting scientist at MIT's research institute CSAIL. Stallman had described a victim of Epstein as "entirely willing". He had also allegedly called for legalising child pornography and abolishing age of consent laws on his personal blog over 15 years.

column2: India-US relationship in very good health: EAM S Jaishankar
column3: External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar on Tuesday said that the India-US relations have come a long way and are in "very good health". Jaishankar added, "As the relationship grows there will be issues. We have been talking to the US, my expectation is that the sharper edges will be addressed in the not too distant future."

column2: No massages by opposite gender: SDMC to issue advisory to spas
column3: South Delhi Municipal Corporation (SDMC) will issue a mandatory advisory to all spas and massage parlours in its jurisdiction asking them "not to provide cross-gender massage services to customers". This comes after reports of alleged sex rackets running at such facilities. If the spas do not follow the advisory, their Health Trade License will be cancelled, an SDMC official said.

column2: School gets washed away in river Ganga in Bihar, video surfaces online
column3: A video of a school getting washed away in river Ganga in Bihar's Katihar district has surfaced online. No teacher or student was present at the time of the incident as the Education Department had suspended classes at the premises and shifted children to another school earlier. In the video, villagers can be seen looking at the school collapsing.

column2: US teen jailed for 20 yrs over support to Pak-based Lashkar-e-Taiba
column3: An 18-year-old American named Michael Kyle Sewell has been sentenced to 20 years in prison for conspiring to provide material support to Pakistan-based terrorist organisation Lashkar-e-Taiba (LeT). Sewell had helped his co-conspirator with his plans to travel to Pakistan to join LeT. Authorities had found an AR-15 style rifle, multiple magazines and several knives in Sewell's bedroom.

column2: Taliban claims responsibility for blast at Afghan President's rally
column3: The Taliban has claimed responsibility for the blast at Afghan President Ashraf Ghani's rally on Tuesday. A suicide bomber blew himself up at the rally in the Parwan province, killing 24 people and injuring 32 others. The suicide attack targeted Afghan security forces, the Taliban said.

column2: US releases images showing damage to Saudi oil facility
column3: The US released satellite images revealing the extent of the damage to infrastructure at the world's largest oil processing facility in Saudi Arabia's Abqaiq after drone attacks. One photo shows a row of four spherical tanks that process crude each with similar puncture marks. There were 17 different points of impact at the Abqaiq complex, according to the US government.

column2: S Asia's tallest tower in shape of 356-m lotus unveiled in Sri Lanka
column3: Sri Lanka on Monday unveiled South Asia's tallest tower, the Lotus Tower, in the capital Colombo. Constructed in the shape of a 356-metre lotus, the tower has been built at a cost of $104.3 million, 80% of which has been funded by the Chinese government. The tower includes a restaurant, conference hall and an observation area, among others.

column2: Rare polka-dotted zebra foal spotted in Kenyan wildlife reserve
column3: A newborn zebra foal with unusual polka dot markings has been photographed in Kenya's Maasai Mara National Reserve. The foal has a melanin disorder in which the stripes don't develop properly and are replaced by a pattern of small stripes and spots. The discovery reportedly caused a 'stampede' as tourists and guides rushed to take a look at the foal.

column2: GM to transfer assets, staff of Bengaluru technical centre to TCS
column3: General Motors has announced an agreement with TCS under which certain assets and 1,300 employees of the US carmaker's Bengaluru-based technical centre will be transferred to the IT firm. TCS will partner with GM to support its global vehicle programmes with engineering design services over the next 5 years. TCS has been working for GM for the past 16 years.

column2: Shah raises questions over success of multi-party democracy
column3: Union Minister Amit Shah on Tuesday raised questions on the success of multi-party democratic system in India. The aim of the multi-party system was to further the national progress, Shah said. After 70 years of independence, people had doubts in their mind on whether the multi-party system had failed and if it would meet their goals, he added.

column2: Syntizen raises pre-Series A funding from Mastercard, ACPL
column3: Digital identity solutions provider Syntizen Technologies has raised an undisclosed amount in a pre-Series A funding round from Mastercard and biometric solutions provider ACPL. The startup was founded by Siddharth Kukatlapalli, Vamsi Kotte and Dinesh Desu in 2014. It has clients like Muthoot Fincorp, Manappuram Finance, Shriram Housing, Angel Broking, Videocon Telecommunications, etc.

column2: Astronomers detect the most massive neutron star ever
column3: Astronomers using the Green Bank Telescope discovered that J0740+6620, a rapidly rotating millisecond pulsar, is the most massive neutron star ever measured. The neutron star has a mass that is 2.17 times the mass of our Sun packed into a sphere which is 30 kilometers across. The discovery will help understand the limits of mass density that nature will allow.

column2: LJP workers offer milk to PM Modi's banner on his b'day
column3: Lok Janshakti Party (LJP) workers on Tuesday offered milk to PM Narendra Modi's poster on the occasion of his 69th birthday. Surrounding the poster were a group of saffron-clad children and a priest who poured the milk while chanting Vedic mantras. The banner with PM Modi's picture read, "We want PoK as return gift."

column2: People are wearing saffron and raping: Digvijaya Singh
column3: Former Madhya Pradesh Chief Minister and Congress leader Digvijaya Singh on Tuesday said that "people are wearing saffron clothes and raping". "Rapes are happening inside temples, is this our religion?" he added. "Those who have defamed our 'Sanatan Dharma', even God will not forgive them," the Congress leader further said.

column2: Doordarshan news anchor Salma Sultan walks the ramp at 72
column3: Seventy-two-year-old Doordarshan news anchor Salma Sultan on Sunday walked the ramp in a saree. Talking about the occasion, Salma said, "I don't believe millennials have any problem wearing the saree, it's... about ensuring that they have confidence. When confidence is there you can pull off any attire." Kathak dancer and Padma Shri-awardee Shovana Narayan also attended the event.

column2: Tata Power exits South African JV 'Cennergi' for $106 mn
column3: Tata Power announced on Tuesday that it sold its entire 50% stake in Cennergi, a South African joint venture, for $106 million. The entire stake will be acquired by Exxaro Resources, which owns the other 50% of Cennergi. The agreement is likely to be completed by the third quarter of FY20. Cennergi owns two wind power farms in South Africa.

column2: Peace in J&K, not a single shot fired since August 5: Amit Shah
column3: Addressing an event in New Delhi, Union Home Minister Amit Shah on Monday stated, "From August 5 till now, we did not have to fire a single shot and not even a single person has died. There is peace in Kashmir." He made the statement over a month after Article 370, which gave special status to J&K, was abrogated.

column2: I doubt US will do a wealth tax; wouldn't oppose it: Bill Gates
column3: World's second-richest person, Microsoft Co-founder Bill Gates in a recent interview said he doubts the US will do a wealth tax, but he wouldn't oppose it. The 63-year-old also backed higher income taxes on America's wealthiest people alongside a call for greater financial transparency. "I don't like that you can have trusts where nobody knows who owns it," he said.

column2: EU's €13 billion tax bill 'defies reality, common sense': Apple
column3: Apple, in a legal challenge launched on Tuesday, said that the August 2016 European Commission order to pay €13 billion in Irish back taxes "defies reality and common sense". The commission had said that tax rulings by Ireland in 1991 and 2007 artificially reduced Apple's tax burden for over two decades, effectively making it illegal state aid.

column2: Uber working on Ola-like OTP verification before starting ride: Report
column3: Uber is reportedly testing a new feature that allows users to share a four-digit code before starting a ride. The four-digit code-based verification appeared in Uber's Android app for some users. Uber's homegrown rival Ola Cabs has a similar feature for a long time, that requires the riders to share an OTP with their drivers before the ride begins.

column2: OYO misused tech, falsified bookings: B'luru hoteliers' association
column3: Bengaluru-based Bruhat Bangalore Hotels Association contacted the Bengaluru police commissioner to conduct an investigation into alleged unfair business practices by OYO. The association accused OYO of misusing its technology to falsify booking data. OYO Founder and CEO Ritesh Agarwal and two other company representatives were also recently booked over criminal breach of trust in Bengaluru.

column2: SC judge recuses from 17 disqualified Karnataka MLAs case
column3: Supreme Court judge Justice MM Shantanagoudar on Tuesday recused himself from hearing the petitions filed by 17 disqualified MLAs of Karnataka, challenging the decision of the then Speaker to disqualify them from the Assembly. Justice Shantanagoudar recused himself saying that he was from Karnataka and added that his conscience was not permitting him to hear the case.

column2: Air-to-Air missile Astra successfully flight tested from Su-30 MKI
column3: Air-to-Air missile Astra was successfully flight tested off the coast of Odisha today. The missile was launched from Su-30 MKI as a part of User trials. The live aerial target was engaged accurately demonstrating the capability of first indigenous air-to-air missile, a statement said. Radars, Electro-Optical Tracking System and sensors tracked the missile and confirmed its engagement with target.

column2: Hindu student found dead in Pak college hostel; brother alleges murder
column3: A Hindu doctor from Pakistan's Sindh region has appealed for help after his sister, a medical student, was found dead with a piece of cloth tied around her neck in her hostel room in Larkana on Monday. Namrita Chandani was studying at Bibi Aseefa Dental College. Alleging murder, Namrita's brother Vishal said he found cable marks around her neck.

column2: PM Narendra Modi meets his mother on birthday, eats lunch with her
column3: Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who turned 69 on Tuesday, met his mother in Gujarat and they had lunch together at her residence. Earlier in the day, he visited the Sardar Sarovar Dam in Kevadia and the Statue of Unity. He also visited the Cactus Garden, Ekta Nursery and Butterfly Garden, and set a bag full of butterflies free.

column2: Iran seizes vessel in Gulf for allegedly smuggling fuel to UAE
column3: Iran has seized a vessel in the Gulf for allegedly smuggling 2.5 lakh litres of diesel fuel to the UAE, a semi-official Iranian news agency said. The crew have been handed over to authorities in the Hormozgan province. Earlier this month, Iranian coast guards seized a vessel for smuggling fuel in the Gulf and detained its 12 Filipino crew members.

column2: Sensex falls 642 points as oil prices rise, Nifty erases 2019 gains
column3: Indian equities fell for a second straight session on Tuesday as oil prices surged following attacks on Saudi Arabian oil facilities. The Sensex ended 642 points lower at 36,481.09 and the Nifty 50 fell 186 points to 10,817.60, wiping out this year's gains. Oil marketing companies extended losses to a second day, with Indian Oil and Bharat Petroleum falling 1.4%-2.1%.

column2: Over 6 crore EPFO members to soon get 8.65% interest for FY19
column3: Labour Minister Santosh Gangwar on Tuesday said that over 6 crore Employees' Provident Fund Organisation (EPFO) members will soon get 8.65% interest on their PF deposits for 2018-19. In February, EPFO's Central Board of Trustees decided to raise the interest rate to 8.65% for 2018-19, the first increase in the past three years. EPFO had paid 8.55% interest for 2017-18.

column2: Actors Jay, Mahhi reveal daughter's name after 20,000 suggestions
column3: Television actor Jay Bhanushali and wife Mahhi Vij, who were blessed with a baby girl on August 21, have named their daughter Tara after receiving more than 20,000 suggestions. Mahhi had earlier asked fans to suggest names beginning with the letter T or M for their newborn. Thanking their fans, Jay and Mahhi shared a video showing their baby's hands.

column2: I don't fear getting typecast, won't stop doing comedy: Varun
