column2: Afghanistan break own world record of most consecutive T20I victories
column3: Afghanistan defeated Bangladesh by 25 runs in the T20I tri-series to register their 12th consecutive victory in T20I cricket. With this, Afghanistan set the world record for the longest winning streak in men's T20I cricket, surpassing their own streak of 11 matches (2016-2017). Further, Afghanistan have won each of their last 21 T20I matches in Asia.

column2: Smith scores most runs by a batsman in a Test series in last 25 years
column3: Australia batsman Steve Smith ended his Ashes 2019 campaign with 774 runs in seven innings, registering the most runs by a batsman in a Test series in the last 25 years. The last time a batsman scored more runs in a Test series than Smith's 774 was in 1994 when ex-West Indies captain Brian Lara scored 798 runs against England.

column2: India-SA T20I abandoned without a ball bowled due to rain in Dharamshala
column3: The first T20I between India and South Africa in Dharamshala has been abandoned without a ball being bowled due to rain. The match was called off hours before the cut-off time of 9:46 PM due to consistent rainfall. The second match of the three-match series will take place in Mohali on Wednesday.

column2: We will implement NRC in Haryana: Manohar Lal Khattar
column3: Haryana Chief Minister Manohar Lal Khattar today announced that the National Register of Citizens (NRC) will be implemented in the state. Khattar gave the statement in Panchkula after meeting retired High Court judge HS Bhalla and former Navy Chief Admiral Sunil Lanba at their residences. Khattar met them under the BJP's 'Maha Sampark Abhiyan' ahead of the upcoming Assembly polls.

column2: You can't insult North Indians: Priyanka on Gangwar's comments
column3: Congress General Secretary Priyanka Gandhi tweeted that Union Minister Santosh Gangwar cannot get away with insulting North Indians. She added, "It has been more than five years for your government. There is no job creation. Whatever jobs were there, they've been snatched due to the economic slowdown." Gangwar had said there was a lack of qualified candidates in North India.

column2: Over 16,000 people shifted after heavy rain in Madhya Pradesh
column3: Over 16,000 people from Madhya Pradesh's Mandsaur and Neemuch districts were shifted to safer places on Sunday after heavy rainfall caused waterlogging in several areas there, an official said. Mandsaur received 218 mm rain while Manasa town in Neemuch got 243 mm rain in 24 hours ending Sunday morning, as per the India Meteorological Department's (IMD) office.

column2: Delhi CM meets ex-Tata Steel colleagues to mark Engineers' Day
column3: Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal on Saturday met his friends from Tata Steel at Jamshedpur to mark the Engineers' Day, which is being observed on Sunday. "We had joined Tata Steel as trainee engineers over 30 years ago. Relived some wonderful memories," tweeted Kejriwal. "My best wishes to all my fellow engineers on Engineers Day!" he added.

column2: 2 die, 20 hurt as bus runs into parked truck on Yamuna Expressway
column3: Two passengers were killed and 20 others injured when a private bus on its way to Delhi rammed into a stationary truck on the Yamuna Expressway on Sunday, police said. The bus, with 45 passengers on board, was coming from Azamgarh in Uttar Pradesh. Two men from UP's Bulandshahr and Azamgarh, both aged around 35, were killed in the accident.

column2: Swarm of bees delay Air India Kolkata-Agartala flight by 2 hours
column3: A Kolkata-Agartala Air India flight was delayed for around two hours on Sunday after a swarm of bees was noticed in front of the aircraft while it was taxiing towards the runway at Kolkata airport. As many as 136 passengers and crew members were on the flight when bees were spotted. Fire Services personnel were called to tackle the problem.

column2: House collapses within seconds after heavy rainfall in UP, video surfaces
column3: A house in Keharpur village of Bairia tehsil in Uttar Pradesh's Ballia district collapsed within seconds following heavy and incessant rainfall. A video of the incident that went viral shows the house, situated near river Ganga, collapsing within seconds. Some of the rivers in Uttar Pradesh are flowing above the danger mark, reports said.

column2: Video leak a conspiracy: Dad of law student allegedly raped by BJP leader
column3: The father of UP law student, who accused BJP leader Swami Chinmayanand of raping her, has claimed that the leakage of the video footage given to the SIT by his daughter is a conspiracy. "From where have the screenshots and videos come to the social media?" he asked. He added that he would request Supreme Court to probe the leakage.

column2: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella performs father's last rites in Hyderabad
column3: Microsoft's Chief Executive Officer Satya Nadella performed his father BN Yugandhar's last rites and lit the funeral pyre in Hyderabad on Sunday. The only child of Yugandhar, Nadella reached Hyderabad late Saturday night. Yugandhar, a retired Indian Administrative Service officer, passed away on Friday at the age of 80 after a brief illness.

column2: Crediting RSS for India's existence exaggeration: JD(U) to BJP
column3: Janata Dal (United) National Spokesperson Pavan Varma on Sunday said that Rajasthan BJP President Satish Poonia's claim that without the RSS there would have been no India is an exaggeration. "India has existed. We call it Bharatvarsha; it is Sanatan, Anadi, Anant and a great civilisation," he said. "Let the RSS not take credit for everything," Varma added.

column2: Saying Pakistanis unhappy in Pak politically motivated: Pawar
column3: Nationalist Congress Party (NCP) chief Sharad Pawar on Saturday said that saying Pakistanis are unhappy in their country is politically motivated in India. He accused the BJP-led central government of spreading propaganda against Pakistan for political gains. Pawar also said that he was accorded hospitality whenever he visited Pakistan.

column2: PM Modi condoles deaths after boat capsizes in Godavari
column3: PM Narendra Modi on Sunday condoled the deaths in a boat capsizing accident in the East Godavari river, Andhra Pradesh. "Extremely pained by the capsizing of a boat... My thoughts are with the bereaved families," he said, adding that rescue operations are underway. At least 12 were reportedly killed and over 30 are missing after the boat carrying tourists overturned.

column2: I shop outside India as I can't walk into mall & try clothes here: Taapsee
column3: Speaking about being a public figure, Taapsee Pannu said, "I'd love to walk into the mall and shop, but it doesn't happen anymore." "I shop outside [India]...I can't walk into a mall and try on clothes here," she added. Taapsee said people pester her family to get through to her and they're trying to understand how to deal with it.

column2: Kashmiri Pandits hold rally in Aus to back Article 370 revocation
column3: The Kashmiri Pandit community in Melbourne, Australia on Sunday held a rally in support of the government's move to abrogate Article 370 of the Constitution that accorded special status to Jammu and Kashmir. Joined by other members of the Indian-Australian community, the rally was held from Victorian State Parliament to Federation Square. The Centre revoked Article 370 on August 5.

column2: World record for lowest average opening stand in 5-Test series broken
column3: The world record for lowest average opening partnership in a Test series of five or more matches has been broken after 113 years in the 2019 Ashes. The lowest average first wicket partnership in the 2019 Ashes was 12.55. The previous record was set in 1906 when the average was 14.16 in the five-Test series between South Africa and England.

column2: Indian Army Eastern Command condoles 9-year-old dog Dutch's death
column3: The Eastern Command of the Indian Army on Saturday condoled the death of a "decorated" dog named Dutch who died on Wednesday by garlanding him in Kolkata. Dutch was 9 years old and helped in identifying improvised explosive devices in various counter-terrorism and counter-insurgency operations. "A real hero in service to nation," the Eastern Command tweeted along with Dutch's pictures.

column2: Iran rejects US claim it was behind attacks on Saudi oil facilities
column3: Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesman Abbas Mousavi on Sunday dismissed US claim that Iran was behind drone attacks which hit two oil facilities in Saudi Arabia as "pointless". "Such useless accusations...are meaningless and not comprehensible," he added. Blaming Iran, US State Secretary Mike Pompeo had said, "Iran has now launched an unprecedented attack on the world's energy supply."

column2: United Bank, PNB, OBC's merged entity to be functional from April 1
column3: The amalgamated entity of United Bank of India, Punjab National Bank and Oriental Bank of Commerce will come into effect from April 1, 2020, UBI's MD & CEO Ashok Kumar Pradhan said on Saturday. The merged entity will be the second-largest public sector bank in the country after the State Bank of India.

column2: Air India crew to get low-fat dishes like tinda masala, sautéed spinach
column3: Air India has changed its menu for flight crew and is providing them 'low-fat diet meals', which include dishes like sautéed spinach, beetroot ki tikki, palak matar bhurji and tinda masala, to improve their health. As of now, the changed menu applies only on the flights operating from Delhi and Mumbai. The officials said the move was also cost-effective.

column2: I want to share my experiences with youngsters: Shreyas
column3: Actor Shreyas Talpade talked about his journey in an interview and said that he wants to share his experiences with youngsters. "All they need is a path and guidance on how to take it forth. I don't mind hand holding them," he added. "I had no godfather in the industry, and struggled my way through," he further said.

column2: Broad now has joint-most dismissals of a batsman in a series
column3: Pacer Stuart Broad on Sunday joined the list of bowlers who have the most dismissals of a batsman in a Test series after he claimed David Warner's wicket for the seventh time in the ongoing Ashes 2019. The other pairs include Glenn McGrath's seven dismissals of Mike Atherton in 1997 and Nathan Lyon's seven dismissals of Moeen Ali in 2017/18.

column2: Ponting backs Warner for Pakistan series despite poor Ashes 2019
column3: Former Australian captain Ricky Ponting has backed David Warner to be a part of the Australian team for the upcoming series against Pakistan despite poor performances in the ongoing Ashes 2019. "Marnus [Labuschagne] is an absolute lock. [Steve] Smith's a lock," Ponting added about the players that will surely be included in the squad for the home series against Pakistan.

column2: 16-yr-old earns standing ovation after Barca's win vs Valencia
column3: Barcelona's 16-year-old Ansu Fati, who became the third-youngest La Liga scorer this month, was given a standing ovation by the Camp Nou crowd after he helped his side register a 5-2 win over Valencia on Saturday. The teenager scored a goal in the second minute of the match before setting up Barcelona new signee Frenkie de Jong's first goal.

column2: Govt rejects Facebook's alternative to WhatsApp traceability
column3: The government has rejected Facebook Global Affairs VP Nick Clegg's proposed mechanism for WhatsApp to address cases flagged by law enforcement agencies. WhatsApp has so far refused India's demand for 'absolute' traceability of 'fake' WhatsApp messages to their originators. Clegg had instead suggested use of 'meta-data', machine intelligence and harnessing WhatsApp, Instagram and Facebook linkage.

column2: YouTube to remove TV-friendly interface for web 'soon'
column3: YouTube's TV-friendly web interface will be 'going away soon', a message on it said. The reason for the removal of the 'Leanback' interface, which was launched almost a decade ago, was not given but reports say that it could be an attempt to stop the interface from being exploited on platforms that Google has not made licensing agreements with.

column2: Augmented reality headset startup DAQRI to shut down: Report
column3: US-based augmented reality headset startup DAQRI has reportedly closed its headquarters, laid off several employees and is selling assets ahead of a shutdown. It emailed its customers saying it was closing its cloud and smart-glasses hardware platforms by September, TechCrunch reported. Co-founded in 2010 by Brian Mullins, Gaia Dempsey and Philip Tolk, DAQRI builds professional-grade AR products.

column2: Undefined LAC leading to border row with China: Ladakh MP
column3: India and China need to sit down and properly define the Line of Actual Control (LAC) to avoid border skirmishes, Ladakh MP Jamyang Tsering Namgyal said. "The actual line of control is not fixed and demarcated properly," he said. On the recent tensions at the Indo-China border, Namgyal said, "We should not worry too much about such developments."

column2: 82 ex-MPs still to vacate official bungalows despite warning
column3: Despite a warning by a Lok Sabha panel, 82 ex-MPs are yet to vacate their official bungalows in Lutyens' Delhi, sources said. On August 19, the Lok Sabha Housing Committee had ordered around 200 ex-MPs to give up the facility within a week. Former MPs had to vacate their bungalows within one month of dissolution of the previous Lok Sabha.

column2: Building of Ram temple in Ayodhya to start by Nov: Swamy
column3: The construction of the Ram temple in Ayodhya will commence by November, BJP leader Subramanian Swamy said. Swamy also said that the verdict of the Ram Janmabhoomi-Babri Masjid land case being heard in the Supreme Court will be in favour of the Ram temple. "The temple which is at the spot of Lord Ram's birthplace cannot be removed," he added.

column2: Super emergency in India: Mamata on International Day of Democracy
column3: On International Day of Democracy, West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee said that there is a state of 'Super Emergency' in the country. "Let us once again pledge to safeguard the constitutional values our country was founded on," she tweeted. "In this era of 'Super Emergency', we must do all it takes to protect the rights...that our Constitution guarantees," she added.

column2: Naomi Campbell hosts charity party at London Fashion Week
column3: Naomi Campbell on Saturday hosted Fashion For Relief charity party at the London Fashion Week. Naomi wore a shiny black ankle-length dress with black high heels and accessorised her look with a necklace and bracelet of the same colour. Pierce Brosnan, Maya Jama, Eve and Naomie Harris were other celebrities who attended Naomi's charity event in London.

column2: NCLT approves Monsanto India's merger with Bayer Crop Science
column3: The National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) approved the merger of Monsanto India with German-based Bayer AG's subsidiary Bayer Crop Science on September 13. In June 2018, Bayer announced completion of the $63 billion deal to acquire US-based Monsanto to create the world's biggest agro-chemical and seed company. Bayer took shareholders' approval for the merger in the first quarter of 2019-20.

column2: 5 dead, 40 missing after boat carrying tourists overturns in Godavari river
column3: At least five people were killed and 40 are missing when a boat carrying tourists overturned in Godavari river in Andhra Pradesh on Sunday. The boat was proceeding to Papi Hills when the incident took place. Two NDRF teams, each with 30 members, are on the spot for rescue and relief operations. Around 17 people swam to safety, officials said.

column2: Jharkhand to implement new traffic fines after 3 months
column3: Jharkhand government has announced the amended Motor Vehicles Act will be implemented in the state after three months, adding that old penalties would be applicable for traffic rule violations till December. The government asked officials to raise awareness on amended rules during this period. Facilitation centres will be opened in Jharkhand to enable people to get their documents in order.

column2: Chopra asks Paine to become MS Dhoni's student for failing to take DRS
column3: Ex-India cricketer Aakash Chopra trolled Australia captain Tim Paine after the latter said he'd go to umpiring school for getting DRS wrong in fifth Ashes Test. "Give a call to Dhoni. See if he's ready to take students...Dhoni Review System," Chopra tweeted. Paine didn't review not-out decisions against England's Joe Denly and Jos Buttler, who scored 94 and 47, respectively.

column2: Measuring error forces long delay in first Australia-West Indies WT20I
column3: The first T20I between Australia Women and West Indies Women was delayed after officials noticed the inner fielding circle was too big. The third official and venue's curator, who was carrying a measuring tape, were summoned onto the field. The inner circle was found to be 30 yards, while it should have been 25.15 yards as per women's T20I rules.

column2: Infosys opens Arizona Innovation Center, plans to hire 1,000 locals
column3: Infosys recently inaugurated its Technology and Innovation Center in Arizona for which it plans to hire 1,000 locals by 2023, the company said. The center focuses on autonomous technologies, Internet of Things, full-stack engineering, data science and cybersecurity. The company also announced that it has surpassed its Spring 2017 commitment to hire 10,000 American workers.

column2: Idea for Drivezy came after my new car's accident: Co-founder Ashwarya
column3: Vehicle leasing startup Drivezy's Co-founder Ashwarya Pratap Singh in an interview said the idea of the startup emerged after his new car met with an accident. "I barely used it...and I spent a good part of salary to maintain it," he said. "The accident made me realise that a lot of people might be facing the same conundrum," he added.

column2: 21 Indians killed in 2,050 ceasefire violations by Pak in 2019: MEA
column3: External Affairs Ministry spokesperson Raveesh Kumar on Sunday said that there had been more than 2,050 unprovoked ceasefire violations this year, in which 21 Indians were killed. He further said that India has repeatedly called upon Pakistan to ask its forces to adhere to 2003 ceasefire understanding and maintain peace and tranquility along the Line of Control (LoC).

column2: College said 'Wear long kurtis for good marriage proposals': Hyd student
column3: A student from Hyderabad's St Francis College for Women has shared videos showing guards stopping girls from entering the premises for wearing kurtis that were "an inch or less above the knee". She added that college authorities said "a long kurti would get [them] good marriage proposals". "We can't...watch their internalised patriarchy...dictate our beliefs," her Facebook post read.

column2: Pak will 'break into pieces' if it promotes terrorism: Rajnath
column3: Pakistan should stop promoting terrorism, otherwise no one will be able to prevent it from "breaking into pieces", Defence Minister Rajnath Singh has said. Singh also warned Pakistan that if its people cross the LoC, Indian Army will not allow them to return. "Pakistan PM Imran Khan has given good advice to his people to not cross LoC," he added.

column2: 2,600 vehicles fined for RFID tag violations on entering Delhi
column3: Over 2,600 commercial vehicles entering Delhi through 13 entry points without radio-frequency identification (RFID) tags or having insufficient recharge amount were penalised, officials said on Saturday. From Friday midnight only those commercial vehicles which have RFID tags are allowed to enter Delhi. Drivers or owners were charged twice the amount of toll and Environment Compensation Charge.

column2: 2 vets booked after Telangana CM's dog dies; may face up to 5-yr jail
column3: Two veterinary doctors of a private animal clinic have been booked after one of the nine pet dogs of Telangana Chief Minister K Chandrashekar Rao died last week. The police complaint accused them of negligence in the treatment of the 11-month-old Siberian Husky. If proven guilty, the doctors face a jail term for up to five years.

column2: Taliban revokes ban on Red Cross, provides security guarantees
column3: The Taliban revoked its ban on International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) in Afghanistan and gave a guarantee of security for its staff doing humanitarian work in areas under its control. Taliban imposed a ban on ICRC and WHO in April saying the organisations were carrying out "suspicious" activities during vaccination campaigns and not sticking to their declared missions.

column2: Saudi's full oil supply could take weeks to resume: Report
column3: Saudi Arabia's return to its full oil supply capacity after Saturday's attacks on Aramco oil plants could take "weeks not days", Reuters said on Sunday quoting a source. Drone attacks on two oil facilities owned by Saudi Arabia's state-owned oil giant Saudi Aramco knocked down more than half the kingdom's production. Yemen's Iran-aligned Houthi group claimed responsibility for the attacks.

column2: Aadhaar compulsory for new dealers from January 2020
column3: Verification of Aadhaar would be compulsory for new dealers from January 1, 2020. The verification of Aadhaar is currently optional for the dealers. "This will curb fake invoices that came to light after the new tax regime came into being from July 1, 2017," GST Network's group of ministers' Chairman Sushil Kumar Modi said.

column2: Main roles are reserved for star kids: Actress Aahana Kumra
column3: Actress Aahana Kumra, who starred in 'Lipstick Under My Burkha', said that the industry is dominated by star kids. "The main roles are reserved for them, whatever is left comes to us," she added. "The other lead roles are chickened out to actors who have...created a space for them in the industry," she further said.

column2: My kids will inherit both positives and negatives from us: Ajay
column3: Actor Ajay Devgn said that the constant spotlight on his kids, Nysa and Yug Devgn, bothers him and added, "But I think kids are also sensible that if they inherit so many positive things from their parents, there will be some negatives also." Talking about his stardom, Devgn said that both he and his wife Kajol don't care about it.

column2: Kim Kardashian walks on red carpet of Creative Arts Emmy Awards
column3: Kim Kardashian was among the celebrities who walked on the red carpet of the 2019 Creative Arts Emmy Awards. Kim wore a black velvet ankle-length gown which featured an asymmetrical sleeve that was wrapped around her neck and she pulled her hair back at the top of her head. Nicole Scherzinger, Lisa Kudrow and Angela Bassett also attended the event.

column2: Shahid has promised we'll renew our wedding vows: Mira
column3: In an interview with Vogue India, Mira Rajput revealed that her husband Shahid Kapoor has promised her that they will renew their wedding vows. Talking about her wedding, Mira added, "Anand Karaj ceremony was my favourite moment...[I]t was just a room full of our people, celebrating us, perfect strangers who were going to take this insane journey together."

column2: Amazon testing one-tap product feedback system
column3: Amazon is testing a new product feedback feature to make the process easier through a one-tap rating system. The one-tap rating lets users leave a star rating by tapping on any product without providing extra information, as done previously. It is accessible from a number of places, including the "Your Orders" page, on product pages, or through Amazon customer support.

column2: Government begins to digitally map country using drones
column3: The Survey of India (SoI) with support from Department of Science & Technology (DST) will be digitally mapping the length and breadth of the country over the next two years. The work has already begun in three states — Maharashtra, Karnataka and Haryana. The mapping would be drone-based, but this would be validated by ground-based information.

column2: Exam data to be recorded digitally in Delhi govt schools
column3: Delhi Deputy Chief Minister Manish Sisodia said that exam data in government schools will now be recorded digitally in order to reduce burden on teachers. "This step would be big relief to about 60,000 teachers," stated an official statement. Schools spend around 50 hours and class teachers around 310 hours every year for exam-related work, as per the statement.

column2: Enough jobs in India but job seekers aren't qualified: Union Minister
column3: Minister of State for Labour and Employment Santosh K Gangwar (Independent Charge) said that there are enough jobs in the country but job seekers are not qualified enough. "In North India, those who come to recruit, question the quality of people being hired," he added. He reportedly added that there is economic slowdown but no job scarcity.

column2: US lawmakers ask Boeing CEO for staff interviews on 737 MAX
column3: A US House of Representatives panel has asked Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg to make several employees available for interviews in the lawmakers' probe into the design, development and certification of Boeing 737 MAX aircraft. The 737 MAX was grounded worldwide in March after two crashes killed 346 people. Boeing has already provided over 3 lakh pages of documents, reports said.

column2: New Zealand man being fired takes emotional support clown to meeting
column3: A copywriter in New Zealand's Auckland being fired from work brought an emotional support clown to his redundancy meeting. The clown crafted balloon animals throughout the meeting, including a poodle, and also mimed crying when the paperwork was handed over. New Zealand legally requires employers to allow workers the option of bringing a support person to serious disciplinary meetings.

column2: She's elder to me, I'll always be her junior: Mondal on Lata's remark
column3: Ranu Mondal has reacted to Lata Mangeshkar's "imitation is not a reliable and durable companion for success" remark on her. "As far as age is concerned, I was younger to her and will always remain her junior. I have loved Lataji's voice since childhood," she said. Ranu had gone viral after a video of her singing Lata's song surfaced online.

column2: New iPhones may contain hardware to charge other wireless devices
column3: The 2019 lineup of iPhone may contain necessary hardware for enabling bilateral charging to let the phones wirelessly charge other Qi-compatible wireless devices, as per Australian iPhone information leaker Sonny Dickson. Apple might have reportedly kept the feature disabled within the phones' software. However, Dickson said he was "uncertain whether this was removed prior to final production".

column2: Sharif should be provided songs of Mukesh in jail: Pak Minister
column3: Pakistan's Railways Minister Sheikh Rashid has said that the government should provide a tape recorder and a collection of songs by Indian singer Mukesh to former PM Nawaz Sharif. Sharif is serving a seven-year prison term in Kot Lakhpat jail in Lahore. He has been serving the prison term since December 2018.

column2: K'taka college principal breaks phones seized from students with hammer
column3: RM Bhat, principal of Karnataka's MES Chaitanya PU College on Thursday smashed two of the seventeen mobile phones seized from students and warned them not to bring phones to the campus. The college had imposed a ban on phones on campus. "The remaining 15 phones have been kept in the college locker and...will be returned...after the annual exams," Bhat said.

column2: Indian, US soldiers dance on Assam Regiment's marching song
column3: A video showing Indian and US soldiers dancing on Assam Regiment's marching song 'Badluram Ka Badan Zameen Ke Neeche Hai' at a US Air Force base has surfaced online. The video has been shot during Exercise Yudh Abhyas 2019. The exercise, which began at the Joint Base Lewis-McChord in Washington on September 5, will continue till September 18.

column2: Pak singer who threatened PM Modi with snakes faces 2-year jail
column3: A Pakistani singer who threatened PM Narendra Modi with snakes and an alligator in a video faces two-year jail for violating the country's Wildlife Act, Pakistani Wildlife Protection officials said. The officials added that the Act prohibits turning such species into pets. "See what I've prepared for you...these friends of mine will feast on you," she said in the video.

column2: Hyderabad Police gives helmets instead of challans to traffic violators
column3: Instead of imposing fines for traffic violations, Rachakonda Police Commissionerate in Greater Hyderabad is facilitating violators to buy helmets or obtain necessary documents. Deputy Commissioner of Police (traffic) Divyacharan Rao launched the drive on Saturday. Telangana's Minister for Municipal Administration and Urban Development KT Rama Rao praised the police for the move.

column2: Law student alleges Chinmayanand filmed her during bath, raped her
column3: The Uttar Pradesh law student, who accused BJP leader Chinmayanand of rape, has given a pen drive containing 43 videos to a Special Investigation Team. The law student added Chinmayanand had shown her a video of her taking bath and then used it to blackmail, rape and exploit her. Earlier, the student claimed Chinmayanand sexually exploited her for a year.

column2: Pakistan could lose in a conventional war with India: PM Imran Khan
column3: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan has said that the country could lose in a conventional war with India. "God forbid if we are losing...I know Pakistanis will fight to the death for their freedom," he added. Khan further said, "So when a nuclear-armed country fights to the end, to the death, it has consequences."

column2: US blames Iran for drone attacks on Saudi oil facilities
column3: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has accused Iran of leading attacks on Saudi oil facilities that have cut the kingdom's output roughly in half. Yemen's Iran-aligned Houthi group has claimed responsibility for the attacks on the two facilities, including the world's biggest petroleum processing facility. The US State Department has declined to provide any evidence to support Pompeo's claim.

column2: Brazil hospital fire that killed 11 caused by explosion of generator
column3: Police officials have said that a blaze that killed 11 people in a hospital in Brazil's Rio de Janeiro was caused by explosion of a generator in the building's basement. The preliminary conclusion was reached Saturday despite difficulties accessing the basement of the hospital because of accumulated water and poor visibility. Police officials are still investigating why the generator exploded.

column2: Gitanjali Rao's 'Bombay Rose' to have India premiere at MAMI
column3: Filmmaker Gitanjali Rao's 'Bombay Rose' will have its India premiere at the Jio MAMI Mumbai Film Festival in the India Gold category. "It's... a fantastic festival... and for Bombay Rose to be part of it is an honour," she said. The film also became the first-ever Indian animated film to open the Venice International Film Critics' Week in August 2019.

column2: I was never under depression: Ayushmann on low phase in career
column3: Talking about the low phase in his career, Ayushmann Khurrana said that he always had a lot of options and due to which he was never under depression. Khurrana further said he immediately formed a band after 'Hawaizaada' and started gigging with them. "It... motivated me because it's like instant gratification for an artist when performing on stage," he added.

column2: It's bound to happen: Prabhas on facing prejudice in B'wood
column3: On being asked if Bollywood is prejudiced against other film industries, actor Prabhas said that prejudice has been there in every region as everyone is used to their actors. "Some have been around for 20-30 years. So, that's bound to happen," he added. He further said Bollywood is the biggest film industry and he's looking forward to work over there.

column2: Irrfan Khan hides his face as he returns to Mumbai after surgery
column3: Actor Irrfan Khan covered his face as paparazzi clicked him at Mumbai Airport when he returned to India after his successful surgery in London. "Irrfan had a successful surgery after wrapping 'Angrezi Medium' shoot in London," Irrfan's spokesperson said. Irrfan was diagnosed with Neuroendocrine Tumour and left for London for his treatment in March 2018.

column2: Criticism never made me feel bitter or hostile: Kangana
column3: Kangana Ranaut has said that one cannot ignore the importance of speaking against issues like nepotism, sexual abuse and pay disparity and that the criticism she has received never made her feel bitter or hostile. "Today, people openly talk about nepotism... But did anyone talk about it earlier? For me, what matters is the larger goal," she added.

column2: Tough time will pass: Nitin Gadkari on economic slowdown
column3: Talking about economic slowdown, Union Minister of Road Transport and Highways Nitin Gadkari on Saturday urged the industries not to lose heart and added that this time will pass. "I met automobile manufacturers....and all of them were little worried," said Gadkari. "I certainly feel that in coming days we're going to be the fastest growing economy," he further added.

column2: Tradition of Opposition chairing External Affairs panel ends: Tharoor
column3: After BJP MP PP Chaudhary replaced Congress' Shashi Tharoor as head of the panel on External Affairs, Tharoor said, "Govt has decided to end the tradition of the leading Opposition party...a BJP MP will now hold the BJP Govt accountable instead." Tharoor has now been appointed as Chairman of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Communications & Information Technology.

column2: India shares draft pact on Kartarpur Corridor with Pakistan
column3: India reportedly shared a draft agreement on the Kartarpur Corridor with Pakistan on Saturday. "It is hoped Pakistan will show the desired flexibility...to ensure that the corridor is opened in November on the occasion of the 550th birth anniversary of Guru Nanak," said an official. This comes after Pakistan said that it'll charge $20 as service fee from pilgrims.

column2: Afghanistan smash 7 sixes in a row against Zimbabwe in T20I
column3: Afghanistan smashed seven sixes off seven deliveries against Zimbabwe in the second match of the T20I tri-series. Afghanistan all-rounder Mohammad Nabi dispatched fast bowler Tendai Chatara's last four deliveries for maximums in the 17th over, while Najibullah Zadran followed it by slamming three sixes on the first three delivers of the 18th over bowled by fast bowler Neville Madziva.

column2: Why wasn't Bairstow penalised for fooling Smith with fake fielding?
column3: England wicketkeeper Jonny Bairstow faked collecting the ball which forced Steve Smith to dive in the 30th over of Australia's first innings in fifth Ashes Test. The umpires didn't penalise Bairstow under fake fielding rules as his action was considered to be done "out of jest" than out of "an attempt to cause confusion and prevent a run being scored".

column2: Days after retirement U-turn, Rayudu named captain of Hyderabad
column3: Days after his decision to come out of retirement from all forms of cricket, Ambati Rayudu was on Saturday appointed captain of Hyderabad for the upcoming Vijay Hazare Trophy. Hyderabad will kick off their season against Karnataka on September 24. Rayudu had announced his retirement after not being selected in India's World Cup squad.

column2: 3,400 illegal hoardings removed in a day in Chennai after techie's death
column3: Around 3,400 illegal hoardings have been taken down from various places in Chennai after the Greater Chennai Corporation announced formation of a special patrol to check illegal hoardings and flex banners. This comes two days after a 23-year-old techie lost her life after an illegal flex banner fell on her bike and made her lose control of the vehicle.

column2: Toll plaza employee collapses after man smashes tin drum on his head
column3: A security guard at a toll plaza near Haryana's Bahadurgarh was critically injured after a man smashed a broken tin drum on his head following an argument allegedly over toll amount on Saturday. The incident was captured by the CCTV, which showed the guard collapsing after being hit by the drum by a man in white shirt.

column2: Assange to stay in jail after sentence ends over absconding fears
column3: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange will remain in jail after his jail sentence ends over fears that he'd abscond, a judge has ruled. Assange was due to be released on September 22 after serving his sentence for skipping bail in 2012 and taking refuge in Ecuador's embassy in London. He's facing extradition to the US for allegedly leaking government secrets.

column2: How would Ola, Uber cause truck sales to fall: Yashwant Sinha
column3: Former Finance Minister Yashwant Sinha questioned Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman's claim that Ola and Uber caused a drop in passenger vehicle sales, asking why there's a slowdown in sales of two-wheelers and trucks. "People in the government are making weird statements. These statements will not lead to betterment of economy. But they'll definitely affect the government's image," he added.

column2: Will look at new deals in India once father demits office: Trump Jr
column3: Donald Trump Jr has said that Trump Organization will look at new branding and licensing deals in India once his father US President Donald Trump demits office. Trump Organization has so far signed partnerships with five Indian real estate companies to develop luxury apartments. Trump Jr further said the company will also look at expanding its hotel business to India.

column2: Saudi shuts down half its oil output after drone attacks: Reports
column3: Saudi Arabia has reportedly shut down half of its oil output following drone attacks on Aramco plants. Yemen's Iran-backed Houthi group said it deployed 10 drones in the attacks on two plants, including the world's biggest oil processing facility. The shutdown amounts to a loss of about 5 million barrels per day, about 5% of the world's daily oil production.

column2: Liverpool win 14th match in a row; set Premier League record
column3: Table-toppers Liverpool defeated Newcastle United 3-1 in the Premier League on Saturday, maintaining their 100% start to season. With this, Liverpool became the first team to win 14 consecutive PL games while scoring more than once in each victory. The match also witnessed Sadio Mane become the first PL player to play 50 home games for one club without defeat.

column2: USA exits Basketball World Cup with lowest-ever finish
column3: Defending champions USA finished seventh at the Basketball World Cup, their worst finishing place in the tournament's history. The team managed to win their final match of the tournament, avoiding a third straight loss in the 2019 edition. The final of the 2019 edition of the Basketball World Cup is set to take place on Sunday, between Argentina and Spain.

column2: Hazard makes La Liga debut as Real edge past Levante
column3: Eden Hazard made his La Liga debut as Real Madrid beat Levante 3-2 on Saturday. Karim Benzema scored twice for Real, while Casemiro was also on the scoresheet. The win takes Real to eight points in four matches in the La Liga so far. Real, who are placed second in the league, will face PSG in the Champions League next.

column2: US sanctions North Korean hackers for global cyberattacks
column3: The US has imposed sanctions on three North Korean hacking groups it blames for the "WannaCry" ransomware attacks among other cyberattacks to fund the country's missile program. Naming them Lazarus Group, Bluenoroff, and Andariel, it said they were controlled by North Korea's primary intelligence bureau which is already under US sanctions. The sanctions will freeze US-related assets of the groups.

column2: US lawmakers seek email records from Apple, FB, Amazon, Google
column3: A US House of Representatives panel has sought internal emails, financial statements and other records from the CEOs of Apple, Facebook, Amazon and Google in an antitrust probe. It asked the firms to share internal executive communications spanning a decade, related to their acquisitions and prior antitrust probes. The panel aims to see whether the four engaged in anti-competitive practices.

column2: Without RSS, there would have been no Hindustan: Rajasthan BJP
column3: Rajasthan BJP chief Satish Poonia on Saturday said that there would have been no Hindustan if not for the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS). Poonia was announced as the Rajasthan BJP chief earlier today by BJP General Secretary Arun Singh. "Because RSS is such a big force, 'Bhagwa' (saffron) is respected all over," he added.

column2: NeoGrowth raises $17 mn debt funding from France's Proparco
column3: Mumbai-based fintech startup NeoGrowth has raised $17 million through debt financing from the French Development Agency's private sector financing arm Proparco. Founded in 2012 by Dhruv Khaitan and Piyush Khaitan, NeoGrowth operates as a non-banking financial company and lends to small and medium enterprises in India. It had last raised around $47 million in equity funding in January 2018.

column2: Music publishers to double claims in lawsuit against Peloton
column3: Music publishers have asked a US court to double their claims in a lawsuit against exercise bike startup Peloton to $300 million from the earlier $150 million. The National Music Publishers' Association said Peloton streamed over 2,000 unlicensed songs in its workout videos. Discovering the misuse of even more songs, they requested the addition of 1,324 songs to their lawsuit.

column2: US-based startup LifeShip plans to send human DNA to Moon
column3: US-based startup LifeShip has said it is planning to send the DNA of humans to the Moon. The startup claimed it will collect saliva from people, extract their DNA, preserve it in an "artificial amber" and send it to the lunar surface. LifeShip said it will soon launch a Kickstarter campaign to sell DNA-collection kits for $99 for the purpose.

column2: President Kovind unveils Mahatma Gandhi’s statue in Switzerland
column3: President Ram Nath Kovind on Saturday unveiled the statue of Mahatma Gandhi in Switzerland's Villeneuve. "Today, we have brought (Mahatma Gandhi) to the banks of Lake Geneva...It's a fitting tribute to a man who loved nature and cared so much for it," he said. "His legacy shall inspire us as we work together to tackle climate change," the President added.

column2: Misbehaving police officers may face demotion: Odisha govt
column3: Under Odisha government's 'Mo Sarkar' initiative, police officials misbehaving with those coming to police stations or hospitals may face demotion. Odisha's CM Naveen Patnaik said if the officials in a police station don't listen to the complainants, they can go to the SP and DIG and lodge their complaint before them. The initiative will be launched on October 2.

column2: Medi-city to come up in Jammu and Srinagar: Satya Pal Malik
column3: Jammu and Kashmir Governor Satya Pal Malik on Saturday said Jammu and Srinagar will soon have a 'medi-city'. Malik also said that the land for the same has been finalised by the Central government. "A lot of best hospitals across the country are willing to invest. We will bring them here and operate the 'medi-city'," the Governor added.

column2: Death toll from fire at Brazil hospital rises to 11
column3: The death toll from a fire at a hospital in the Brazilian city of Rio de Janeiro has risen to 11. The hospital said there were 103 hospitalised patients at the time of the fire, with fire officials saying 90 of them were transferred to different hospitals. The fire was apparently caused by a short circuit in a generator.

column2: Ex-Zimbabwe President Mugabe's burial delayed by a month
column3: Former Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe's burial has been delayed by a month until his mausoleum can be built at the National Heroes Acre monument, his family said. More than 10 African leaders and several former presidents attended Mugabe's official funeral ceremony at the National Sports Stadium in Harare on Saturday. Mugabe died aged 95 in Singapore earlier this month.

column2: Osama bin Laden's son and al-Qaeda heir Hamza killed by US: Trump
column3: US President Donald Trump confirmed on Saturday that Hamza bin Laden, the son of al-Qaeda founder Osama bin Laden, was killed in a US counterterrorism operation in the Afghanistan/Pakistan region. Hamza was reportedly killed in an air strike. "He was very threatening to our country. He was saying very bad things about our country," Trump had earlier said about Hamza.

column2: Steve Smith literally cannot get out, it's weird: Jofra Archer
column3: Talking about Australia batsman Steve Smith, who set a world record by scoring his 10th straight 50-plus score against England, pacer Jofra Archer said, "It's weird. Every time he bats, he just, I don't know what it is, he literally cannot get out." "Especially if he plays a bad shot, the ball just lands in no man's land," he added.

column2: Politics does interest me, I want to be Mayor of London: Monty Panesar
column3: England spinner Monty Panesar has said politics interests him and he wants to be Mayor of London. "Maybe once Sadiq Khan is done, he'll pass the baton on to me for Mayor of London," he added. "We haven't decided the party I will join because I am still playing and hope to return to the Test team," he further said.

column2: Tuition teacher tells 13-yr-old he wants to have sex with her, held
column3: Mumbai Police have arrested a 42-year-old tuition teacher for allegedly telling a 13-year-old girl he wants to have sex with her after calling her inside his cabin. The girl narrated the incident to her mother, who took her to a police station to file a complaint. "We've learnt he used to pass comments on other students as well," police said.

column2: Former US priest jailed for 30 years for child sexual abuse
column3: Arthur Perrault, an 81-year-old former Roman Catholic priest, has been sentenced to 30 years in prison for sexually abusing an altar boy in New Mexico, US, in the 1990s, prosecutors said. Although he was convicted of abusing just one victim, prosecutors alleged that Perrault was a serial child molester who abused several young people for more than 30 years.

column2: Iran-backed Houthi rebels claim drone attacks on Saudi oil facilities
column3: Yemen's Iran-backed Houthi rebels claimed responsibility for the drone attacks on two Saudi oil facilities on Saturday. The rebels had deployed 10 drones against Saudi Aramco plants in Abqaiq and Khurais in eastern Saudi Arabia. The drone attacks sparked fires at both the facilities.

column2: Remains of 2,200 foetuses found at home of US abortion doctor
column3: The medically preserved remains of more than 2,200 foetuses were found in the US at the home of abortion doctor Ulrich Klopfer, just 9 days after his death. Authorities said that there was no evidence that any medical procedures were conducted at the doctor's property in Illinois. Klopfer's medical licence was indefinitely suspended in 2016 for violating various state laws.

column2: Ashton Kutcher allegedly cheated on Demi Moore with 2 women: Book
column3: In her upcoming memoir 'Inside Out', actress Demi Moore has reportedly accused ex-husband Ashton Kutcher for cheating on her with two women in a bathtub. Moore was pregnant and suffered a miscarriage when she was dating Kutcher, as per reports. She reportedly blamed herself for the miscarriage as she had started drinking again after being sober for a while.

column2: Tesla car to attempt breaking Porsche's electric record timing
column3: Tesla's Model S is set to appear at Germany's Nürburgring circuit after Porsche's new Taycan Turbo S set the record as the fastest four-door electric car last month at the same circuit. Former Formula One racing champion Nico Rosberg had replied to Elon Musk's declaration on Twitter that he would be willing to drive the Model S in Nürburgring.

column2: Smith has been the top scorer in all his 6 Ashes 2019 innings
column3: Steve Smith has been the highest scorer in all the six innings he has appeared to bat in the ongoing Ashes 2019 series. Smith is an innings behind former West Indies cricketer Shivnarine Chanderpaul, who was the top scorer in seven consecutive Test innings. Notably, Smith has also broken Don Bradman's record of most runs in 10 successive Ashes innings.

column2: We've come here to win and leave a mark: David Miller
column3: Speaking about the upcoming series against hosts India, South African batsman David Miller said, "We have a young squad and they are all looking ahead to the challenge... [W]e have come here to win and leave a mark." "So we are lucky that it's a new phase in South African cricket at the moment," Miller added.

column2: India defend lowest total in Youth ODIs to win 7th U-19 Asia Cup
column3: The Indian team successfully defended the total of 106 to beat Bangladesh by five runs to win their seventh Under-19 Asia Cup title. This is the lowest total successfully defended by any team in Youth ODI cricket. Notably, the Under-19 Asia Cup tournament's final in 2012 was a tie with India and Pakistan being declared the joint-champions.

column2: Excited to play under Virat bhaiya: Shubman Gill on Test call
column3: Batsman Shubman Gill, who earned his maiden Test call-up for South Africa series, said he is "excited to play under Virat bhaiya" and tries to follow Kohli's work ethics. The 20-year-old further said, "Yuvi paa (Yuvraj Singh) is my inspiration. His journey...is so inspirational." Gill has an average of 72.15 in first-class cricket and recently captained India A side.

column2: Microsoft considers foldable devices with fluid-filled hinges
column3: Microsoft may develop a clamshell-like device having a foldable display with a liquid or gas-filled hinge, a patent filed by the tech giant revealed. The hinge, which may be used in a Surface device, would reduce strain on the screen along the folding edge and prevent debris from entering. The patent showed "semi-viscous" liquid "slowly moving" within the hinge's cavity.

column2: YouTube to stop counting views from ads for its Music Charts
column3: YouTube has announced it will no longer count "paid advertising views" while ranking artists on its 'Music Charts' and determining videos eligible for a 24-hour record debut. It said that to improve transparency, the artists will now be ranked based on views from organic plays on YouTube. These include direct video links, search results, embeds, YouTube homepage and Trending section.

column2: India's unity threatened by your ideology: Cong to Amit Shah
column3: After Home Minister Amit Shah on Saturday tweeted that Hindi can play a key role in 'uniting the country', Congress said that it is mindset like Shah's that threaten the country's unity. "Linguistic diversity has been the greatest strength of our great country," Congress added. "India's unity is threatened by your ideology and not by languages," the party further said.

column2: I did more work than an elected govt: J&K Guv Satya Pal Malik
column3: J&K Governor Satya Pal Malik on Saturday said that he has managed to change people's perception towards Governor's post and has worked more than an elected government. People think Governors play golf and do nothing, he said. "But the...work that we've done in past one year, I don't think even an elected government does that much work," Malik added.

column2: Finance Minister's comments on inflation were shocking: Cong
column3: After Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman's press conference on Saturday about the current economic situation among other issues, Congress termed her comments on inflation as shocking. "She said inflation is under control...She didn't announce any measures to address the current economic situation," Congress leader Anand Sharma said. "BJP...lacks the vision to revive the economy," Sharma added.

column2: Autonomous vehicle startup Voyage raises $31 million
column3: Silicon Valley's autonomous vehicle startup Voyage has raised $31 million in a Series B round led by investment management firm Franklin Templeton. Jaguar Land Rover's InMotion Ventures, Chevron Technology Ventures and Khosla Ventures also took part in the round. Co-founded in 2017 by Oliver Cameron and MacCallister Higgins, the startup operates self-driving cab services in retirement communities.

column2: Iran signs $440mn deal to develop gas field in Gulf amid US sanctions
column3: Iran has signed a $440-million deal with the local company Petropars to develop the Belal gas field in the Gulf amid the US sanctions on import of Iranian oil. "This is a sign that we are still functioning with sanctions at their peak...We are alive, we are active and working for Iran's oil industry," Oil Minister Bijan Zanganeh said.

column2: Lawyer claims he has been eating glass for fun for 45 years, video viral
column3: A video of a lawyer from Madhya Pradesh eating glass has gone viral on social media. The lawyer has claimed that he has been eating glass for fun for the last 40-45 years. "It is an addiction for me. This habit has caused damage to my teeth. I wouldn't suggest others to follow as it’s dangerous for health," he said.

column2: Two nights before giving birth, I was playing tennis: Sania Mirza
column3: Indian tennis player Sania Mirza has revealed that two nights before giving birth to her son Izhaan, she was playing tennis. "I was like I need this baby to come out. So I was just like...let me play tennis, maybe there's something going to happen," she added. "Well...nothing happened. It was all mental but I felt better," she further said.

column2: Lesson for me: Kohli on his pic that sparked Dhoni's retirement rumours
column3: Virat Kohli has clarified the reason behind him posting a throwback picture that sparked MS Dhoni's retirement rumours. "I didn't have anything on my mind. I was just sitting at my home and uploaded the picture. It became news. It's a lesson for me that what I think about myself, the world doesn't necessarily see it that way," he said.

column2: Using drones to study Amazon rainforest's health: Harvard team
column3: Harvard University researchers are using specifically-engineered drones to monitor the effects of climate change on the Amazon rainforest's health. Researchers aim to monitor unique chemical signatures emitted by plants species, which change if they are under stress, in varied ecosystems. They began work in 2017 with Amazonas State University and the Amazonas State Research Support Foundation.

column2: Can't destroy greatness: Priyanka after Gandhi ji's statue vandalised
column3: A Mahatma Gandhi statue was vandalised by unidentified miscreants at a college in Uttar Pradesh's Jalaun. Reacting to this, Congress leader Priyanka Gandhi Vadra said, "You cannot move even a fraction of greatness of these great men by attacking their statues." "This is the achievement of cowards in their life, who break the statues of great people," she added.

column2: Amit Shah sweeps AIIMS floor as part of campaign for PM's b'day week
column3: BJP President Amit Shah with working President JP Nadda swept the floor at AIIMS as part of the party's 'Seva Saptah' campaign launched to celebrate PM Narendra Modi's birthday, which is on September 17. Party leaders Vijay Goel and Vijender Gupta were also seen sweeping the floor. The leaders also visited the patients admitted in the hospital.

column2: NCP MP Udayanraje joins BJP in Maharashtra, says 'inspired by PM'
column3: Senior NCP leader Udayanraje Bhonsle on Saturday resigned as Lok Sabha MP and joined BJP in the presence of party President Amit Shah and Maharashtra CM Devendra Fadnavis. "I'm inspired by the works and leadership of PM (Narendra) Modi, Amit Shah and BJP," Bhonsle said. The move comes ahead of Maharashtra Assembly elections scheduled to take place in October.

column2: Hindi can unite the country today: Amit Shah on Hindi Diwas
column3: On the occasion of Hindi Diwas, Union Home Minister Amit Shah said that if there's one language which can unite the country, it's the most widely spoken Hindi language. "It's necessary to have a common language that becomes the mark of India's identity globally," he added. Shah also appealed to the people to promote both their mother tongues and Hindi.

column2: 5 of family killed as their car overturns, explodes on Andhra highway
column3: Five members of a family, including three children, were burnt alive after their car overturned on a highway and caught fire in Andhra Pradesh's Chittoor on Saturday. Meanwhile, the owner of the car was critically injured in the incident and was rescued by locals who noticed the accident. The police have launched an investigation into the incident.

column2: India to organise Dubai-like mega shopping festival in 4 places
column3: Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Saturday announced that India will organise an annual mega shopping festival in four places across the country in March 2020 to promote exports. The shopping festival will be on the lines of Dubai Shopping Festival, she added. It will focus on four themes — gems and jewellery, handicraft/yoga/tourism, textiles, and leather.

column2: Man, who died 8yrs ago, gets notice for not wearing seat belt in 2019
column3: The transport department in Rajasthan's Jhalawar district has allegedly issued a notice to cancel the driving licence of a man, who died eight years ago, for driving at high speed and without wearing a seat belt last month. The man's son said his father, who was a utensil seller, never owned a four-wheeler and his licence was valid till 2014.

column2: Ex-Kolkata police chief ignores CBI summon, switches off phone
column3: Former Kolkata Police Commissioner Rajeev Kumar on Saturday failed to appear before CBI despite being summoned in connection with Saradha chit fund scam. The agency's officers said that Kumar's phone was also switched off. Calcutta High Court on Friday withdrew Kumar's protection from arrest, following which CBI officials visited his official residence but did not find him there.

column2: US baby born on 9/11 anniversary at 9:11 pm weighs 9lb 11oz
column3: A US mother says her newborn daughter is a "little miracle" after she was born on the anniversary of the 9/11 attacks at 9:11 pm weighing 9lb 11oz. "She is a new life amongst the devastation and destruction," her mother added. "It was really exciting, especially to find some joy during a day of such tragedy," her father said.

column2: 16-year-old climate activist protests outside White House
column3: Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg on Friday protested outside the White House. The 16-year-old was greeted by hundreds of mostly young people carrying signs reading 'People or Profit?' and 'Warming!', and chanting 'This is a crisis, act like it!'. Notably, US President Donald Trump is among the few global leaders who have openly questioned the science of climate change.

column2: Brexit referendum result left me depressed: Former UK PM Cameron
column3: Former UK Prime Minister David Cameron has said the Brexit referendum result in 2016 had left him "hugely depressed". Cameron had called for the referendum after promising it in the Conservative Party's election manifesto in 2015 but had himself campaigned to remain in the European Union. Cameron had announced his decision to resign as PM after the result was announced.

column2: Afghan Taliban sends team to Russia after US talks collapse
column3: The Taliban has sent a delegation to Russia to discuss prospects for a withdrawal of US troops from Afghanistan following collapse of talks with the US this month. Taliban said US President Donald Trump's decision to call off the peace process came at a time when both sides had resolved all outstanding issues and were about to sign an agreement.

column2: Top trader body seeks ban on Amazon, Flipkart's festive season sales
column3: The Confederation of All India Traders (CAIT) has asked the government to ban upcoming festive sales on Amazon and Flipkart, saying their deep discounts violate FDI rules. It also demanded a "blanket ban" on such sales and asked the government to probe the potential violation of FDI norms. Both Amazon and Flipkart said sellers decide the pricing for their products.

column2: I will never do something regressive: Ayushmann Khurrana
column3: Actor Ayushmann Khurrana said that "being part of progressive cinema", he'll never do something regressive. "I'll never do something which is...outdated as far as message is concerned," Ayushmann added. Talking about his latest release 'Dream Girl', he said, "The way the songs are placed in the film is also like the nineties...[It] still gives a message in the end."

column2: YouTuber PewDiePie cancels $50,000 pledge to anti-hate group
column3: YouTuber Felix Kjellberg, known as 'PewDiePie', has pulled back his $50,000 pledge to Anti-Defamation League (ADL), a group that campaigns against anti-Semitism. This follows fans claiming PewDiePie was pressured to make the donation. "I made the mistake of picking a charity I was advised to, instead of picking [one] I'm personally passionate about, which is 100% my fault," Kjellberg said.

column2: We should respect all languages equally: Mamata Banerjee
column3: West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee on Saturday wished people on Hindi Diwas and said everybody should respect all languages and cultures equally. Her statement came after Home Minister Amit Shah said Hindi which is spoken the most can unite the country. "We may learn many languages but should never forget our mother-language," she tweeted.

column2: It is India not Hindiya: DMK over Shah's Hindi Diwas tweet
column3: DMK President MK Stalin on Saturday criticised Home Minister Amit Shah's tweet on Hindi Diwas and asked him to withdraw his statement. Earlier today, Shah tweeted that Hindi can play a key role in 'uniting the country' and urged people to use it more. "Unity in diversity is the foundation of this country...this is India, not Hindiya," Stalin said.

column2: GrabOnRent settles with GrabOn over trademark infringement
column3: Bengaluru-based products rental startup GrabOnRent has agreed to settle with coupons retailer GrabOn over trademark infringement allegations. GrabOnRent agreed that it and its vendors will not sell, advertise and deal in goods or services under "GrabOnRent", "GrabOn" or similar trademarks within a specified timeframe. The case was settled before Delhi High Court Mediation and Conciliation Centre.

column2: Never felt beautiful, makeup gave me wings to fly: Lady Gaga
column3: Lady Gaga, who will soon launch her new makeup line Haus Laboratories, said in an interview that putting on makeup gives her wings to fly. "I never felt beautiful and have days when I still don't. Then I put makeup...I feel this superhero within," she said. She revealed how her makeup artist would put on her makeup whenever she cried.

column2: Priyanka turns showstopper at The Sky Is Pink world premiere
column3: Priyanka Chopra turned showstopper at the 'The Sky Is Pink' world premiere at the Toronto International Film Festival. Priyanka wore a strapless black and white ruffled gown by Marchesa from their Fall 2019 collection. Her co-star Farhan Akhtar and his girlfriend Shibani Dandekar also attended the event. Priyanka is one of the producers of 'The Sky Is Pink'.

column2: JK Rowling donates $18.8M to research centre named after her mother
column3: Harry Potter author JK Rowling has donated $18.8 million towards multiple sclerosis research at a centre named after her late mother, Anne Volant Rowling, who died of the disease. The donation will be used for new facilities at the Anne Rowling Clinic in Scotland's University of Edinburgh. The clinic was started after a $12.5-million donation by Rowling in 2010.

column2: If Pak doesn't want war, it should hand over PoK to us: Union Minister
column3: Union Minister Ramdas Athawale has said, "If [Pakistan doesn't] want a war and Imran Khan thinks of Pakistan's interest, then he should hand over PoK (Pakistan-occupied Kashmir) to us." "If they hand over PoK to us, we will set up many industries there. We will also help Pakistan in trade and help fight poverty and unemployment," he added.

column2: Facebook not complying with Indian law: TN govt tells SC
column3: The Tamil Nadu government on Thursday claimed in the Supreme Court that Facebook, alongside other social media companies, isn't complying with the Indian law. It claimed that this is resulting in "increased lawlessness" and difficulties in "detecting crimes". The Madras High Court was earlier restrained by the SC from passing any effective orders over linking Aadhaar to social media accounts.

column2: Disney CEO resigns from Apple board ahead of Apple TV+ launch
column3: Walt Disney CEO Bob Iger resigned from Apple's board of directors on September 10, regulatory filings revealed. This comes ahead of the launch of Apple's recently unveiled video streaming subscription service Apple TV+, which stands as a direct rival to the entertainment conglomerate's own service, Disney+. Iger became an Apple director shortly after Apple Co-founder Steve Jobs' death in 2011.

column2: Leader dresses up as groom, workers as 'baraatis' to meet Akhilesh
column3: Samajwadi Party (SP) leader Firoz Khan dressed up as a groom and was accompanied by party workers pretending to be 'baraatis' to meet former Uttar Pradesh CM and party President Akhilesh Yadav in Rampur. Some SP leaders have alleged that they are being prevented from meeting Akhilesh or going to Rampur, while the district administration denied putting such restrictions.

column2: Human corpses move significantly for over a year after death: Study
column3: A recently published study, where movements of a human corpse were studied and photographed over 17 months, claimed that the body moves significantly for over a year after death. In one case study, arms initially close to body ended up flung out to the side. The lead researcher attributed this to decomposition as the body "mummifies" and "ligaments dry out".

column2: Burj Khalifa-sized asteroid among 2 to pass by Earth soon: NASA
column3: Two medium-sized near-Earth objects (NEOs), including one asteroid nearly as long as Earth's tallest building Burj Khalifa, are set to safely fly by Earth, NASA said. The two bodies will pass by on September 14 and 15, as per Indian time. NASA added it's tracking the objects but orbit calculations ruled out any chance that they could pose a threat.

column2: I expected the world to react more on Kashmir: Pak PM Imran Khan
column3: Pakistan PM Imran Khan has said, "Sadly, I...expected the world to react much more than it has on the Kashmir issue." "Kashmir is no longer a disputed territory as far as India is concerned. They have made it a part of India," he added. Earlier, Pakistan Interior Minister Ijaz Ahmad Shah said the international community believes India and not us.

column2: Pak shows white flag to get bodies of soldiers killed by Indian Army
column3: A video showing Pakistan Army raising white flag to retrieve the bodies of two of its soldiers killed by the Indian Army along the LoC has surfaced online. The Indian Army killed the two soldiers in retaliation to unprovoked ceasefire violation by Pakistan. The Indian Army reportedly said it allowed Pakistan to retrieve the bodies as it respects the dead.

column2: AIADMK leader booked for erecting hoarding that led to woman's death
column3: AIADMK leader S Jayagopal has been booked for erecting illegal hoardings for his son's wedding that led to the death of 23-year-old woman in Tamil Nadu's Chennai. Meanwhile, Madras High Court had also criticised the leader, asking, "Couldn't that politician have conducted the family marriage without flex boards?" Deputy CM O Panneerselvam also attended the wedding.

column2: Trump says energy-efficient light bulbs make him look orange
column3: During his speech to House Republicans in Baltimore, US President Donald Trump claimed that energy-efficient light bulbs, which his administration has tried to block, make him look orange. He described energy-efficient light bulbs as "many times more expensive than that old, incandescent bulb that worked very well", adding that energy-efficient light bulbs' "light's no good".

column2: Fires at Saudi Aramco oil facilities after drone attacks
column3: Drone attacks on two oil facilities owned by Saudi Arabia's state-owned oil giant Saudi Aramco in Abqaiq and Khurais provinces on Saturday caused fires, a Saudi interior ministry spokesman said without identifying the source of the drones. A Saudi-led military coalition has been battling Yemen's Houthis rebels since March 2015, and the latter have launched similar attacks in the past.

column2: Actress Felicity Huffman gets 14 days in prison for college scandal
column3: Emmy and Golden Globe Award winner Felicity Huffman has been sentenced to 14 days in prison for rigging her daughter's entrance exam scores for US college admissions. The 'Desperate Housewives' actress had paid $15,000 to improve her daughter's SAT score in 2017. Felicity has also been charged with an year of probation, $30,000 fine and 250 hours of community service.

column2: My father doesn't give my number to anyone: Sonam on nepotism
column3: When Dulquer Salmaan said that his father doesn't entertain calls related to work for his son, his 'The Zoya Factor' co-star Sonam Kapoor revealed that her father Anil Kapoor doesn't even give her number to anyone. Talking about nepotism, Sonam added, "Any smart person or someone with wisdom should get online and look for its [nepotism] meaning."

column2: Dharmendra breaks down on the sets of Superstar Singer
column3: On the sets of the reality show 'Superstar Singer', actor Dharmendra couldn't control his tears when he watched a video of his journey from Punjab to Bollywood. "Rula diya yaar, tumne mujhe rula diya. Yahi mai khwab dekhta tha yahan aane ke," Dharmendra said. "Us pul...se kehta hu ki Dharmendra tu actor ban gaya yaar," he added.

column2: BJP MPs replace Congress leaders as heads of parliamentary panels
column3: BJP MPs on Friday replaced Congress leaders in two crucial parliamentary panels- the standing committees on finance and external affairs. BJP MP Jayant Sinha has replaced Congress' Veerappa Moily and PP Chaudhary has replaced Shashi Tharoor as heads of the panels on finance and external affairs respectively. Tharoor will now head the Standing Committee on Information Technology.

column2: Tripura CM to donate salary for installing dustbins in rural areas
column3: Tripura CM Biplab Kumar Deb will donate his six months' salary to install dustbins in 1,100 panchayats and village committees of the state as part of BJP's 'Seva Saptah' campaign. "We are committed to making Tripura garbage-free," he said. BJP will observe 'Seva Saptah' from September 14 to mark the birthday of Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

column2: Breaking Bad's 'Walter White' lookalike wanted in meth possession case
column3: Police in US' Illinois are hunting for a man resembling Bryan Cranston's Breaking Bad character 'Walter White' in a meth possession case. A mugshot of 50-year-old Todd Barrick has gone viral after the Galesburg Police Department released the photo on Facebook. "Please check the nearest car wash or storage centre," a Breaking Bad fan commented on the picture.

column2: Zomato to launch original food-centric video streaming service
column3: Food delivery giant Zomato has announced a foray into video streaming with "Zomato Originals" and will launch 18 original food-centric shows over the next three months, starting September 16. The shows will be available under a new "Videos" tab in the Zomato app. Videos will have a 3-15 minute duration and mainly revolve around recipes and 'Sneak Peek' restaurant stories.

column2: People stared at me when I told my name: MK Stalin on 1989 Russia trip
column3: Speaking about his visit to Russia in 1989, M Karunanidhi's son and DMK President MK Stalin said, "At a Russian airport, I was asked to mention my name. When I said 'Stalin' many people...started looking at me." He stated that officials asked him several questions while checking his passport, adding, "Many people in Russia didn't like Joseph Stalin."

column2: Contact with Vikram lander looks less & less probable: ISRO official
column3: An ISRO official has said that establishing contact with Chandrayaan-2's Vikram lander looks "less and less probable". "With every passing minute, the situation becomes worse only," the official added. Another ISRO official said that hard-landing of Vikram lander has made the task of establishing contact with it much difficult as it may not have the "right orientation to receive signals".

column2: UP CM, ministers to pay own taxes as state ends 38-yr-old practice
column3: The Uttar Pradesh government on Friday decided that the Chief Minister and other state ministers will pay their own income taxes, ending the around 38-year-old practice of state government doing so. "The decision has been taken on the directives of CM Yogi Adityanath," Finance Minister Suresh Kumar Khanna said. The direction comes after the law was criticised in the media.

column2: 68-yr-old man fakes name, passport to impersonate 89-yr-old; arrested
column3: A 68-year-old Punjab man impersonating an 89-year-old was caught by the immigration authorities at Delhi airport after he landed from Hong Kong with a fake passport. Gurdip Singh had used the fake passport and a fake name (Karnail Singh) to get permanent residence ID of Hong Kong, police said. He had been travelling abroad with fake passport for 11 years.

column2: Ex-IAS officer BN Yugandhar, father of Microsoft CEO, passes away at 80
column3: Microsoft Chief Executive Officer Satya Nadella's father and former IAS officer BN Yugandhar passed away aged 80 in Hyderabad on Friday after a brief illness. Yugandhar was an IAS officer of 1962 batch and had served as Planning Commission member during Manmohan Singh's tenure as PM. He had also served as director of Lal Bahadur Shastri National Academy of Administration.

column2: Pak delegation skips SCO conference in Delhi, attends only dinner
column3: A Pakistani delegation skipped the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) military medicine conference organised in Delhi on Thursday and only attended the dinner later that evening. The inaugural session of the two-day conference was addressed by Defence Minister Rajnath Singh. The conference was attended by around 27 international and 40 Indian delegates.

column2: Tiananmen Square 'Tank Man' photographer Charlie Cole passes away
column3: Charlie Cole, one of the four photographers who captured the 'Tank Man' protester at China's Tiananmen Square in 1989, passed away at the age of 64 in Bali last week. Cole won the World Press Photo award for his picture in 1990. Cole had hidden the undeveloped film roll in the bathroom, fearing he would be searched by Chinese authorities.

column2: China tells state firms to take control of Hong Kong firms: Reports
column3: China has called on its biggest state-run firms to take control of Hong Kong companies instead of just holding stakes in them, Reuters reported. China urged representatives from nearly 100 of China's largest state-run companies to help calm the unrest in Hong Kong. The companies reportedly pledged to invest more in key Hong Kong industries, including real estate and tourism.

column2: Not scared of making mistake: Goyal on crediting Einstein for gravity
column3: Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal has acknowledged that he made a mistake by crediting the discovery of gravity to Albert Einstein instead of Isaac Newton. "Mistakes are made by everybody and I'm not one of them who is scared of making a mistake," he said. "Einstein has said, 'A person who never made a mistake never tried anything new'," Goyal added.

column2: Dream of seeing Real Madrid in the NBA: Real Madrid president
column3: Real Madrid president Florentino Perez has said that he dreams of seeing Real Madrid's basketball team play in the NBA. "I have asked us to be included in the Eastern Conference, but they say that's far away... [T]here are Greek and Turkish clubs with which we could have a European Conference," Perez added about the creation of NBA's European division.

column2: Playing Federer or Nadal will be psychologically challenging: Murray
column3: Former world number one Andy Murray has said he needs four or five months to play top-level tennis and taking on Roger Federer or Rafael Nadal would probably be "psychologically challenging". "I need to be patient and not expect too much too soon," he added. The 32-year-old is regaining his fitness after a hip resurfacing procedure in January.

column2: Google Search results to give prominence to original reporting
column3: Google has announced it will give better recognition to original news reporting by displaying it prominently in 'Search' results and ensuring it stays there longer. With the updated Search algorithm, readers interested in a piece of news can find where it was originally reported. Google said the move would benefit publishers by expanding the readership of their original news stories.

column2: Google agrees to pay nearly €1 bn to settle French tax probe
column3: Google has agreed to pay €965 million to settle a tax dispute with France. The settlement, ending a four-year-old financial fraud investigation by authorities into Google's tax affairs and activities in France, comprises a €500-million fine and €465-million additional taxes. In July, France approved a 3% digital tax on about 30 tech giants with over €750 million revenue including Google.

column2: WeWork cuts CEO Adam Neumann's voting power amid IPO plans
column3: Co-working space startup WeWork's owner The We Company has cut the voting power of Co-founder and CEO Adam Neumann to reportedly revive demand for its planned IPO. The startup, seeking a valuation of less than half from before, said the changes were "in response to market feedback". It decreased Neumann's superior voting shares to 10 votes per share from 20.

column2: Govt may cap Ola, Uber surge price at thrice the base fare
column3: The government will likely cap the surge price charged by cab aggregators like Ola and Uber at three times the base price during peak hours, reports said. The upcoming regulations for ride-hailing platforms will also address passenger safety issues and types of vehicles allowed. This follows the new motor vehicle law recognising cab aggregators as marketplaces for the first time.

column2: Fintech startup Lendingkart's COO Mukul Sachan resigns
column3: The COO of Ahmedabad-based Lendingkart, Mukul Sachan, has quit the fintech startup. Sachan, who had co-founded Lendingkart along with Harshvardhan Lunia in 2014, will continue as a mentor and a consultant for the digital lending startup and may reportedly start a new venture. An IIM graduate, Sachan earlier worked as a scientist at the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO).

column2: Environmental pollution in China in decline: Study
column3: According to a new international research study, environmental pollution in China as a whole has begun to decline. The study also shows that China has improved in 12 of the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) during the last 40 years.
