Researchers studied statistics for economic growth, environmental conditions, regional differences, and social inequality, among other factors.

column2: Left activists, police clash in WB during protest over unemployment
column3: Clashes broke out in West Bengal's Howrah on Friday between the police and the Left activists, who were demanding employment for the youth. Several people on the two sides suffered injuries in the clash, a police officer said. The police also used water cannons to disperse the activists, who reportedly pelted stones at them.

column2: Gurugram couple stabbed to death before their 7-year-old son
column3: A couple was stabbed to death on Thursday in Gurugram in front of their seven-year-old son. The couple, identified as Vikram Singh and Jyoti, was allegedly stabbed by their friend Abhinav who has been arrested by the police. Abhinav stabbed the couple after an argument over money that he lent to Vikram for getting him a job abroad, police said.

column2: Used hairdresser's hand in magazine as I had short nails: Neetu on old pic
column3: Actress Neetu Kapoor on Friday shared the picture of an old magazine cover featuring her. She captioned the post, "#funfact Rakesh Shrestha ace photographer (Rohan Shrestha's dad) had a cover concept...face with red lipstick and red nails!!!" "Since my nails were short we used my hairdresser's hand...the hand posture looks so weird," Neetu further revealed.

column2: Smith registers 10th straight 50+ score vs England, breaks world record
column3: Australia batsman Steve Smith slammed his 10th straight 50-plus score against England in Test cricket on Friday, breaking the world record for scoring the most 50-plus scores in a row against a single nation. The previous record was set by Inzamam-ul-Haq, who hit nine consecutive 50-plus scores against England from 2001 to 2006.

column2: Co-pilot left plane's cockpit after panic attack, captain landed it himself
column3: An EasyJet co-pilot suffered a mid-air panic attack and left the cockpit of a plane, carrying 148 passengers, which was approaching Glasgow International Airport, an Air Accidents Investigation Branch report said. The captain landed the plane on his own after the co-pilot became incapacitated. His anxiety was triggered by a go-around the day before at 30 feet, the report added.

column2: First-ever arrested landing of naval Tejas successfully executed in Goa
column3: The first-ever arrested landing of Light Combat Aircraft (LCA) Tejas (Navy) was successfully executed by Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO) and Aeronautical Development Agency (ADA) at INS Hansa, a shore-based facility in Goa. After a series of successful trials on the shore based facility, the LCA will attempt landing on the deck of carrier INS Vikramaditya.

column2: Is Centre contemplating rules on social media-Aadhaar linkage: SC
column3: The Supreme Court today sought a response from Centre on whether it is contemplating formulation of any guidelines regarding linking of social media with Aadhaar. The division bench of justices Deepak Gupta and Aniruddha Bose sought Centre's response by September 24. Several petitions are pending before various high courts seeking direction for interlinking of Aadhaar with social media accounts.

column2: 4 Indian men drown in manure tank at farm in Italy
column3: Four men from Punjab, aged between 28 and 48, drowned in a manure tank on a dairy farm in Italy. Investigators believe that three men died after jumping in to rescue a worker who had been emptying the tank. The farm, located about 45 km from the city of Milan, was owned by two of the deceased, who were brothers.

column2: Melania criticised over coat showing plane flying into tower on 9/11
column3: US First Lady Melania Trump was criticised over a coat she wore in a 9/11 tribute image, with social media users claiming the stitching on it apparently resembled a plane flying into a tower. The image was shared by US President Donald Trump on Twitter, with the caption, "We will never forget 9.11.01." The White House called the criticism "ridiculous".

column2: 8 Indian-Americans held for distributing millions of opioid pills
column3: Eight Indian-Americans were arrested for their alleged involvement in the distribution of millions of opioid pills smuggled from India. The accused allegedly operated out of a warehouse in New York, where they repackaged the pills and mailed them to customers. If convicted, seven of the accused may face up to five-year jail, while the eighth accused may face 25-year imprisonment.

column2: Bangladesh removes Pakistan's name from all border pillars
column3: Border Guard Bangladesh has removed Pakistan's name from all the border pillars installed along its border with India. Bangladesh took the step to remove the border pillars, which were installed after the Partition in 1947, for the first time since its independence in 1971. The pillars were erected in several border areas, including Naogaon, Sylhet and Chittagong.

column2: London Stock Exchange rejects Hong Kong Exchanges' $39 bn takeover bid
column3: London Stock Exchange (LSE) board has unanimously rejected Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing's $39 billion takeover offer. The 300-year-old British bourse said it remains committed to its proposed acquisition of financial information provider Refinitiv. Hong Kong Exchanges said its takeover would only happen if the LSE ended its deal with Refinitiv.

column2: Delhi Police investigates Budweiser owner in tax evasion case
column3: Delhi Police is investigating a case of alleged tax evasion involving Budweiser owner AB InBev after receiving a request from the Delhi government. Local authorities barred AB InBev in July from selling its beer in Delhi for three years over alleged tax evasion. Delhi Police said it would conduct its own probe before registering a formal case.

column2: Worked my arse off, didn't eat many roasts at home: Mitchell Marsh
column3: Australia's Mitchell Marsh, who took a five-for in fifth Ashes Test, said he made a lot of lifestyle changes to perform better. "I eat a lot...My mum likes to feed me...I haven't had as many roasts at home in last six months," said Marsh, who's playing a Test after eight months. "I...worked my arse off...to get another opportunity," he added.

column2: Porn company bids $10 mn for Miami Heat stadium naming rights
column3: Internet porn company Bang Bros has revealed that they have made a $10 million bid for the naming rights for the Miami Heat home stadium. The move has come after American Airlines stated they won't renew their naming rights deal. The company has stated they intend to change the stadium's name from 'American Airlines Arena' to the 'BangBros Center'.

column2: France to block Facebook's Libra cryptocurrency in Europe
column3: France has said that it will block the development of Facebook's cryptocurrency Libra in Europe. French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire said, "All these concerns around Libra are serious," citing threat to the "monetary sovereignty" of European countries and the risk of abuse of dominant position. This follows reports claiming that Facebook was under a Libra-related EU antitrust investigation.

column2: Huawei offers to license 5G technologies to Western firms
column3: China's Huawei has offered to share its 5G technologies with Western firms to ease the security concerns raised by the US. CEO Ren Zhengfei said Huawei would give companies "perpetual access" to its existing 5G patents, codes and technical blueprints for a one-time fee. This would create more 5G players and a balance between China and the West, Zhengfei added.

column2: Fashion e-tail startup StalkBuyLove faces cash crunch
column3: Fashion e-tailing startup StalkBuyLove has reportedly been facing a cash crunch for the last six months. Several customers, vendors and fashion influencers like Komal Pandey took to social media to criticise the e-tailer and its co-founders for absconding without clearing payments and product deliveries. Some customers alleged that refunds for cancelled deliveries have been pending for months.

column2: New cancer treatment prevents hair loss from chemotherapy
column3: Researchers at The University of Manchester claim to have found a way to prevent hair loss in cancer patients during chemotherapy. Researchers found that coating the hair follicles with CDK4/6 inhibitors may prevent hair loss. Researchers have claimed that as many as 8% of patients may refuse chemotherapy due to the 'psychological burden' of hair loss.

column2: Engineers develop 'blackest black' material to date
column3: MIT engineers reported that they have created a material that is 10 times blacker than anything that has previously been reported. The material, which has been made from vertically aligned carbon nanotubes, captures more than 99.96% of any incoming light. The material can be used to make optical instruments that reduce unwanted glare, which could be used in space telescopes.

column2: HC criticises TN political parties for encouraging banner culture
column3: A division bench of the Madras High Court criticised political parties in Tamil Nadu for encouraging the banner culture, despite various court orders against it. This comes after 23-year-old Subhasri Ravi died on Thursday after an AIADMK leader's banner announcing his son's wedding fell on her. "Couldn't that politician have conducted the family marriage without flex boards?" the HC asked.

column2: New Parliament building to come up by 2024: Union Minister
column3: Union Minister Hardeep Singh Puri on Friday said, "[By 2024], it's our expectation that we will be in a new Parliament building." He also said one of PM Narendra Modi's dream projects is to reconstruct buildings built between 1911 and 1927 like North Block, South Block, Rashtrapati Bhavan, among others. "We are going to reconstruct all of that," Puri added.

column2: Rajasthan men beaten by mob in Ajmer after accident
column3: Three men were beaten in Rajasthan's Ajmer on Friday by a group of locals after their car collided and injured two sheep of the locals. "After the accident, the crowd pursued their vehicle and nabbed the three," a police official said. "All three have incurred minor injuries in the ensuing scuffle," the police official added.

column2: Delhi's traffic improved after new Motor Vehicles Act: Kejriwal
column3: Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal on Friday said implementation of new Motor Vehicles (Amendment) Act 2019 has improved the traffic situation in the national capital. "If there is any clause due to which people are facing more problem and we have the power to reduce fines then we will certainly do it," he added. Notably, several states have reduced traffic penalties.

column2: 18 dead across Maharashtra during Ganpati Visarjan
column3: At least 18 persons died in separate incidents during Ganesh Visarjan across Maharashtra, police said on Friday. Immersions began on Thursday and continued till Friday in several parts of Mumbai, Pune and Sangli, officials said. The deaths include four in Amravati, three in Ratnagiri, two each in Nashik, Sindhudurg and Satara, one each in Thane, Dhule, Buldhana, Akola and Bhandara.

column2: Amazon Prime Video launches song & music video for The Family Man
column3: Amazon Prime Video launched a music video for their upcoming original, The Family Man. "Dega Jaan", composed by Sachin-Jigar, is performed by Shreya Ghoshal and Mellow D. Featuring Manoj Bajpayee as Srikant Tiwari, it showcases his struggle of managing life as a family man and spy. It will feature on Amazon Prime Music, a week before other music streaming services.

column2: ABVP wins 3 posts including Prez, NSUI 1 in DU Students Union polls
column3: The Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) has won three out of the four top posts in Delhi University Students Union polls. ABVP bagged the top posts of President, Vice President and Joint Secretary, while the National Students' Union of India (NSUI) won the post of Secretary. The overall polling percentage was recorded at 40%, Chief Election Officer Ashok Prasad said.

column2: There was pain but no diagnosis: Shraddha on struggling with anxiety
column3: Actress Shraddha Kapoor has revealed that just after Aashiqui 2 she started having "physical manifestation of anxiety", stating, "There was this pain happening where there was no physiological diagnosis." Further talking about her struggle with anxiety, she said, "Today, it's something that I still deal with but it has become so much better than what it was."

column2: Russell stretchered off, rushed to hospital after getting hit on head
column3: Jamaica Tallawahs all-rounder Andre Russell was stretchered off after getting hit by the ball on his helmet during their CPL match against St Lucia Zouks on Thursday. The 31-year-old dropped to the ground after getting hit post missing a pull shot on the bowling of Hardus Viljoen. He was rushed to hospital, where he was cleared of any serious injury.

column2: SIT questions Chinmayanand for 7 hours, seals his bedroom
column3: BJP leader Swami Chinmayanand was questioned by a Special Investigation Team (SIT) for seven hours on Thursday in connection with allegations that he raped a 23-year-old law student. The SIT, formed on the orders of the Supreme Court, also sealed Chinmayanand's bedroom. Meanwhile, it also questioned the principals of two colleges where the law student studied.

column2: Study on French postmen's testicles wins Ig Nobel Prize
column3: Roger Mieusset has been honoured with an Ig Nobel Prize for his study conducted on French postmen to find out if a man's testicles are both the same temperature. The engineering prize went to an Iranian inventor's nappy-changing machine, while the peace prize went to a study that mapped out which parts of the body are most pleasurable to scratch.

column2: Water enters Indore hospital after rain, equipment seen floating
column3: Water entered the Maharaja Yeshwantrao Hospital in Madhya Pradesh's Indore following heavy rains in the city. Equipment was seen floating in the hospital corridors and wards, while hospital staffers ploughed through knee-deep water to administer medicines to patients. Meanwhile, an official said, "We are alert and ready if any mishap happens."

column2: Pak is hub of terrorism, spreads deceitful narratives: India at UN
column3: Pakistan is a hub of terrorism that has jeopardised innocent lives in the region and beyond, First Secretary in the Permanent Mission of India to the UN, Sandeep Kumar Bayyapu, said. Pakistan misused the UN to spread baseless and deceitful narratives about India, he added. His statement came during participation in the debate on the Report of the Security Council.

column2: Delhi court allows Robert Vadra to travel abroad for business
column3: A Delhi court on Friday allowed businessman and Congress General Secretary Priyanka Gandhi's husband Robert Vadra to travel abroad for business purposes. He was granted permission to travel to Spain from September 21 to October 8. Vadra is facing a probe under the Prevention of Money-Laundering Act (PMLA) related to purchase of alleged illegal assets abroad.

column2: Russia asks Interpol for information on alleged CIA spy
column3: Russia has asked the US via Interpol to provide information on the whereabouts of the alleged CIA spy who was reportedly close to President Vladimir Putin. The spy, identified by Russian media as Oleg Smolenkov, was extracted from Russia in 2017, reports said. Russia said that it learned via US media that Smolenkov and his family were in the US.

column2: Ex-Zimbabwe Prez Mugabe to be buried at heroes monument
column3: Former Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe will be buried at the country's National Heroes Acre. The official ceremony would be followed by a private family event at the monument for heroes of the liberation war against white minority rule. Mugabe's body arrived in Zimbabwe from Singapore on Wednesday. Mugabe, who ruled Zimbabwe for 37 years, died at the age of 95.

column2: Thailand allows 6 cannabis plants per household under draft law
column3: A party in Thailand's ruling coalition has proposed a draft law that allows up to six marijuana plants per household. This comes less than a year after the country legalised the drug for medicinal purposes and research. Under Thailand's current drug laws, recreational users of cannabis can incur penalties, including up to 10 years in prison for possession.

column2: US, China tariffs could lower global GDP by 0.8% in 2020: IMF
column3: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) on Thursday said that tariffs imposed or proposed by the US and China could lower global economic output by 0.8% in 2020. The impact of the US-China trade war and other trade disputes is now being felt, IMF spokesman Gerry Rice said. He added that the tariffs could trigger additional losses in future years.

column2: Polish flag carrier enters India after 25 yrs with Warsaw-Delhi route
column3: Poland's flag carrier, LOT Polish Airlines, on Thursday started Warsaw-Delhi direct flight, which is slated to fly five times a week. LOT Polish had discontinued its regular flight between the two capitals via Tashkent in 1994. The airline, which is a part of the Star Alliance, also has a codeshare agreement with Indian national carrier Air India.

column2: It was a phase that changes you: Neetu after Rishi's return
column3: After Rishi Kapoor's return to India, his wife Neetu Kapoor wrote on Thursday, "Where did these last 11 months go?? Was a long road!!!" "It was a phase that taught and changed me a lot," she further added. Rishi Kapoor, who was undergoing cancer treatment in New York, tweeted on Tuesday, "BACK HOME!!!!!! 11 Months 11 days! Thank you all."

column2: Google One allows auto backup for subscribers using Android
column3: Google has updated its expanded cloud storage service 'Google One' to allow 'automatic phone backup' option for subscribers using Android devices. Google One will let users automatically back up their multimedia messages (MMS) along with device data, photos and videos, letting them restore conversations on their new Android phones. Google One was launched in 2018.

column2: HRD Ministry asks institutes to use 1% of budget for startups
column3: The Human Resource Development Ministry (MHRD) has asked Higher Education Institutions (HEI) to allocate at least 1% of their annual budget for funding and supporting startups and innovation-related activities. As per MHRD's guidelines, HEIs will set up "innovation fund" for the purpose. HEIs will also have to provide round-the-clock pre-incubation and incubation facilities to students and staff.

column2: UP govt has nothing to do with women's safety: Priyanka Gandhi
column3: Congress General Secretary Priyanka Gandhi slammed the BJP government of Uttar Pradesh over Swami Chinmayanand sexual harassment case. "The BJP government of UP has made it clear that it has nothing to do with women's safety," she tweeted. "Why is the UP Police sluggish? Because the accused is related to BJP?" she further wrote.

column2: Delhi govt will distribute N95 masks to public in Oct: Kejriwal
column3: Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal on Friday said AAP government will procure N95 masks on large scale and distribute it to the citizens. "It will be distributed in October as the smog...penetrates Delhi in November. N95 masks that are considered best are being procured," he added. The CM also announced that the odd-even rule will be implemented again from November 4.

column2: Meghan Markle launches her own clothing line collection
column3: The Duchess of Sussex, Meghan Markle launched her own 'Smart Set Capsule Collection' in collaboration with her designer, Misha Nonoo and brands- Jigsaw, Marks & Spencer and John Lewis. The sales will benefit an organisation called Smart Works which helps unemployed women find jobs. "Thank you to the four brands who came together in supporting Smart Works," Meghan said.

column2: Pyer Moss showcases black culture during New York Fashion Week
column3: Men's fashion label Pyer Moss' latest collection 'Sister' showcased black culture at the ongoing New York Fashion Week 2019. The show witnessed black and brown models wearing Pyer Moss labels. Kerby Jean-Raymond, founder of the Pyer Moss label said, "The whole thing is really to recognise our worth...what we've contributed to what pop society is in America."

column2: Man dies during sex on biz trip, court calls it 'workplace accident'
column3: The death of a Frenchman who died while having sex when he was on a business trip has been termed as "workplace accident" by a court. The court ruled that the firm should compensate the family of the employee who had suffered a heart attack. However, the firm said that the employee's sexual activity was not a part of work.

column2: Don't want to see the whole film: Sibal on PM Modi's 'trailer' remark
column3: Responding to PM Narendra Modi's remark that in the last 100 days of NDA government, the nation has seen "its trailer, the film is remaining", Congress leader Kapil Sibal said, "We don't want to see rest of the film." Sibal stated that in the last 100 days, GDP, GST collections and investments have gone down while unemployment has increased.

column2: Zomato suspends its 'Infinity Dining' programme
column3: Zomato has suspended its 'Infinity Dining' programme from its app amid issues with restaurants over "deep and unsustainable" discounting. Introduced in July, the 'Infinity Dining' programme allowed Zomato Gold subscribers to order unlimited food and drinks at a set price from the menu of partner restaurants for a limited period of time.

column2: BJP MLA opposes MP govt's decision to sell chicken, milk at same outlet
column3: BJP MLA Rameshwar Sharma has objected to Madhya Pradesh government's project of selling cow milk and chicken at the same outlet. "This is hurting the religious sentiments of people. We request the government to look into it," Sharma said. The state government had started the project to increase the earnings of women from tribal communities.

column2: SC's 3-judge bench to review its 2018 verdict diluting SC/ST act
column3: The Supreme Court has referred its March 2018 verdict on Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act to a three-judge bench, on a review petition filed by the Centre last year. The top court had last year banned automatic arrests and registration of cases over Dalit atrocities complaints under the act, that led to protests across the country.

column2: Delhi court dismisses Chidambaram’s plea seeking to surrender before ED
column3: A Delhi court on Friday dismissed former Finance Minister P Chidambaram’s plea seeking permission to surrender before the Enforcement Directorate (ED). He would now remain in jail till September 19. Chidambaram, who is currently lodged in Tihar, was seeking regular bail in the INX Media case. He has been in judicial custody since September 5.

column2: Tell India to lift restrictions in Kashmir: US lawmakers to Trump
column3: A group of four US lawmakers on Thursday asked President Donald Trump to tell India to lift the communications blackout in Kashmir and release those detained. The lawmakers also said Pakistan should end support to terrorism and refrain from taking any steps that could destabilise Kashmir. "We urge you to act swiftly," the lawmakers told Trump.

column2: UP policemen kick, slap man after failing to show bike papers
column3: A video has surfaced online, showing two policemen slapping and kicking a 25-year-old man on the road in Uttar Pradesh's Siddharth Nagar district in front of his five-year-old nephew. As per initial reports, the policemen starting beating the man up after he failed to show his motorcycle's paper and resisted giving his vehicle's keys. The duo has been suspended.

column2: 52 errors like 'Artcle', 'Shariet' corrected in Act to bifurcate J&K
column3: The Centre has issued corrections for 52 errors in J&K Reorganisation Act, the legislation to bifurcate Jammu and Kashmir. Words like "artcle" was corrected to "article", "Tterritories" to "territories" and "Shariet" to "Shariat". It also mentioned "State of Jammu and Kashmir" instead of "Union territory of Jammu and Kashmir" and "Institutes Act, 2005" was corrected to "Institutions Act, 2004".

column2: Canadian thrashes immigration officer at Delhi airport, deported
column3: A Canadian national was deported from the Delhi airport on Wednesday night after he got into an argument with an immigration officer and thrashed him, as per media reports. The officer had asked the Canadian man why he'd failed to fill his immigration form properly, following which he got into an argument with the officer. The officer then informed police.

column2: Trump says he won't appoint Mike Pompeo as US NSA
column3: US President Donald Trump has said that he won't appoint Secretary of State Mike Pompeo as the National Security Adviser (NSA). Trump added that he spoke with Pompeo about it and that the Secretary of State "liked the idea of somebody (else) in there". This comes after Trump fired John Bolton as NSA, citing disagreements over several issues.

column2: NZ PM proposes creating gun register after Christchurch shootings
column3: New Zealand's PM Jacinda Ardern tabled a bill in the Parliament to create a register to track all the guns in the country. This has been proposed under gun law reforms following the shootings at two mosques in Christchurch in March. The bill also proposed gun licences in New Zealand be renewed every five years instead of every 10 years.

column2: Google Earth helps find body of man who went missing 22 years ago
column3: The remains of a US man who went missing 22 years ago have been found in a submerged car visible on Google Maps. William Moldt had failed to return home from a night out at a club. A report by an online database said the "vehicle had been visible on a Google Earth satellite photo of the area since 2007".

column2: US to name Saudi official who allegedly helped 9/11 attackers
column3: The US Justice Department plans to disclose the name of the Saudi official who had allegedly helped the hijackers who carried out the 9/11 terror attacks. In the past 18 years, Saudi Arabia has denied any involvement in the attacks, which killed nearly 3,000 people. Two Saudi officials, Omar al-Bayoumi and Fahad al-Thumairy, had previously been named.

column2: Our kids are first projects we did together: Shahid on his children
column3: Shahid Kapoor said that for him and wife Mira Rajput, their kids- Misha Kapoor and Zain Kapoor were the "first two projects they actually did together." "One year into an arranged marriage...you really evolve around each other," Shahid added. He also revealed that roles are perfectly cut out and Mira is 'the disciplinarian' and he is 'the softy'.

column2: So many people are earning because of Kapil: Bharti
column3: Talking about Kapil Sharma, comedian Bharti Singh said in an interview that so many people are earning because of him. "His comeback was much needed...[P]eople have bought big cars, houses by doing shows with him," she added. Bharti further revealed that Kapil has changed after marriage and said, "He has stopped drinking, smoking and eats ghar ka khaana."

column2: Fintech startup OkCredit raises $67 mn led by Tiger Global
column3: Bengaluru-based fintech startup OkCredit has raised $67 million in a Series B round of funding led by existing investors Tiger Global and Lightspeed. Founded in 2017 by IIT alumni Harsh Pokharna, Aditya Prasad and Gaurav Kunwar, OkCredit lets merchants and customers record their credit and payment transactions digitally across India. The startup had in June raised $15.5-million Series A funding.

column2: World's first malaria vaccine to be introduced in Kenya
column3: The world's first malaria vaccine is being rolled out in parts of Kenya after debuting in Ghana and Malawi earlier this year. More than 300,000 children are expected to receive the vaccine over the next three years. Malaria infected about 219 million people in 2017, killing around 435,000 of them, most of them babies and children in parts of Africa.

column2: Cab driver boarded train, harassed me & posed for pic: Pawar's daughter
column3: NCP chief Sharad Pawar's daughter and MP Supriya Sule alleged she was harassed inside a train in Mumbai by a man touting for taxi service. "Despite a refusal twice he blocked my path, harassed me and shamelessly even posed for the photo," Sule tweeted. Asking Railways Ministry to look into it, she said touting shouldn't be permitted within train stations.

column2: Accidental war with India a possibility: Pak Foreign Minister
column3: Pakistan Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi has said, "An accidental war with India cannot be ruled out." Qureshi further said that he believes both Pakistan and India "understand the consequences of a conflict", adding, "If the situation persists...then anything is possible." Tensions between India and Pakistan heightened following the revocation of Article 370 in Jammu & Kashmir.

column2: Odd-even rule to be back in Delhi from November 4-15: CM Kejriwal
column3: Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal on Friday announced that odd-even rule for vehicles will be implemented again in the National Capital from November 4-15 in order to curb pollution. Under the rule, vehicles with registration plates ending in odd and even numbers are allowed to ply on alternate days, respectively. He also urged people not to burst crackers on Diwali.

column2: OnePlus marks 1500 days of OxygenOS with plant a tree campaign
column3: OnePlus is celebrating 1500 days of OxygenOS and marking the occasion has collaborated with WWF India and their 'Adopt a Tree' campaign. OnePlus will plant one tree for every tweet with #OxygenOS. "It's been an amazing journey, building great products and software together with the OnePlus community," said Szymon Kopec, Product lead at OnePlus in a post on Friday.

column2: Great Learning's PGP-DSE offers dedicated hiring drives
column3: Great Learning's PG program in Data Science & Engineering helps graduates and early-career professionals become job-ready. The 5-month full-time program offers placement assistance that helps alumni transition to data science roles in MNCs and startups. Upon program completion, learners get a certificate from Great Lakes and can expect an average salary hike of 65%, according to Great Learning.

column2: It was the season of MeToo: Chunky on allegations on Sajid Khan
column3: Speaking about sexual harassment allegations on filmmaker Sajid Khan, actor Chunky Panday said, "When these allegations came, it was a shocker to everyone...it was the season of MeToo, and everyone was getting exposed." "The thing is Sajid has always been a very very outspoken person...A lot of people might misunderstand Sajid Khan...I know Sajid since childhood," he added.

column2: Fintech startup FamPay may raise $8 mn from Sequoia, Lightspeed
column3: Bengaluru-based fintech startup FamPay is in talks with Sequoia Capital and Lightspeed to raise up to $8 million, Entrackr reported. The round could reportedly see participation from several angel investors including former WhatsApp Business Chief Neeraj Arora. Founded by IIT-Roorkee graduates, FamPay is a family-friendly digital payment app where parents can safely send money to their children.

column2: Imran Khan claims 58 nations supported Pak; UNHRC has only 47 members
column3: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan has wrongly claimed that 58 nations supported Pakistan's stand against India at the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC). Notably, the UNHRC has only 47 members. Reacting to Khan's tweet, Indian Ministry of External Affairs spokesperson Raveesh Kumar said, "You have to understand that UNHRC has 47 members, they have gone beyond that."

column2: Delhi School of Magic offers courses in magic to both kids & adults
column3: The Delhi School of Magic, established by magician Raj Kumar, trains kids as well as adults to learn magic. The school offers four kinds of courses to people - the beginners magic courses, the professional magic courses, the instant magic tricks and the usage of all magic props. These courses are taught by senior magicians from India and abroad.

column2: TN artist carves pencil tips to create awareness on sensitive topics
column3: Tamil Nadu artist Kailash Babu creates miniature sculptures by carving the tips of pencils to create awareness on sensitive topics like water conservation and women’s safety. He was inspired by Brazilian artist Dalton Ghetti in 2011 to explore this form of art. So far, he has carved over 200 sculptures on pencil lead, some as small as 0.7mm in diameter.

column2: India's economic growth is much weaker than expected: IMF
column3: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) spokesperson Gerry Rice has said that the recent economic growth in India is "much weaker than expected". He said that it's weaker mainly due to "corporate and environmental regulatory uncertainty" and "lingering weakness in some non-bank financial companies". In July, IMF had cut India's GDP growth forecast for 2019-20 to 7% from 7.3%.

column2: Would've loved to play Alia's role in Kapoor & Sons: Nushrat
column3: Actress Nushrat Bharucha said that she would've loved to play Alia Bhatt's character in 'Kapoor & Sons'. "Even though it was about a family, I enjoyed watching her because the character was so nicely weaved in," Nushrat said. Talking about her film choices, Nushrat added, "If suddenly one of the films did well...it can't change the choices I've been making."

column2: Kenyan couple sings DDLJ song, Anupam Kher shares video
column3: Actor Anupam Kher who starred in Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge (DDLJ) in 1995 along with Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol has shared on Twitter a video of a Kenyan couple lip-syncing 'Tujhe Dekha Toh' song from the movie. Anupam captioned his tweet, "Presenting #Sharukh and #Kajol from Kenya...[V]ideo shared by the man who composed the song, @pandit_lalit. Enjoy. #MusicIsUniversal."

column2: Google to shut down shopping service 'Express' in next few weeks
column3: Google, which had earlier announced the shutdown of its US shopping service Google Express, in emails sent to users revealed that it will be closed in a few weeks. The features and functions of Express will be integrated into Google's new, global 'Shopping' platform. The Google Express apps will automatically update to become Google Shopping if already installed by users.

column2: Pledge to fight for Muslim sisters, develop J&K and Ladakh: PM
column3: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Thursday asserted that his government has taken several measures to remove corruption, bring about development and root out terrorism. "We pledge to...fight for the rights of Muslim sisters," PM Modi added. "We aim to bring about development in Jammu & Kashmir and Ladakh, the work for which has begun," the PM further said.

column2: 300 street plays on Article 370 to be staged in Mumbai: BJP
column3: Maharashtra BJP unit officials on Thursday said that the party will stage 300 street plays based on Article 370 and 35A revocation in Mumbai ahead of Assembly polls. The BJP's corporators in the Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation were reportedly given the task of implementing this project. These plays will be staged in all Assembly constituencies of Mumbai, party sources said.

column2: Ranthambore’s man-eater tiger kills its third human prey
column3: A man-eater tiger numbered T-104 from the Ranthambore Tiger Reserve in Rajasthan on Wednesday killed a 30-year-old man, its third human prey, while he was asleep in his hut. "It dragged the body inside the forest. When we found out, we raised an alarm," a villager said. A forest department official said teams were sent to tranquilize and catch T-104.

column2: Bumrah best bowler in the world even if rankings didn't say so: Pathan
column3: All-rounder Irfan Pathan has said fast bowler Jasprit Bumrah is the best bowler in the world. "Even if the rankings did not say so. To be able to bowl with this pace with such a short run up, he is more effective," he added. "We are very lucky to have this kind of bowler in our ranks," he further said.

column2: PM Modi's presence became bad luck for ISRO: Kumaraswamy
column3: Former Karnataka Chief Minister HD Kumaraswamy held PM Narendra Modi responsible after Chandrayaan-2's Vikram lander lost contact with the ground station. "PM came to Bengaluru to give a message that he himself was landing Chandrayaan-2...he came just for sake of advertisement," he said. "Once he stepped in the ISRO Centre, I think it became bad luck for scientists," Kumaraswamy added.

column2: China lays claim on Ladakh territory where it clashed with India
column3: China on Thursday said that the area in Ladakh, where Indian and Chinese troops had a standoff, is "entirely located" in its territory. The standoff between the two countries had occurred near the bank of the Pangong Tso lake, according to reports. China added that it hopes both the countries would take no action to "complicate the situation".

column2: India asks Pakistan to reconsider $20 fee from Kartarpur pilgrims
column3: India on Thursday asked Pakistan to reconsider its decision to charge $20 as service charge from pilgrims to visit the Gurudwara Kartarpur Sahib in Pakistan. MEA Spokesperson Raveesh Kumar said India has urged Pakistan to show "some flexibility" on the Kartarpur Corridor so that the celebrations of the 550th birth anniversary of Guru Nanak Dev are conducted without hindrance.

column2: 22-year-old farmer kills self, family loses 5th male member to suicide
column3: Lavpreet Singh, a 22-year-old farmer from Bhotna village in Punjab's Barnala district, committed suicide by reportedly consuming pesticides due to mounting debt. Also, his great grandfather, grandfather, father and his brother had committed suicide. "Around 70 years ago, the family had around 14 acres of land, but now the family owns only one acre," a villager said.

column2: Current economic situation challenging: Sadananda Gowda
column3: Union Minister DV Sadanada Gowda on Thursday said the current economic situation in the country was "challenging". Gowda said, "I agree that our GDP, that was 8.2%, has now come down to 5%. This is certainly a challenge." However, he added that the measures taken by the government would see the country progress ahead "in a very short time".

column2: Siddaramaiah, DK Suresh not allowed to meet Shivakumar in hospital
column3: Former Karnataka CM Siddaramaiah and Congress MP DK Suresh came to visit DK Shivakumar at Dr Ram Manohar Lohia Hospital in Delhi, however, they were not allowed to meet him. Suresh is the brother of Shivakumar, who is in the Enforcement Directorate's custody in a money laundering case. Shivakumar's daughter Aisshwarya is also being probed in the case.

column2: ED probes Cong leader Shivakumar's daughter for over 7 hours
column3: The Enforcement Directorate on Thursday questioned Congress leader DK Shivakumar's daughter Aisshwarya for over seven hours in Delhi in connection with a money laundering case. Aisshwarya's statement was recorded under the Prevention of Money Laundering Act. She has been asked to appear before the ED again on Friday. Notably, Shivakumar's nine-day ED custody expires tomorrow.

column2: Techie hit by tanker after AIADMK leader's hoarding falls on her, dies
column3: Subhasri Ravi, a 23-year-old who was working in an IT company, died on Thursday after an AIADMK leader's hoarding erected on the road's divider to announce his son's wedding fell on her in Chennai. Subhasri, who was riding a two-wheeler, lost her balance and fell on the road. Eyewitnesses said that a tanker lorry coming from behind ran over her.

column2: No-deal Brexit could lead to rise in food, fuel prices: Govt docs
column3: A no-deal Brexit could lead to a rise in food and fuel prices as well as a reduction in medical supplies, documents published under the government's Operation Yellowhammer revealed. "Protests and counter-protests will take place across the UK," the document said. Trade between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic will be "severely disrupted", it added.

column2: Plane with 326 fliers made emergency landing after pilot spilt coffee
column3: A commercial flight with 326 passengers was forced to make an emergency landing in February after pilot spilt coffee over the control panel, the UK's Air Accidents Investigation Branch said. The flight from Germany to Mexico had to land in Ireland. The hot liquid damaged the audio control panel, producing an electrical burning smell and smoke, the accident report revealed.

column2: Facebook VP counters Ambani, says data is not oil to be hoarded
column3: Countering Mukesh Ambani, Facebook VP (Global Affairs) Nick Clegg said data isn't the new oil and countries like India shouldn't hoard it within national boundaries. The value of data comes from allowing it to flow freely and encouraging the innovation that comes from it, Clegg added. Ambani had said India's data must be owned by Indians and not by corporates.

column2: Frogs married 2 months ago, divorced to stop rains in MP
column3: A frog couple married nearly two months ago to bring rain in Madhya Pradesh was divorced symbolically on Wednesday to end the heavy rainfall in the state. The frogs were wedded on July 19 in Bhopal in the superstitious belief that marrying them would bring rain. As per a report, Madhya Pradesh had already recorded 26% excess rains till Wednesday.

column2: Rohit Sharma to open in three Tests against South Africa: MSK Prasad
column3: Team India chief selector MSK Prasad has said that Rohit Sharma has been selected in India's squad for the Test series against South Africa as an opener. "He will open in the three matches and also for the Board President's XI. We want to give him an opportunity to open the innings in Tests," Prasad added.

column2: Smith learnt harsh lessons, will be better leader next time: Taylor
column3: Former Australia captain Mark Taylor has said that he believes batsman Steve Smith can lead Australia again when he becomes eligible on April 1, 2020. "(Smith) will be a better leader next time around because of the very harsh lessons he learnt," the 54-year-old added. "I don't believe the additional responsibility of captaincy would affect his batting," Taylor further said.

column2: Ex-world no. 1 Clijsters, mom of 3, to return to tennis after 7 yrs
column3: Former world number one Kim Clijsters on Thursday shared a video announcing her plans to return to WTA Tour in 2020 after an over seven-year break. The decision marks the four-time Grand Slam Champion's second return to the sport after first retiring in 2007. "I missed the feeling of being a professional tennis player," the 36-year-old said about her return.

column2: Scientists create colour-changing smart skin inspired by chameleons
column3: Scientists have created a flexible smart skin that can change colour in response to the environment without changing shape. It was created by studying time-lapse videos of chameleons' phase-shifting skin and experiment with embedding photonic crystal arrays into flexible, water-containing polymers. Expanding or contracting the hydrogel changed the spacing in the arrays, leading to colour change.

column2: UP govt attacking journalists who seek answers: Priyanka
column3: Congress leader Priyanka Gandhi Vadra on Thursday alleged that BJP government in Uttar Pradesh is constantly attacking journalists who seek answers from it. "Their job is to make news on public issues and seek answers from the government," she tweeted. Recently, a journalist was arrested for allegedly shooting a video of kids mopping school floor in UP's Azamgarh.

column2: Vertex Ventures adds $290 mn fund for high-growth tech firms
column3: Singapore-based Vertex Venture Holdings has added a new $290 million venture capital fund targeting investments in high-growth technology firms. The Vertex Growth Fund will look to invest between $10 million-$15 million per company, mostly in the third or fourth funding rounds, compared to $3 million-$4 million by affiliate funds in early rounds. Vertex has invested in more than 200 companies.

column2: 6 killed, 15 injured as bus rams into truck in Maharashtra
column3: At least six people were killed and 15 others injured after a bus rammed into a stationary truck in Maharashtra's Satara on Thursday, a police official said. The accident took place at around 5 am. Due to low visibility on the road in the early hours, the bus driver was apparently unable to see the truck, another police official said.

column2: NC leader 'appreciates' Pak's role in taking up J&K issue
column3: National Conference leader and MP Mohammad Akbar Lone on Thursday said that he "appreciated" the role of Pakistan for taking up J&K issue internationally and putting pressure on India. "It is military rule in Kashmir. Every nook and corner of the state is guarded by the Army, by paramilitary forces, people are not allowed to come out," Lone said.

column2: Habibie, Indonesian Prez during transition to democracy, dies
column3: Indonesia's ex-President BJ Habibie, who served during the country's transition to democracy in 1998, passed away aged 83 on Wednesday after suffering from heart failure. Thousands of people reportedly lined the streets as Habibie's cortege moved for a state funeral. Habibie oversaw economic and democratic reforms during 17 months in office, after ex-President Suharto stepped down after 32 years.

column2: Taliban bomb blast kills four Afghan special forces in Kabul
column3: A suicide bomber targeted an Afghan Special Forces base in Kabul on Thursday, killing at least four commandos and injuring three, officials said. Taliban spokesperson Zabihullah Mujahid issued a statement claiming responsibility for the attack, which he said killed more than 200 commandos. The violence reportedly began to escalate following the collapse of peace talks between the US and Taliban.

column2: Women are constantly under pressure to look beautiful: Nandita Das
column3: Actress Nandita Das has said that women are constantly under pressure to look beautiful, which shouldn't be the case. "Women are intelligent, they have skills and talent so, they can do a lot of things," she added. Nandita is a supporter of 'Dark Is Beautiful' campaign, which focusses on the issue of colour discrimination men and women face in society.

column2: It's surreal: Kohli on having Pavilion named after him at Delhi stadium
column3: The Delhi and District Cricket Association (DDCA) on Thursday officially renamed Feroz Shah Kotla Stadium as Arun Jaitley Stadium and unveiled Virat Kohli Pavilion stand. Adding that he first came to the stadium to watch a match in 2001, Kohli said, "To have a pavilion in my name at the same stadium is surreal and a great honour."

column2: Russia terminates its 1st humanoid robot to space Fedor
column3: Russia has terminated its first life-sized humanoid robot to space, Fedor (Final Experimental Demonstration Object Research). Fedor was launched on August 22 aboard a Soyuz MS-14 spacecraft, which docked successfully with the International Space Station (ISS) five days later. "There's nothing more for him to do [in ISS], he's completed his mission," the robot developer's executive director said.

column2: NASA attempts to establish contact with Vikram lander: Report
column3: NASA attempting to establish contact with Chandrayaan-2 mission's Moon lander Vikram by sending communication signals with its Deep Space Network, a report said on Thursday. NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory had beamed a radio frequency to Vikram to establish contact, the report added. Chandrayaan-2's Vikram lander made a hard landing on the Moon on September 7.

column2: Nation saw the trailer, film is remaining: PM on 100 days of govt
column3: Addressing a rally in Jharkhand, PM Narendra Modi on Thursday said, "At the time of the election, I promised you a working and strong government. In the last 100 days, the nation has seen its trailer, the film is remaining." He added, "Our aim is to show the right place to the people who looted the money of the citizens."

column2: Pakistan to charge $20 service fee from Kartarpur pilgrims
column3: Pakistan said on Thursday that it will charge $20 as service fee from pilgrims visiting Gurudwara Kartarpur Sahib. This is meant to cover 10%-15% of the costs, which is only a small part of the expenditure on the construction of facilities for the pilgrims on the Pakistani side, Pakistan's Foreign Office spokesperson Mohammad Faisal said.

column2: Maharashtra stays implementation of new Motor Vehicles Act
column3: Maharashtra government has termed the heavy penalties under the new Motor Vehicles Act as "exorbitant" and stayed its implementation. Announcing the decision, state Transport Minister Diwakar Raote urged the Centre to "reconsider and reduce" the hefty fines by making amendments to the new Act. Uttarakhand government has relaxed fines levied on certain violations under the new Motor Vehicles Act.

column2: UP woman sits on snakes while talking on phone; gets bitten, dies
column3: A woman in Uttar Pradesh's Gorakhpur sat on a pair of snakes on her bed while talking to her husband on phone, following which they bit her. Her family members rushed her to a hospital, where she died during treatment. After returning from the hospital, the family and neighbours beat the snakes to death that were still on the bed.

column2: Can't find bride due to job conditions: Constable in resignation letter
column3: Siddanthi Prathap, a 29-year-old constable working with the Hyderabad Police, resigned from his position last week. In his resignation letter, he wrote that a prospective bride rejected his marriage proposal over his long working hours and limited growth. "I've been observing senior constables who retired from services as constables after serving 35-40 years without any promotion," he added.

column2: Indian Army officer's body retrieved from Lake Kivu in Congo
column3: The body of Lieutenant Colonel Gaurav Solanki of the Indian Army, posted with the India contingent in the United Nations peacekeeping mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo, was retrieved from Lake Kivu on Thursday. Solanki had been missing since Sunday after he went kayaking in Lake Kivu. Intensive search was carried out to retrieve the officer, said the Army.

column2: China offered oil & gas deal to ignore South China Sea ruling: Duterte
column3: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has said that his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping had offered his country a controlling stake in a joint energy deal if he ignored a South China Sea ruling against China. The Permanent Court of Arbitration had in 2016 clarified maritime boundaries and invalidated China's claims to almost the entire South China Sea.

column2: US briefly overtakes Saudi Arabia as world's top oil exporter
column3: The US briefly overtook Saudi Arabia as the world's top oil exporter in June, the International Energy Agency (IEA) said on Thursday. Record shale production helped the US ship almost 9 million barrels a day of crude and oil products in June. Saudi reclaimed the top exporter's spot in July and August as hurricanes disrupted US production, the IEA said.

column2: Not privy to any information of attack on SL players: PCB
column3: After Sri Lanka's Prime Minister's Office alerted the SLC of receiving "reliable information of possible terrorist threat" on the Sri Lankan team while touring Pakistan, PCB said it isn't privy to any such information. The PCB is committed to the safety of players, it added. Earlier, ten players including Lasith Malinga withdrew their names from the series citing security concerns.

column2: Alexa Auto's new offline capabilities work in remote areas
column3: Amazon launched a new version of the Alexa Auto SDK that will let users drive through tunnels, parking garages or remote areas without going offline. The new 'Local Voice Control' extension acts as a backup and is meant to increase the resiliency of Alexa's cloud-based capabilities. The feature will allow users in search and navigation as well as car control.

column2: Why is govt confused on economy: Priyanka on Ola-Uber remarks
column3: Congress' Priyanka Gandhi Vadra on Thursday said that before elections government stated that Ola and Uber increased employment and it's now blaming them for automobile sector's slowdown. "Why is BJP government so confused about the economy?" she added. Earlier, Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman said millennials choosing Ola and Uber over buying vehicles has led to automobile sector's slowdown.

column2: BJP is standing with Chinmayanand: AAP leader Sanjay Singh
column3: AAP leader Sanjay Singh on Thursday alleged that BJP is "standing" with its party leader Swami Chinmayanand, who has been accused of physically exploiting a law student. "She (the victim) submitted proof...to SIT and it's also available with the media but it has maintained silence," Singh said. The student has accused Chinmayanand of physically exploiting her for one year.

column2: Hungry Foal raises pre-Series A round led by Madison Capital
column3: Gurugram-based healthy snacks manufacturer Hungry Foal has raised an undisclosed amount in a pre-Series A round led by Singapore-based Madison Capital. InnerChef Co-Founder Rajesh Sawhney, Startup Buddy CEO Amit Singal and senior corporate executives also participated in this round. The company had previously raised funds from GAIL and an undisclosed amount of debt from State Bank of India.

column2: Mamata Banerjee leads a protest rally against Assam NRC
column3: West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee on Thursday led a rally in Kolkata to protest the National Register of Citizens in Assam. The TMC had on September 7 and 8 conducted rallies in other parts of the state to oppose the exercise to update the citizenship register. It accused the BJP of trying to divide people through the exercise.

column2: 50 dead after train derails in Congo
column3: Up to 50 people died and 30 were injured after a train derailed in Congo on Thursday, officials said, adding that the death toll is a provisional number. The national railway company said the cause of the accident could not be determined and undamaged carriages were moving towards their destination. An official said three of the train's carriages were derailed.

column2: India will protect national interest in RCEP pact: Piyush Goyal
column3: Piyush Goyal said on Wednesday that India will protect its national interest and domestic industry while signing the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) agreement. India has invited RCEP representatives for a two-day meet on September 14-15 to discuss ideas to strengthen the pact between the 16 Asia-Pacific countries. Goyal seeks to conclude the pact with adequate protection soon.

column2: RFID-enabled toll plazas to go cashless from September 13
column3: Commercial vehicles having RFID tags will switch to cashless payments from Friday. Failing to do so, vehicles would be required to pay double the tax as fine. RFID tags in August were made mandatory for commercial vehicles entering Delhi. "Going cashless would bring down human interference, save time and improve integrity of the system," member of Environment Pollution Authority stated.

column2: Consumer inflation hits 10-month high of 3.21% in August
column3: The consumer inflation increased from 3.15% in July to hit a 10-month high of 3.21% in August, government data showed on Thursday. Despite the increase, inflation is still below the Reserve Bank of India's target of 4%. The CPI inflation data released by the government shows the rise in prices was mainly driven by the price rise in food items.

column2: Waited for beautiful ladies to take same bus as mine in college: Big B
column3: Amitabh Bachchan, in an episode of Kaun Banega Crorepati season 11 recalled his college days and said, "[A] bus used to...leave me at my university." "Through [the] route, a lot of good looking college-going ladies...used to take this bus," he added. "We used to eagerly wait for the stop to arrive faster and...for beautiful ladies to get in," said Bachchan.

column2: ICC photoshops goat into Steve Smith's face in picture with fan
column3: The ICC took to Twitter to share a picture showing a goat photoshopped into Australia batsman Steve Smith's face in a picture with a fan. Commenting on it, a user photoshopped Don Bradman's face on the viral angry Pakistani fan's face, and wrote, "Am I a joke to you?" Notably, the acronym GOAT is known as Greatest of All Time.

column2: News about Dhoni's press conference on retirement incorrect: MSK Prasad
column3: Team India chief selector MSK Prasad on Thursday said that the news about former captain MS Dhoni holding a press conference today to announce his retirement is incorrect. He further said that there is no update on the former India captain's retirement. Dhoni was not selected for West Indies and South Africa series after he made himself unavailable.

column2: Modified Tesla Model S set record for fastest 4-door sedan: Musk
column3: Tesla Co-founder Elon Musk took to Twitter to reveal that a Model S equipped with "Plaid powertrain" has set a new record for the fastest four-door sedan. Tesla released the video a day after the tweet saying the Laguna Seca track was lapped in 1:36.555, a second faster than the past record. However, this may not be an official record.

column2: Man who fractured Mamata Banerjee’s skull acquitted after 29 years
column3: Lalu Alam, the key accused in a case of attempt to murder West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee 29 years ago, was acquitted by a court over lack of evidence. On August 16, 1990, Alam had hit Mamata on the head with a stick and the impact had fractured her skull. Mamata was West Bengal Youth Congress President at the time.

column2: Will keep trying ICJ verdict is followed: India on Kulbhushan Jadhav
column3: After Pakistan denied second consular access to retired Indian Navy officer Kulbhushan Jadhav, India said, "The verdict of the International Court of Justice (ICJ) was in our favour. We'll keep trying that the judgement is fully implemented." "We would like to remain in touch with the Pakistani side through diplomatic channels," External Affairs Ministry spokesperson Raveesh Kumar added.

column2: Mischievous narrative sought to be created: Goyal on Einstein remark
column3: Union Minister Piyush Goyal on Thursday said, "The comment I made had a certain context...some friends have sought to remove context...and create a mischievous narrative." "I quote, I said, 'Don't get into maths, those maths has not helped and shall discover gravity'," Goyal said. His clarification came after he said 'Maths never helped Einstein discover gravity' during a press conference.

column2: Traffic violations to be linked to motor insurance premiums
column3: Insurance regulator IRDAI has formed a nine-member working committee to examine linking motor insurance premiums with traffic violations. The committee has been given two months to recommend the implementation framework and methodology, after which a pilot project will be undertaken in Delhi. The premiums are currently linked to the vehicle and not the driver.

column2: Pakistan was unfairly blamed for US failure in Afghanistan: Pak PM
column3: Pakistan's PM Imran Khan said in an interview that Pakistan was "unfairly" blamed for the US' failures in Afghanistan. "Had we not participated in American war (in Afghanistan) after 9/11, we wouldn't have been the world's dangerous country," he added. Pakistan trained Islamist Mujahideen fighters to wage war against the Soviet Union in Afghanistan in the 1980s, he further said.

column2: Saudi princess found guilty of ordering attack on worker in Paris
column3: Saudi princess Hassa bint Salman was found guilty of ordering a bodyguard to beat up a worker in her Paris apartment by a French court and given a 10-month suspended sentence. The bodyguard bound the worker's hands, kicked him and forced him to kiss her feet. She allegedly got angry when she saw the worker filming her on his phone.

column2: We spent billions to bring Jamaat-ud-Dawa to mainstream: Pak minister
column3: Pakistan spent billions of rupees on Hafiz Saeed's Jamaat-ud-Dawa terror group to bring it to the mainstream, Pakistan's Federal Minister for Interior, Ijaz Ahmad Shah, said in an interview. Shah's statement came as he talked about Pakistan's crackdown on terror groups. Shah said in the same interview that the international community believes India and not Pakistan, on the Kashmir issue.

column2: I did not lie to the Queen over suspension of Parliament: UK PM
column3: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Thursday denied that he lied to the Queen over the suspension of the Parliament, insisting such a claim by opposition lawmakers is "absolutely not" true. Johnson's statement came after Scotland's highest civil court ruled that the suspension was unlawful. The UK Parliament was suspended on Monday until October 14.

column2: Israel denies report it planted spying devices near White House
column3: Israel's Foreign Minister Israel Katz has denied a report that Israel planted cell phone surveillance devices near the White House and other locations around Washington DC. The devices were likely intended to spy on US President Donald Trump as well as his top aides and closest associates. The Trump administration did not reprimand Israel over the matter, the report said.

column2: Google adds Maps locator tools to help drug addicts find help
column3: Google is adding two new map-related tools to help people suffering from drug addiction by connecting them to support groups or helping to make the life-saving drug Naloxone more accessible. Google launched a website called 'Recover Together', to help about 23 million Americans recover from drug addiction, which includes a 'Recovery Locator Tool' and a 'Naloxone Locator Tool'.

column2: Economy in grim state but govt indulging in vendetta politics: Sonia
column3: Congress interim President Sonia Gandhi on Thursday said the economic situation in the country is very grim, but the government is indulging in "vendetta politics". "Losses are mounting. All that the government is doing is indulging in unprecedented vendetta politics to divert attention from mounting losses," she added. "Democracy is at peril," Sonia further said.

column2: Govt should reconsider its decision on traffic fines: Kamal Nath
column3: Madhya Pradesh CM Kamal Nath on Thursday said the government must reconsider the quantum of penalties for traffic violations and give relief to the people. "We also want to put a stop on road accidents...but it must be seen that the penalty is not unviable," he added. Penalties should be in accordance with people's paying capacity, Nath further said.

column2: Indian Army is always ready for action in PoK: Army Chief
column3: Indian Army Chief General Bipin Rawat on Thursday said forces are always ready for action in Pakistan occupied Kashmir (PoK). The Army will act as per the directions of the government in this regard, he added. General Rawat also said that the residents of J&K should give a chance to security forces and administration to bring peace in the Valley.

column2: Vera Wang's fans defend her after she is called 'too skinny'
column3: Designer Vera Wang was defended by her fans after she was called 'too skinny' by her followers on Instagram. A user wrote, "She needs to eat protein and lift weights," after Wang posted a picture of herself on Instagram. The comment received responses in support of Wang with some saying, "None of our business", and "You're some random [person] on...internet".

column2: Michael Kors showcases his collection at NYFW on 9/11 anniversary
column3: Designer Michael Kors displayed his Spring 2020 collection at the New York Fashion Week on the 18th anniversary of the 9/11 terror attacks. The show featured a model wearing a sweater that had the word 'HATE' written on it and a red line crossing through it. It also featured a mix of casuals, sporty outfits and sparkly dresses.

column2: India's 15-member squad for South Africa Tests announced, Rahul dropped
column3: The BCCI on Thursday announced India's 15-member squad for the upcoming Test series against South Africa. KL Rahul has been dropped from the squad and has been replaced by 20-year-old Shubman Gill, who has scored 1,443 runs in 14 first-class matches at an average of 72.15. India-South Africa Test series will begin on October 2.

column2: 'Chandrakanta' director's son booked for forcibly kissing 6-yr-old boy
column3: The 45-year-old son of Nirja Guleri, director of 90s television show 'Chandrakanta', has been booked for allegedly forcibly kissing a 6-year-old boy in Delhi's Lodhi Garden. Police said preliminary investigation revealed the man is "mentally unstable", but only a medical examination will be able to confirm it. The boy's father claimed the incident happened when they went for a walk.

column2: 92% of J&K has no restrictions: MEA Spokesperson Raveesh Kumar
column3: Ministry of External Affairs Spokesperson Raveesh Kumar has said that 92% of Jammu and Kashmir had no restrictions. Kumar said that there was no shortage of medicines in the state and 95% of healthcare professionals were on duty. He added that banking facilities were operating normally in J&K. "We are very close to normalcy," said J&K DGP Dilbag Singh yesterday.

column2: Work on issues that matter: Kapil Sibal to PM on 'Om' comment
column3: Criticising PM Narendra Modi for saying some people believe India is going back to 16th century when they hear words 'Om' and 'cow', Congress' Kapil Sibal tweeted, "Instead of politically charged statements...worry about our Universities!" Sibal added, "First time since 2012: No Indian University in the top 300 World University Rankings list (Times Higher Education)...Work on issues that matter."

column2: Manmohan Singh gives 5 remedial steps to reverse economy slowdown
column3: Former Prime Minister Manmohan Singh suggested five measures to reverse the economic slowdown, which he said was "both structural and cyclic". He said that GST should be made "logical" despite revenue loss for some time. He asked to find ways to revive agriculture and increase rural consumption. He also suggested to revive main employment sectors like textile, automobile, and housing.

column2: Army officer posted with UN mission in Congo goes missing
column3: An Army officer posted in the India contingent in the UN Peacekeeping Mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo has been missing since Saturday, an officer stated. Lt Col Gaurav Solanki had gone kayaking with several officers and all of them returned except Solanki. Rescue and search operations are on, with speed boats and helicopters being pressed into service.

column2: 3 suspected terrorists coming from Punjab held with 6 AK-47s in J&K
column3: Three suspected terrorists were arrested in Jammu and Kashmir's Kathua district after their truck, coming from Punjab, was intercepted on Jammu-Pathankot Highway. Six AK-47 rifles were seized from them, Inspector General of Police Jammu, Mukesh Singh said. It's believed that either of these suspected militants infiltrated from across the International Border via Bamial border in Pathankot.

column2: Relaxing fines for now, sticking to old ones: UP Transport Minister
column3: Uttar Pradesh Transport Minister Ashok Katariya on Thursday said that the state government is relaxing the traffic rule violation fines for now. Speaking to ANI, Katariya said, "We are sticking to the old fines." "We will wait for the Centre to give its final nod," he further said.

column2: 15-yr-old only son commits suicide after parents scold him over PUBG
column3: A 15-year-old boy in Andhra Pradesh committed suicide after his parents scolded him for spending too much time playing PUBG. He was studying in Class 10 and was the couple's only son, a police officer said. "When his parents took away his phone and asked him to concentrate on studies, the teen was so upset, he killed himself," he added.

column2: Maths never helped Einstein discover gravity: Piyush Goyal
column3: Addressing a press conference on Thursday, Union Minister of Railways and Commerce & Industry, Piyush Goyal, said, "Don't get into the Maths about the economy...Maths never helped Einstein discover gravity." He added, "If we had only gone by the structured formulae and what was past knowledge, I don't think there would've been any innovation in this world."

column2: US SC allows enforcing new asylum rules affecting Central Americans
column3: The US' Supreme Court has allowed US President Donald Trump's administration to enforce new restrictions that would curtail asylum applications by Central American migrants at the US-Mexico border. The rule requires immigrants who want asylum in the US, to first seek asylum in a third country through which they travelled on their way to reach the US.

column2: Ford says it's not selling $1 billion Gujarat factory opened in 2015
column3: Ford Motor Company has denied reports that it plans to sell its newest factory in India located in Gujarat's Sanand. The American carmaker spent over $1 billion to build the Sanand plant, which opened in March 2015 and can produce up to 240,000 vehicles and 270,000 engines a year. Its other Indian factory in Chennai opened in 1995.

column2: Ali Fazal to star opposite Gal Gadot in ‘Death on the Nile’
column3: Actor Ali Fazal will share screen space with 'Wonder Woman' actress Gal Gadot in the upcoming film based on author Agatha Christie's 'Death on the Nile'. "I'm... excited to be part of this wonderful journey," he said. He had earlier acted in 'Victoria and Abdul' along with Judi Dench and also played a small role in 'Fast & Furious 7'.

column2: National Philatelic Museum in Delhi has stamps dating back to 1765
column3: National Philatelic Museum at Dak Bhawan, Delhi is dedicated to postage stamps where visitors can find stamps issued during the pre-independence days (1765-1947) by the Princely States of India. In addition to showcasing stamps from India, the museum also displays stamps from around the world. The museum also showcases thematic stamps like flora, science and technology and armed forces.

column2: Kerala holds annual Payippad Boat Race
column3: The Payippad Boat Race which is also known as the Payippad Vallamkali or the Jalotsavam is being held in Payippad Lake in Kerala. It is one of the most colourful festivals of the region with the largest participation of chundan vallams (snake boats). The boat race pays homage to Lord Sree Ayyappan and Lord Subramanya.

column2: Starting 462 Eklavya schools for tribal youth's development: PM
column3: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Thursday said that for the development and education of tribal children and youth, his government is starting a "big project". "We're setting up 462 Eklavya Model Residential Schools (EMRS) across the country," he added while addressing a gathering in Ranchi. The EMRS are aimed at providing quality education to the Scheduled Tribes' children.

column2: Yahoo Japan to buy majority stake in Zozo for $3.7 bn
column3: Yahoo Japan has agreed to pay about $3.7 billion for a majority stake in online fashion shopping site Zozo Inc. Yahoo Japan said it would launch a tender offer to buy about 50.1% stake in Zozo for nearly $24 per share. That is a 21% premium on Zozo's Wednesday's closing price. Zozo founder Yusaku Maezawa will step down as CEO.

column2: Gas tank explodes at HPCL plant in Unnao, 3 injured
column3: A gas tank exploded in a plant of Hindustan Petroleum Corporation Limited (HPCL) in Uttar Pradesh's Unnao on Thursday, officials said. At least three people are reported to be injured and people in the adjoining areas have been asked to vacate their houses and shift to safer places. Factories and villages in the vicinity have been put on high alert.

column2: Russia 'concerned' by Israel's plan to annex Jordan Valley
column3: Russia condemned Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu's plan to annex the Jordan Valley ahead of a meeting between the Israeli leader and President Vladimir Putin on Thursday. Russia said it was concerned with Netanyahu's recent announcement and noted the Arab world's "strongly negative reaction" to it. This could undermine hope for establishing peace between Israel and its Arab neighbours, Russia added.

column2: Krunal shares KBC question featuring him, tags Big B & says 'lock D'
column3: Mumbai Indians all-rounder Krunal Pandya took to Twitter to share a question from 'Kaun Banega Crorepati' featuring his surname 'Pandya' in the options, writing, "Sir, 'D' ko lock kiya jaye please" while tagging Amitabh Bachchan. "What is the surname of the brothers who play for Mumbai Indians?" the question read. Notably, Krunal and brother Hardik both play for Mumbai Indians.

column2: Pakistan denies second consular access to Kulbhushan Jadhav
column3: Dr Mohammad Faisal, Spokesperson, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Pakistan on Thursday said, "There would be no second consular access to Kulbhushan Jadhav." Pakistan had earlier offered consular access to the retired Indian Navy officer in August. This was after the International Court of Justice found Pakistan guilty of violating the Vienna Convention and ordered it to grant Jadhav consular access.

column2: Copying doesn't work but inspiration is important: Himesh on Lata's remark
column3: Singer Himesh Reshammiya has said Lata Mangeshkar's "imitation isn't a reliable and durable companion for success" remark on Ranu Mondal has been misunderstood. "I feel when you start copying another singer it doesn't work that well. But I also feel that taking inspiration from someone is really important," he added. Social media users had earlier criticised Lata for her remark.

column2: Kevin Hart released from hospital 10 days after car accident: Reports
column3: Actor-comedian Kevin Hart was released from hospital 10 days after he injured his back in a car accident, as per reports. The 40-year-old is now recovering from his injury in a rehabilitation facility, reports added. He had reportedly undergone back surgery due to the "major back injuries" he suffered in the accident.

column2: I never lost hope, listened to songs & learned continuously: Mondal
column3: Speaking about her newfound fame, Ranu Mondal said, "I never lost hope. Yes, the magnitude of the stage given to me by Himesh ji, is something that maybe I didn't anticipate." "I never stopped listening to songs...I used to listen...on cassettes and learn continuously," she added. Ranu further said she's grateful to Himesh Reshammiya for giving her an opportunity.

column2: Kashmir is India's integral part, Jamiat Ulama-i-Hind adopts resolution
column3: Muslim organisation Jamiat Ulama-i-Hind has adopted a resolution that Kashmir is an integral part of India. "It's our firm belief [Kashmiri people's] welfare lies in getting integrated with India," it added. "Pakistan is trying to project on the international forum that Indian Muslims are against India, we condemn this act of Pakistan," JuH's Mahmood Madani said.

column2: Gilgit-Baltistan technically India's part: Ex-European Union official
column3: Former official of European Union Brian Toll supported India's move to revoke Article 370 and said Gilgit-Baltistan, which is currently under Pakistan-occupied Kashmir, is "technically a part of India". "The [revoking] of Article 370 is actually about giving more economic opportunities to the people in Kashmir, according to the government. Let's hope it works," he stated.

column2: Dhoni made me run like in a fitness test: Kohli shares throwback pic
column3: India captain Virat Kohli took to social media to share a throwback picture of himself bowing down to MS Dhoni after winning 2016 World T20 match against Australia. "A game I can never forget...Special night. This man, made me run like in a fitness test," Kohli captioned the picture. Kohli had slammed an unbeaten 82 to help India reach semi-finals.

column2: Google confirms its subscription service Play Pass to launch 'soon'
column3: Google took to Twitter to confirm that it's working on a service 'Play Pass', saying, "It's almost time. Google Play Pass is coming soon." The service was earlier reported to be in testing, which would offer users "hundreds of premium apps and games" for a monthly fee. This comes days after Apple announced its own subscription gaming service 'Apple Arcade'.

column2: Apple flashes encrypted 'We love you' text in iPhone 11 launch recap
column3: Apple flashed a message encrypted in binary in a video recap of its September 10 product launch event. In the flash, Apple said, "It might be nice to have some sort of easter egg message in here for hardcore Apple fans that'll stop the video." The translated message read, "So you took the time to translate this? We love you."

column2: Security flaw exposes private Instagram posts, Stories to public
column3: A security flaw affecting Facebook-owned Instagram lets users with a basic understanding of a browser and the computer language HTML to publicly access private posts and Stories, BuzzFeed News revealed. A user can pull out the source URL by inspecting a post, which can be shared with others. Facebook responded by saying that the hack is like taking a screenshot.

column2: Ola, Uber may not be big factor in auto sector slowdown: Maruti
column3: Maruti Suzuki Executive Director (Marketing and Sales) Shashank Srivastava has said Ola and Uber may not be a big factor in the current slowdown. He said that people in India still purchase cars with an "aspirational aspect". "People may use...Ola and Uber to go to offices...but still they buy a vehicle for the weekend outings with the family," he said.

column2: Journo assaulted by Uber driver, says police refused to file complaint
column3: A journalist has accused an Uber driver of harassing and assaulting her and her colleague when they were travelling from Greater Noida to Delhi. She claimed that the driver made racial remarks against them and pulled her laptop bag and held her colleague by his neck when they were getting down. Police also refused to lodge her complaint, she added.

column2: ISRO will surely try to fix Moon lander issue: Serge Haroche
column3: French scientist Serge Haroche on Wednesday said, "I don't know what happened with [Moon lander Vikram] but [ISRO] will certainly try to solve the problem." On the sidelines of 'Nobel Prize Series India 2019' event in Mohali, the 2012 Physics Nobel Prize winner said science is something where you're going in the unknown. "Sometimes you have bad surprises," he added.

column2: Reunite 8 girls from Muzaffarpur shelter home with families: SC
column3: While hearing the Muzaffarpur shelter home sexual assault case on Thursday, the Supreme Court directed Bihar government to take steps to unite eight out of 44 girls with their family members. The order came after a field action project of TISS, 'Koshish', told the court that the eight girls are fit to be handed over to their families.

column2: Not bad, but good roads reason for accidents: K'taka Dy CM Karjol
column3: Karnataka Deputy Chief Minister Govind Karjol has said, "Every year the state witnesses around 10,000 road accidents. The media said the reason...was bad roads but I said no...the reason was good roads." He claimed people drive at the speed of 120-160 kmph on good roads.
